Tasted many times over the years, but most memorable was from Magnum at Akkurat. Pours a glowing orange color with small head. Aroma is complex, with orange juice, citrus peel, slight oak, barnyard funk, yeast, and lime. The palate is sour, at times with bracing acidity, but always brought back with flavors of earth, sweet citrus, oak, and yeast (Brett & lacto). Always a nice drink.

Bottle 37,5 cl. Pours hazy yellow and orange with fast vanishing head. Nice sour and bitter at the beginning. Notes of citrus, some sort of berries, tarts, earthy, floral, some yeast, fruity, funky. Smooth finish. An good gueuze.

375ml bottle. Golden amber colour, foam white head that diminishes and aroma of straw, bready earthy yeast & sourish fruits. Taste is sour, acidic tart, fruity & yeasty with some lingering bitterness. Very smooth mouthfeel, light to medium bodied, soft to medium carbonation, dry tart finish. Interesting, refreshing and very drinkable.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours hazy, yet vibrant orange with a small, dense beige head which has great retention. Nose shows loads of straw and earthy notes - grassy & herbal. Some pungent citric fruits come out as it warms. Funk isnt over the top. Very refreshing and almost juicy as it brings you back quickly for more. Quite fruit driven with some damp wood and grassy undertones. Very wet. Very drinkable. A very solid, all round sour
Draught at the brewery. Golden colour with a quickly vanishing white head. Sour acidic fruit aroma. Flavour is sour, acidic, bitter. Sour finish.
37.5cl bottle @ home, from Maes Dendermonde; hazy blonde with small white foam; low carbonation; smell is acidic, a bit lemony; taste is quite acidic, tart, dry. Decent beer.

375ml bottle at the Sybarite Pig in Boca Raton, FL. Shared with friends. Small snifter. Light in color (yelow) and thick white head. Funky, sour aroma with light fruits and bread. The taste was acidic, sour, funky, fruity, and yeasts. The finish was dry and clean. Light body and tingling mouth. One of the best I have ever had.

Bottle at the Cantillon Brewery. Pours orange brown. Aroma has a lot of lemon peel, wood, damp hay, white grapes and acidic bacterial yeast notes. Taste was really refreshing, lots of sharp acidic zest notes, white grapes, champagne and hay. Upfront but not offensive carbonation, backed by a refreshing bitterness. The type of beer you dream about on a hot summers day!

375ml bottle, pours slightly hazy golden brown with small foamy white head. Aroma is on the sour side, lemon, grape combine with herbs & grass, with a tart acidy sourness dancing on the tongue leaving a sharp lemony finish. Ive not always enjoyed Lambics & sour ales but this was really good.
375 CL bottle at home, yellow/orange beer with a white head, damn this beer is sour it was drinkable but taste is lemon (?) and sour, after-taste is dry, strange beer.

2013 750ml at my place with Taylor Thomas Scott and Erin. Pours a nice orange. Aroma of orange start tart and a little lemon. Taste is well balanced, medium tart, great Gueze. Finish is kind of quick but nice. Lighter mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
The aroma is sour, funk, and lemon. Pour a golden yellow. taste is a medium sour, tart and vinegary, it gives you nice pucker but finishes beautifully dry. It is very light bodied but acidic.

Originally reviewed on 08-27-13. 750ml bottle, vintage 1994, old-school label. Thanks to westcoastbeerlvr for this one.

Pours a hazy muddled golden yellow color, fizzy white head, some bottles on top, wisps here and there, thin film on top. Soft lemon tartness, citrus, subtle funk, straw, damp oak. All very mellow and subtle, nothing sharp about this beer. The age has mellow this one out, very smooth. A wonderful soft tart lemon citrus, nice funk, hay, straw, old stuff, oak. Again, soft and mellow is what this one is all about. Nice and dry, great acidity, slight pucker. Light, soft, good carbonation, dry finish.

One of the best beers Ive ever had from the 1990s. This was just so impressive, I was in awe.

The aroma hits as soon as the cork pops with a complex medley of old wood barns and stables.

Crisp, tart and very dry, in fact incredibly dry, almost too much so, but actually keeps me coming back for more.

This might take a little getting used to, but rewards are there, and plentiful.

Pours an orange hazy colour with an off white head. Aroma is funky, basement aromas, sourness. Taste is sour, crisp, funky, fruity notes. Medium body, lively carbonation. Finish is sour, crisp, refreshing.
750ml. Février 2012. Très acide. Levure sauvage. Citronné. Limonade. Floral. Terreuse. Moisi. Rafraichissante. Un bijou.

It pours a hazy translucent golden colour, with a slight orange tint; the head is off-white and foamy. The aroma has notes of: lemon-juice, barnyard funk, wet-hay, and very sharp yeast notes. The taste is heavy sour that finishes medium dry with a light bitterness; there are notes of: barnyard funk, lemon-juice, earthy notes, and straw. The palate is full-bodied, sticky, has medium carbonation, and a long sour/dry finish. Overall, a stupendously stanky gueuze.
One of my favorites. Love the earthiness of the aroma and taste. Color is outstanding, clear.

Drank from a 375 ml bottle à Saint-Graal brewpub in Sainte-Thérèse (Quebec) on July 12, 2013. Blonde somewhat clear, small head. Aroma of herbs and barley slightly sour notes of vinegar. Taste a bit the same, but a little fruit, notes of barley sugar, good acid aftertaste.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2015 4 oz pour at Dougs tasting. My first Cantillon. Bottled Oct 2012. Bio bottle. Aroma is sour lemons and apples with some funk. Taste is moderately sour, less than I was expecting. Pretty acidic, lots of lemons. Solid.  Re-rate 12/14/15 with regular Cantillion Gueuze.  Two year old bottle.  Huge funky cotton, barnyard and hay.  Very dry taste with tons of barnyard and funk.  Its cool for what it is but Im not seeking this out again.  There are other gueuzes I like better that are easier to get.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2013 Vintage 2002.Smells: funk, sour, fruit, green apples. Quickly dissapearing head. Murky applejuice appearance. Spritz carbonation medium/full body. Aftertaste of smooth funk with mild sour finish. Overall: very fun to taste. More subtle.
Lekker van smaak en een heerlikk aroma. Weinig koolzuur wat wel wat wegneemt van het genot

Bottle shared by drsordr. Pours a lightly hazy dark golden color with a medium sized white head that quickly disappears. The aroma has sour citrus, lemons, funk, acidity and horseblanket character. The flavor is more sour citrus, lemon, acidity, hay, that is a bit musty. I find that as much as I enjoy this, I lack some of the vocabulary I think I need to do it justice.

Bottle shared with two friends at Monks cafe in Philly. 
Pours a lightly hazy dark straw color with a decent sized bone white head that displays moderate retention. The aroma is lemons in your face with a solid hit of grass and hay with a bit of bretty funkiness that lingers and swirls. The flavor is a bit sour with lemons and pomme fruits being dominant. A hint of honey sweetness before a bready bretty yeastiness takes over. Long tart puckering finish begs for a cleanse of the palette which I am all too happy to oblige. Medium body with a tart puckering mouthfeel and a spirited level of carbonation. Great brew, venue, and friends to share the experience with, what more could I ask for.
Amazing, thanks to friends of GT2, bright orange, nice complex nose, smells of apples, right amount of sour, amazing.
Classic and lovely. Pours hazy yellow. Aromas of cider, barnyard and grapes. Shapr lemon on the taste, initially really sour, but with a balancing sweet finish. World Classic Beer.

This one made my day. Starting with the typical geuze in the nose like a ripe apple this ones is of course very special, really sour and offers an interesting bitter end. But easy to this that it is different with a wide range of aromas. Not the best beer in the world, but one of the more special and VERY refreshing.

375 ml bottle. Pours a lightly veiled goldenish straw with a resilient white head. Aroma is brett, mostly. Jungle, humid, forest, oldish. Flavor is sour candy, unripe fruits, light annoying skunk. Finish is tart, sour, very subtle bitterness. Light body, watery mouthfeel, low to average carbonation. Not the best gueuze, but still pretty solid.

Hazy orange-yellow colour with airy but low creamy head and medium body. Nose of peaches and flowers. Taste of medium sour Lambic, thin grass, flowers and citrus. Flowery and fruity finish. Very refreshing and easy to drink - enjoyed it.

Pours cloudy golden amber with no head. Smells of vinegar, fruit, and cider. Tastes sour, bitter, tangy, and citrus. Has a long sour finish with little to no carbonation. I am not a fan of Gueuze but this is the best I have had.
Cloudy lemonade pour, no head. Aroma of lemon and yeast funk, some earthiness. Taste is similar, big earthy taste and lemon zest.

350 mL bottle. Aromas of chamomile, lemon zest, fresh cut grass and yeasty brett funk. Bone dry with plenty of sourness and a distinct barnyard aftertaste with a touch of hops. Complex and well built.

Serving: 375 ml. bottle from a secret loon source. It pours a hazy orange with a pillowy white head. The nose jumps out as soon as you pop the cork. Lots of hay, lemon, cider vinegar, and barnyard notes. Sharply tart on the tongue, with nice lemon pith, yeast, barnyard, and funk notes. Very dry on the back end. The perfect beverage for a hot day. Love it.
Bottle from Trade..Pour is an orange, with a thin white head..Nose is musty,funk, dry, basement, horse blanket..Taste is tartness, dry, sweetness, grape, lemons, dry..Nice classic
UPDATED: JUL 4, 2013 Pours a golden beer with a not very long lasting head. Great gueze with a nice bitter finish.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2014 Bottle. Hazy yellow towards orange with a small white head. Musty, barnyard, white grapes, lime, apricot, light oak. Light/medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Medium sweet and medium/heavy sour. Very thirst quenching summer favorite.

750ml bottle. Clear golden colour with average, foamy, half-way lasting, white head. Spicy and sourish aroma, a minimally peppery, spicy yeast touch, hints of mustard, also a floral note. Taste is sourish, lemon juice, vinegar, in the finish with a dry and astringent character.

Bottle. The pour is a decent yellow. The aroma is a little vinegar. The taste is a smooth sour. Drinks easy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2009 vintage, shared by an unnamed fellow, thanks!
Nice yellow colour
Aroma is quite strong, stronger than in other geuzes Ive had. Tartness, funk, citrus, slight yeast at the end.
Taste is slightly sour at first but builds up and get more vinegary and citrusy at the end.
Dry mouthfeel, medium carbonation. Nice and refreshing!

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 3/17/2010.  Pours slightly hazy golden amber color with a 2 finger dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers.  Slight spotty lacing clings on the glass.  Aromas of big tart green apple, lemon, pear, grape, clove, pepper, oak, leather, hay, grass, straw, funk, white vinegar, wheat, and earthy yeast spiciness.  Fantastic aromas with great balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast notes with a good amount of barrel presence; and good strength.  Taste of big tart green apple, lemon, pear, grape, clove, oak, pepper, hay, grass, straw, leather, wheat, white vinegar, funk, and yeast earthiness.  Moderate tart acidity on the finish; with lingering notes of tart light fruits, clove, oak, pepper, hay, grass, straw, wheat, white vinegar, funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while.  Incredible balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast ester flavors; with a good amount of oak presence and zero cloying acidity on the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a crisp and moderately acidic mouthfeel that is great.  Alcohol is very well hidden with no warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a world class Gueuze!  All around incredible complexity and balance of flavors and aromas; and extremely smooth to sip on, even with the acidity.  Completely amazing stuff as expected.
Okay...not a big gueuze fan there are only a few guezes i drunk that i kinda liked...and im lucky this is one of em.

.375l bottle @ Harrys
Pours clear yellow with low head. Aroma is yeast, malts, citrus fruits and pine. Some berries and herbs. Flavor is sour. Herbs, pine, malts and some white wine. Swell!
Bottle pour clear yellow.  Nose sour, Brett, some spice and breadiness. Taste tart, sour, lemon, hint of pineapple.  Some sweetness on the back end.

Fantastic looking beer with a bright rusty golden colour with a fizzy white cap that dissipates right away.  Aroma is tart and funky.  Taste is very tart with a lasting sourness of green apple and lemon, but some soft pepper and oak too.  Great geuze.
Gedronken bij dutchdrebus, oranje van kleur en niet helder, kleine witte schuimkraag, ruikt muf, zuur en fruitig, lekker

Aroma is a bit odd at first and a bright glowing yellow body. The first sip is sheer vinegarrish awesomeness but subsides into a mellow sourness with funked notes and heavy bitterness on the finish. Just exceptional
Bottled. Hazy orange colour, foamy white head. Bitter apricot and apple aroma. Bitter apricot flavour with very bitter finish. One of the better geuze for me.

Had many bottles of this as close to perfect as beer can get. Intense sour tart cheese barnyard funkiness with citrus grapes and yeast. Quite heavily carbonated, perfect. Ive tried it straight from the barrel at the brewery and thats even better 4.8
citrus, vinegar, yeasty, heavily sour, lively carbonation, natural, complex

A - Slightly hazy golden-orange with a finger of frothy slightly off-white head. Fades normal.

S - Sweet wheat, funk, tart green fruits, oak, vanilla, lactic acid, lemon zest.

T - Wheat, lots of barnyard and yeast funk, tart green fruits, oak, vanilla, lactic acid, lemon zest, sourness.

M - Medium bodied, moderate carbonation. Smooth with a dry, tart, funky, and sour finish.

D - Great complex and balanced gueuze.
Have had this at alot of diffrent times. Always a very good beer. Gets better with some age.

Keg at The Hop & The Glory- 15th May. Well the first thing to note is there isn't as much carbonation as the bottled version. But frankly that's a good thing. I won't bore you with the rest of the details.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
user_location: The big bad LDN, Greater London, ENGLAND

text: Classic bottle. 2011 Vintage. This truly was awesome. I havent been disappointed by a Cantillon yet. This certainly puts the silk and finesse back into a bottle of Gueuze. One the most drinkable examples that Ive ever that experienced. Doesnt destroy your palate or make your stomach curdle. Just tastes great. While not the best sour that Ive ever had, I would happily drink this before most. Very well done.

Bottle. Pours hazy straw yellow, a finger of milky white head. Lively carbonation. Horse blanket and meadowgrass up front, huge acetic tartness. Lots of grapefruit and tangerine, hay, pee, light woody notes. More wood on the backend, biscuity malt finish. Nice and clean.

Bottle from Cotteridge wines. Orange amber beer with no head. Aroma of light vinegar and cat piss. Taste is again a little light vinegar, white wine and very tart and sour. Not one for me Im afraid, big disappointment.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text:
Bottled Feb 3, 2012. Been awhile since I've had this one, and that's a shame. Funky cheese, lemon citrus, and yeast aroma. Taste follows suit with more lemon peel than expected and a delicious, dry sourness profile on my palate.

So, I strongly prefer this to the 3F Oude Geuze & OGV, and I'm happy to be in the minority here. Classic Gueuze is simply fantastic, and I need more ASAP.

Picture this:
Youre standing in the door of a threshing barn, looking out over an orchard with apples, lemons and oranges.
The setting sun pours an amber haze over everything. You close your eyes and feel the suns warmth on your face, and the smells of the fruit - sweet and sour, almost stinging -, and barn - wood, somewhat mouldy, different cereals, dust, undefinable funk - swirl and mingle.
And you feel like youd want to stay there forever.

Thats Cantillon geuze: amber to golden colour, your expected barnyard funky smell, and a very sour bite to it, just enough alcohol to warm you without burning. Its a geuze, and i happen to love those, and this one is quite exceptional.
The ONLY pure and natural geuze: no addition of any yeasts, the wort is inoculated with wild yeast spores in the air.
The original beer, in every sense.

Bottle. December 2011. Opaque golden honey with a thin white head which disappeared almost completely instantly. A big sniff reveals something which smells like no other beer Ive had before, salty and zesty with a little malt. A bit like a light sweat. Apple and cider smells. Theres a little clementine juice in there too. Drinking the first mouthful is a bit of a shock, doesnt really have much of a "taste" persay but a real heavy sourness. Then suddenly the tastes are revealed - grapes, citrus, apple, cider, wheat hit. Really tastes like a good white wine. Tons of natural carbonation helping this to not overpower the mouth and the palate is fresh and long - like drinking a good wine. Really interesting, and a real sipper of a beer. Might have to grab a few of these for cellaring and serving at special occasions. medium body,

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Vintage 2010. Small head. Golden clear. Nutty aromas. Faint malty notes. Very pleasant mild tartness. Dry long finish.

Bouteille 375ml sous le nom de "Gueuze 100% Lambic Bio", courtoisie de mathieuc. De couleur dorée et voilée. Nez de levures sauvages fruitées sûres et acides (pommes vertes, léger de citron, traces de cerises sûres et dabricots), légèrement rustiques et terreuses avec des petites notes épicées (poivre doux), légèrement boisé (bois humide) avec des traces herbeuses et de fromage vieilli. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement  moyen et légèrement croustillant ainsi quune texture légèrement champenoise et aux petites traces huileuses. Goût de levures sauvages fruitées acides et moyennement sûres (citron, moyen de pommes vertes, notes dabricots, faibles traces de cerises sûres et de raisins verts), moyennement rustiques,  légèrement terreuses et aux petites traces épicées dès lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute de faibles notes de fromage vieilli avec des petites traces de cuir puis en toute fin, lon retrouve de faibles notes herbeuses asséchantes (foin). Post-goût moyen-long et sec, assez aigre (aussi acide que sûr) de levures sauvages fruitées (zeste de citron, pelures de pommes, traces de moût de raisins) aux petites notes terreuses et herbeuses.

A true classic gueze, worthy of its reputation. This a refined but funky gueze that I could drink and drink. Very lightly carbonated, small head which dissipates into nothing quickly.. Aromas are funky soggy cut grass..  Tastes sour but refreshing,
Lovely citric attack on the nose. Cork is also full of vinegar notes. Mouth is chock full of wonderful but quickly fading coarse citrusy tastes...
UPDATED: DEC 31, 2016 Cider like aromas while pouring from a couple feet away.  Clear gold.  Green apple, dust, dried apple, some hay.  Complex, smooth, and very balanced.

750ml bottle poured a light cloudy yellow color with aromas of musk, dust, light apples, and some earth.  Flavors are the same, light vinegar, earthy notes, decent beer overall, glad a I have a few more of this bottles laying around.
Klassik god geuze. Frugt og eddike der læsker ganen dejligt. Godt alternativ til den kedelige pilsner i parken i sommersolen.

Pours a cloudy light orange with little head that falls quickly with no or little lacing. Aroma of funk, hay, light horse blanket. Taste is funky, sour, hay motes with some lemon tartness, light oak. Medium carbonation with low mouthfeel. A good classic gueuze but i would take 3F, tilquin or girardin over this one any time.
Poured into a snifter. Orange with a slight white head. Smells of slight vinegar and apple. Taste is super sour apple and again with the vinegar... Very dry finished. Solid.

75cl consumed at the Delirium Cafe, pours up with a crystal clear gold body and supporting a lasting white head of foam. The modest aroma offers up soft vinegar, some apple juice sweetened apple skins and a bit of earthy basement. The taste is pretty bold in vinegar sourness and acidic like tartness. I get some lemon and lime acidity mixing with sweetened and soft sour vinegar notes. It gets mighty dry to midway and into the finish where it is more puckering than anything else.
Bottle purchased at the brewery.  Well balanced sourness and earthy character.  Very refreshing and easy drinking.

375 ml bottle at L'Autre-Oeil. Pours a clear gold with a small white head. Aroma is sour berries and green apple. Taste is a pleasant citric tartness with a touch of sweetness. Mouthfeel is sharp, with a medium sour finish. Very nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy

Jaune nuageux avec une petite mousse blanche. Larôme est très fort dagrumes dominé par de citron, orange aigre, et pamplemousse. Il y a aussi un peu de levure. Le goût est pareille. Plein dagrumes au début, un peu aigre en finale, mais pas trop. Comme une salade dagrumes.

75 cl bottled 24 September 2010. Clear apple juice color, soft pour leaves no head. (2nd pour is opaque) Aroma is tart fruitiness and yeasty funk. Taste is tart and acidic, granny smith apples, sour green grapes, lemony, citrusy, and light earthy yeast funk. Lightly carbed, light bodied, low hopped. Light and refreshing, easy to drink, finishes dry. Not sure what all the fuss is about, this is okay at best. LF (Lagerboy Friendly)

Per gli amanti delle birre acide è un must. Birra citrica, poco carbonata, dissetante come poche altre, con un finale molto astringente. Una di quelle birre che ti fa venire letteralmente lacquolina in bocca, e che non finiresti ai di bere. Direi anche la birra perfetta per entrare ne mondo lambic.

Bottle @Cantillon  end of March 2013. Bevuta alla fine del giro del museo. In rapida successione dopo la lambic si apprezza per un colore più intenso tendente allaranciato. La schiuma è soffice quasi impalpabile. La carbonatazione non è eccessiva, solletica solo il palato. Il Luppolo è intenso sia al naso che sulla lingua, molto profumato, tra lerbaceo  ed il citrico.  In bocca ha poco corpo (un pregio in questo caso) ed una beva che assomiglia a quella del prosecco sur-lie... Il finale è astringente.

12.7 ounce bottle purchased at Corti Brothers in Sacramento.  The aroma is acetic with vinegar hints as well as some cheesy funk notes as well.  Hints of lemon tartness are also present.  Rather aromatic, if not one-dimensional.  Virtually transparent golden body present with a medium, fizzy off-yellow head.  Cork removal was weak.  Starts quite tart with sour apple character present immediately.  The middle has a weird, bitter harshness present.  Astringent, acidic, and acetic throughout.  Finishes with a bit of pimento olive juice flavor, and more, dry tartness.  Pretty good, but a little harsh in the middle.

75cl bottle, served in Cantillon glass @ Homo Sibaris bar. Pours light foggy orange with small white frothy head (persistent though). Green apples and citrusy notes in both aroma and taste. Pretty sour and lemony, but actually well balanced. Some fruits presence with hints of white grape as well. Dry finish. Medium body, perfect carbonation. I dont use to drink beers like this, but was pleasant overall.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2013 Thanks to Brian.  Sour-sweet aroma.  Complex flavor, with a cidery sourness, some oak, and a dash of apple skin bitterness.  Glad I finally got to try it - and I can see how some beer geeks seem to get obsessed with gueuze.

Pours amber with low white head
Aromas of sour fruits, yeast, complexities hard to explain but I really like it
Wow! Lovely sweet n sour of citrusy fruits and hints of sweet ones. Low carbonation, medium bodied and low bitterness.
It is highly enjoyable fresh and sour. Good stuff!

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2015 July 2012 - Like a sour lemonade, maybe some tomato, nice level of carbonation.  Seemed to give me a headache. (3.2)
June 2015 - Magnum bottle shared at Pauls 30th in Croydon.  Many thanks to Paul.  Hazy orange, small foamy off-white head.  Aroma is sour apple, tangerine.  Body is medium to light, dry, smooth, low carbonation, maybe slightly foamy.  Taste is tangy, dry, lemons, straw, not acidic or tooth-rotting.  Left a better impression this time. (3.8)

37.5 CL bottle from de hopduvel in Gent. Aroma of soft citrus and yeast. 
Very sour taste. This is not the best Geuze if you ask me. *

Aroma: lemon, some oak and spice, hay, earthy funk.
Appearance: slightly hazy light golden color, fizzy white head dissipates quickly and leaves little lacing.
Flavor: tart lemons, dry and slightly oaky, citrus, hay, nice spicy Brett character without a lot of funk.
Palate: light body, low-medium carbonation, prickly and dry.
Overall: nice brew.

Bottiglia 37,5cl
Lambic di difficile bevuta.
Molto acida e salata.
Le prime volte difficilmente piace.
Col tempo si apprezza la notevole complessità

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2013 Draught at Torst BK.  Light yellow and cloudy.  No head.  Aroma of Brett, light sour funk, horse blanket, very well rounded, lovely, slight sharp.  Flavor is herbal bitter, dull sour, lightly astringent.  Light clean body with a silt finish. Not as awesome as expected but still great.


Bottle drank at a 4.5

Sample pour at Hunahpus. Hazed straw with white fluffed head. Nose is citric with plenty of light fruit and lemon peel. Flavor is quite tart with moderate sour. Some straw notes with fresh grass. Nice and drinkable.
Hazy gold,white head.Pungent sour nose. Tart vinous puckery palate, very dry finish. Overpriced, and over rated. Actually a drain pour for me even tho I do like this style.
From tap. Yellow cloudy pour with minimal white head. Wine-like aroma of grapes and wild yeast. Initial bite is way too sour, but taste mellows as you drink it. Overpriced and overhyped IMO.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2015 Blind tasting off 18 current available Gueuzes. Shared with Mathieu87.
Appearance: no head.
Nose: fruity, little bit wood.
Taste: nice and sour, rather soft aftertaste.
8-3-9-4-12
Re-rate: 2006 vintage bottle at the brewery! Shared with Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: blond beer, head started nice, but fades away very fast.
NOSE: barnyard, little florar, horse blanket, little fruity.
TASTE: very sour, barnyard.
Completely different beer from a regular young one!

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2013 Rated from beer log during 2009 Belgium trip... Aroma is funky, not tart, not sweet... Funky. Cloudy and light orange-tan, cloudier than other gueuzes Ive had...very tart flavor, but more funky than the other gueuzes, flavor is powerful and while the flavor is tart, the finish that lingers is pure funk... Very much more complex than the other gueuzes and a great preview of Cantillon

A pale and cloudy yellow colour, with a medium frothy head. I tried gueuze twice before, this was my third tasting and Im defenitely not into that style of beer ! Aromas are citrus, hops, yeast and spices. On the tongue, its salty and sour. Too weird for me.

At gollem 
Pours clear blonde , almost no foam
Smell is typical cantillon 
taste is soft , sour, balanced , Apples??
Very good one

Classic sour profile.. Clean, mouthwatering, lacto/lemon citrus/herb resin.. Dry, dry, dry.. Sooo easy to drink.. Each sip makes you crave more.. A benchmark Gueuze. A must try for those interested in sours..

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2013 Very special and famous Gueuze. First taste of cidre and chemicals. A feeling of uncertainty is creeping to you - do I really like this product. Yes, I like it very much. Really a fresh member in the beer family. If you need some day something special, try this. Special thanks for well chosen, bitter hops! Could suit well together with crepes - must test!

pours almost clear bright yellow with a very nice frothy white head, good retention and lacing. tart apples, yet sugary granny smith, lemon, cantillon fun(k), peppery, spicy, soft oaky notes, herbs, medium sourness, tingling finish. sharp acidity and dry herbal-peppery finish. bright carbonation - mouthfeel is perfect. very nice!
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2013 Drunk at Herman Bar, Berlin. As sour as you would expect it :) Solid! Would drink again.

The aroma has sour notes,  some leathery taste and slight aroma. It is a golden opaque pour. The palate is strong upfront, but disseminates fast.  Thin white head, and when swirling you get lacing that leaves immediately. There is a definite aftertaste, which is nice and rewarding. Not overly sour, but complex to say the least.

Pours cloudy gold. Fruity sweet aroma with funky yeasty notes. Tart ripe fruit notes with green apple and some funk. Bright carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

De couleur dorée, légèrement voilée, ayant une fine mousse qui, pour le peu quelle possède, persiste. Des odeurs de levures sauvages bien dosées, accompagnées darômes dagrumes de toutes sortes. Le goût est agréablement acidulé où ses saveurs se séparent en deux étapes. Dès lentrée en bouche, on est envahi par des saveurs citronnées qui nous laisse un arrière-goût légèrement amer, ainsi que dautres fruits, tel le fruit de la passion et le citron, qui reviennent, ou du moins, refont surface, avec assez de force. Le mot clé est sûr. (504-03113)

37,5cl 1998. Sedvanliga surölsdofter. Stall mango kompost. Frisk och fruktig. Smaken är fantastiskt komplex och har toner av mango och vin, i typ 2 sekunder sedan kommer grapefrukt ganska dominerande i smakbilden. Grapefrukt sitter i resten av smakbilden, men inte så att det stör. Åldrats väl denna fantastiska öl
Bottle 0.375 at Oluthuone Leskinen. Bottle 2011 December. Colour is golden with small white head. Aromas and flavours are acid, fruits, grape and sourness.

375ml bottle. Pours a clear, bright medium gold, with a small white head, which does not last all that long nor leave much lacing. Leather, champagne and some funky sour notes create an alluring aroma. Green apple up front leads into dry champagne, with some sourness leading into a leathery, woody flavour in the mid-palate. It ends strongly tart and sour, with cider apple and lemon-lime notes. There is a lingering sour and leathery aftertaste. This is a very good beer, not only potently sour, but with serious complexity to back it up. Great stuff.

Reviewed 12/31/2012. Thanks to Momar42 for all three gueuzes (and the kriek surprise afterwards!) This was part of the gueuze showdown, pitting Tilquins gueuze against the juggernaut duo known as Cantillon Gueuze and Drie Fonteinen Oude Geuze. Part of a 750mL bottle poured into a Cantillon tulip. Notes from last nights Skins/Cowboys game.

A: Pours a hazy golden color. The head is a half finger white color with poor retention.

S: This one had the most balanced hybrid between winy fruit tartness and earthy funk. A very expressive aroma, and the best one of the three (by a small margin).

T: Acetic sourness comes on the palate fast and hard, and then afterwards cheesy, earthy funk...finishes the flavor profile fast and hard. This was the boldest and most complex of the three, yet it wasnt that much harsher than the 3F (certainly it was somehow more subtle than Tilquins offering). Shockingly easy to drink for me.

M: The finish is the dirtiest and most tannic of the three, closing the palate with big dryness, yet minimal harshness. This one is actually pretty thick in its texture, accentuating a fuller level of carbonation than the 3F Oude Geuze.

O: This was the winner in my book - but I wouldnt dare recommend this one to beginners. There is a sense of subtle delicacy to it; however the bigness of the acetic sourness, wet hay, and cheesy funk WILL scare off the average Fat Tire drinker the way a celery stalk scares off a fat kid. And moreso than the other two gueuzes, in fact. To those acclimated to the styles idiosyncrasies, this ones hard to beat.

375ml Bottle from Good Spirits Co., Glasgow (£5.20):
Tarty initally with some sourness and a fair amount of lemon and sour grapes. There is a lot of different fruits noticeable on the nose; these include some apple and peach along with a strong acidic aroma.

Bright and cloudy, orange amber colour with a one centimetre tall, short lived head that was bubbly and disappeared fast leaving only a few bits of white lace around the circumference on the glass.
Acidic and tarty up front with a nice mix of lemon, some vinegar and sour grapes. There is some lemongrass and a nice acidic bite with plenty of additional sourness. The flavour is one that enhances tenfold once left to settle for a few minutes too.

Very smooth, sour and tarty on the palate with a light body, plenty of carbonation and a crisp finish.

Quite a good beer, but only after it opens up a little and has been left to settle for a couple of minutes to left the extremly sour and tarty flavours die down some. It was a great beer though with plenty of depth and character, it was also pretty much what I was expecting for the beer.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2014 Bottled. Pours deep golden and slightly hazy with a small, white head. Aroma of brett, baryard, green grapes, peach and lemons. Dry flavor with some sweetness too and it ends up bone dry and tart. Medium bodied, watery texture and flat CO2. A very nice Geuze

Bouteille 375 ml. Belle robe dorée surmontée dun collet blanc qui disparait assez vite. Au nez, un bouquet très rustique, où domine les notes de "barnyard" et de bretts. En bouche, on retrouve toute lacidité des gueuzes. Intéressantes notes de pomme verte. Très bonne bière, tout à fait sur le style.
Clear golden with a white head. Fresh and sour aroma. The taste was sour, but not overdone.
Shared a bottle with greenclansman and yiannos, pours a hazy golden yellow. Strong citrus aroma. Initial taste is a bit bland with the sourness coming at the end. Good beer.

Hazy, golden.
Sharp aromas.
Tart on taste, barn for sure, citrusy and a great sour finish.
Amazing beer!!!

Eccezionale Gueuze prodotta da Cantillon, una delle migliori (se non proprio la migliore) nel suo stile, già dallaroma si può capire con cosa si ha a che fare! come dice un vecchio detto popolare "una vera gueuze deve puzzare!", si presenta di color oro carico e con con poca schiuma poco persistente, nel palato ovviamente si sente lacidità che caratterizza i lambic, corpo nella media.

Bottle for science! Thanks Levi! Golden pour with a slight haze. Bright nose, a little farm and citrus. Beautiful taste, just slightly tart with lovely notes lingering. 2011 vintage. Why cant I drink this every day??

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2013 Tasted in the Cantillon Brewery in Brussels in 2002. A classic Gueze. One of those expereinces in life you dont forget. Pours a slightly cloudy golden color. Lovely balance in the sour notes.

Vaaleankullankeltainen ja lähes kirkas olut omaa pienen vaahdon. Hiilihappoisuus on hyvin havaittavissa kuplien määrästä. Haju on hyvin happaman tallimainen. Taustalta löytyy myös nahkaa, sitrushedelmää ja maamaisuutta. Hyvin suoraviivainen, mutta miellyttävä. Maku on jälleen hapan, tallimainen, hyvin sitruunainen/greippinen, mainen, nahkainen ja hieman marjainenkin. Suutuntuma on hyvin pirskahtelevan hiilihappoinen, mutta melko tasapainoinen. Yleensä lambiceissa on hiilihappoja melkeimpä liikaa, mutta nyt se on kurissa. Kokonaisuutena klassikko, joka ei petä. Aikanaan ensikosketus gueuzeihin, joten pientä nostalgiaa on ilmassa.

Bottle. Pours Cloudy, Clear, Orange, Pale, Small Head, Sparce Lacing. Aromas of Herbs, Lemon, Light Malt and of course a generous sour tart character. Light Medium body, fizzy carbonation and acidic sour character. Finish is sour, lingering for a good amount of time with a lightly sweet malt bread character.

S: Hay, wheat, lemons, and a bit of white pepper. P: golden with a thin white head. T: same as the smell with more lemons and oak, slight tartness not much sourness going on. M: medium body with full carbonation and finishes dry and clean O: good.

Bottle 375ml.
Pours sligthly hazy golden with low white head. Aroma is of funk, barnyard, yeast (bretts), fruits. Taste is of funk, barnyard, acid, sweetness, fruits. Palate: Ligth body (a bit oo ligth?). Overall: Very good Gueuze. Easily drinkable.
UPDATED: APR 12, 2014 375 ml bottle (at the strike of midnight, newyears 2012-2013). Aroma: very acidic, fruity and fizzy. Tastes of fruity acidity with long nice taste.
Hazy orange body with a minimal white head. Its useless to describe how it is, everybody on this site should know this beer. A must!
Hazy straw color. Nice white head. Aroma is classic Cantillon, funky, barnyard, lemon, appleskin, grapy, hay. Taste has a nice sourness, apple, lemon, barnyard, hay, funk. This beer is awesome!
Monks Cafe version on draft at Monks. Poured hazy light orange with minimal carbonation. Nose of sour, yeasty funk. Flavor much of the same with tart green apples. Refreshing.

Clear light yellow with small white foam head. Quite sparkling. Aroma is sour, so is taste. Fresh, sour ale, understand why they refer to this as a champagne . Aftertaste slowly turning bit sweet, no bitter taste. (Velp 201301 - 1st beer of the year)

Bottle. Pours hazy light orange to yellow with nice white head. Aroma is yeast, lambic basement, apples. Flavor is sour, malt, somewhat distinct wheat, yeast, lambic basement, apples. Nice dry and sour aftertaste.

Bottled in 2010. 375 ml. corked and capped bottle poured in to flute. Slightly hazy golden colour with a darker tint. Lots of bubbles. Thin, lasting white head. Sour and acidic aroma with citrus, apple juice, oak, vinegar, earthy notes. Some leaves, very complex, brett. Taste is  medium to heavy sour. Medium body, lively carbonated. Long lasting tart, fruity finish with barnyard, an acidic note. Excellent.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2013 A yellow golden amber in colour, sparkling in appearance. Smells like the farmyard funk, also of citrus / acidicity fruit. Tastes like perfect yeasty fruit funk and a wonderful tartness lingers for ages. thank you Cantillon!

23/08/13- 1998 33cl bottle, Cantillon gueuze 100% lambic from cellar of akkurat Stockholm
golden murky yellow amber med-lge head
Smells..soft rounded bret yeast scents, lightly fruit sour smell also soft and round.
Palette  -lightly acidic, dry finishing a little pucker
Taste -aged sourness lemons and apples, bret funk is so soft and round like a lambic cloud. oh my god.
Bottle from fear025. Golden pour with small tiny white head. Aroma is dirty socks and funky butt cheddar. Taste is super funky with a slight tartness.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2016 herbs, basement aromas, orange, cloudy, minimal head, white foam, lightly bitter, heavily sour, medium body, fizzy, long finish
375 ml bottle from Wein Kreis Stuttgart
From the bottle, cloudy yellow orange with nice aroma, which is funky, hay and green apple.  Taste is yeasty and acidic with some sour lemon.  Very tasty.

Refrigerated 75 cl corked and capped bottle obtained through trade with JStax poured into a tulip.  Pours slightly hazy golden with big white head which dies down.  Medium small bubble lacing, medium body, medium carbonation, and light tart aroma.  Taste is sour, yeast, and oak.  Not as sour as 3 Fontienen oude geuze, but more oaky.  Good beer, a big thanks to JStax for this one.

Interesting brew. Pours a hazy yellow into the glass with a small white head. Malts and yeast on the nose, with a sour scent. Very dry and sour mouth presence. Has some interesting notes to it, but might even be a bit too sour for my taste. Still a complex and respectable beer, but Id say you have to REALLY be into sours to love this one

Bottle. Pours hazy light orange to yellow with nice white head. Aroma is yeast, lambic basement, apples. Flavor is sour, malt, somewhat distinct wheat, yeast, lambic basement, apples. Nice dry and sour aftertaste.

Hazy orange-yellow.  Awesome lemon-lime sourness.  Pretty much a perfect lambic, other than the appearance.  Acidic, biting, lingering finish.  Fresh, delicate body.  Smooth and clean body, somewhere under the huge sour tones.  Classic.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2014 Bottle (375 ml) 2012. Clear golden with a small quickly diminishing white head. Aroma is quite funky, brettanomyces, leather, barnyard, green apples. Taste is sour and typical of gueuze. Brett, green apple and barnyard are also there. Mouthfeel is dry  and acidic. This one will compete with Girardin Black Label and 3F Oude Gueuze to be my go-to gueuze. Awesome balance while being quite complex and amazingly drinkable/refreshing! 

EDIT:  I tried the 02 and 13 side by side @ Cantillon Quintessence 2014. The appearance and the aroma were quite similar, though the 02 had a little more sourness. The main difference is in the taste, where the 02 was a lot more sour than the 13. It was still nicely balanced despite the sourness. It wasnt crazily sour either. The 13 was more lemony and hay forward. The 02 was a little dryer than the 13. I think I slightly preferred the 13 because the balance was a little better, but  my rating for both will stay the same as the rating above. The 02 was good, but not nearly as fresh/complex as some old 3F can be.

Bottle at BA Buffalo bottleshare. pours golden hue with silky white head. nose of barnyard, hay, and horse hair... classic brett. Taste is moderately puckering with shades of flower and cracky sweet ness. body is light but creamy. What a treat.

On tap at Zwanze day.  Havent had this in a while and man Im starting to love gueuze.  Really funky acetic musty aroma.  Taste is lightly oaky with some vanilla and dominant tartness that finishes very dry. GREAT
Bottle at Redlight Redlight. Nose is mainly lemon peel, vinegar, and funk. Taste is similar with tons of lemony citrus. Good.

Bottle from local Yamaya. Huge, raw barnyard nose -- or maybe abattoir. Blood and guts all sliced and steaming. Golden straw color. Just a bit hazy. Big tart sour lemon and rotten grain; mid extends the tartness and bring out sharp bitter notes; final does seem to fade out quickly. It really is intense enough in the initial and mid palate. Thin body. A bit one dimensional but thats not really a problem. Good stuff. So sharp and crisp.

the one the only loon geuze, had this many times, most recently @ the holy grale fro zwanze day. this straight funk and sour on the nose but not the kind that has sulpher. appearance is dark gold and clear with a ring of solid bubbles. taste is all classic geuze, sour, tart, hints of citrus and just so many complex levels. the palate was lively and full of carbonation, the body is light and drinks easy as it should. overall this is one of the finest gueuzes out there, its becoming a staple in the diet.

Bottle at Redlight. Clear deep golden pour with a bubbly white head. Aroma is basement funk, woody musk, lemon peels, and a note of vanilla. Flavor is tart dryness, sharp aged cheddar, lemons, white wine vinegar. Strong quick and sharp sour finish. Very solid.

Bottle, with chili while the wife was out. Pours a hazy golden color with big pillowy white head. Aroma is musty up front. Some citrus in there and some sour notes. Taste is more musty with medium sour notes, hay and white wine. Overall, great as always with this one but 3F is better.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Draught at tuulensuu, tampere. Clear golden color, small white head, co2 bubbles. Sour aroma, white wine, citrus. Nice sour taste, white wine, citrus, fruits, fresh, medium co2.

11 bottle -Pours golden w/light carbonation, decent amount of haze.  Pineapple, bandaids, lemon peel and oaky must on the nose - big typical lacto/pedio sour tinge, touch of vinegar, too.  Taste is very balanced, not mouth puckering, but really round.  Tart hints of apple cider vinegar, lemon and ripe pineapple.  Delicious...

Bottle at Biercraft Bistro, Vancouver. Pours a somewhat cloudy tan, slight but thick white head. Big nose, slight yeast, slight white fruit. Medium body, VERY effervescent. Finish is sour and sweet, with just the barest hints of hops and spice. Hype fulfilled; this was superb.

375ml bottle. Pours pale orange with thin ring of foam that dissipates very quickly. Aroma is a great hit of earthy, dusty barnyard notes, lemon juice, cider vinegar, leather, and wonderful acetic yeast funk. Taste follows suit: great balance of leathery barnyard notes, beautiful (although not overpowering) sourness, woody notes, lemon. Lovely fruity acidic sourness to finish. A wonderfully balanced gueuze.

Poured from a 750 mL bottle at the Cantillon factory in Brussles, on October 17, 2011.  Nose was very strong, sour apples and alcohol.  Very little head, mildly naturally carbonated.  Light, appealing cloudy gold in color.  Taste was very sour, no noticeable hop bitterness.  Alcohol VERY present, with a mild hint of sweetness teasing the tongue.  Complex and inviting, unlike most Guezes Ive tasted, which beat me over the head with sourness and never let me experience any other flavors.  As someone who generally dislikes sour beers, I found this to be outstanding, with enough subtlety to it to be much, much better than most sours Ive sampled.

Was a little nervous about this as I expected a lot but knew it could be a challenge. Not disappointed. The in laws, enjoying an extended stay, thought it was like cheap cider. The wife pulled a disgusted face and handed it back. So, my palate must be developing. Reckon Im ready for Diabolus now. Prefer a sour/wild but Ill definitely be back. Plotting a trip to Belgium. I cant take any more Come Dine With Me. Help me...
375 ml, bottle. Pours a hazy yellow with a small whitehead.  Sour green apples, grapefruit aroma. a little sweet with some sourness and a light bitter finish.  Not too bad.
(bottle, brought back from Belgium by friend) pale gold with white head. Tart, musty aroma. Flavor was sour and musty. Some yeast.

Tart aroma with some spicy, earthy, maybe "musty" character. A little fruity. 
Sour acidic flavor, sort of lemon-y. Sort of strong spiciness. Moderate but tasty bitterness. Some light grainy malt flavor in the background; it vanishes in the aftertaste, leaving an even more sour flavor.

Bottled 9/17/10; Drank 2/26/12
Bottle shared by Marcus. 2008 vintage. Aroma is classic sour.  Color is golden yellow with not much of what was a white head. Taste is puckering sour. Kind of get a grape taste too.

Aroma is brett and yeast. Appearance a yellow opaque golden colour with a fine white head that will fade away relatively quickly. Taste is yeasty, brett flavours, touches of malt and some nice malic acids, which influence the palate. Palate also has a nice mild bitterness accompanied by lingering tartness. Overall a very refreshing beer that echos the smells of the brewery herself.
Malt, strå, korn, grape, rødgylden , flot hvidt luftigt skum, let, tør, sur bitter, meget skøn og drikkelig til alt.
UPDATED: JUL 15, 2013 Dark-golden cloudy color with white foam. Acid aroma, citrus and spicy, apricot. At taste is sour with medium body and fizzy carbonation.

Pours a light amber with a white head. Certainly a very funky smell, some fruity notes, quite a bit of the sourness which I expected to smell. Taste is quite sour and salty, reminds me a lot of champagne, but a more sour, some white wine/white grapes coming through, quite a bit of acidity. The mouthfeel is medium, plenty of carbonation, theres a quite bitter, dry finish on the front of the mouth but with a sour after taste at the back. Complex, full of flavour, definitely something Id have again. Not bad for my first try.

Tap in Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Came a murky orange brown with a big white head. Tastes clean, obviously sour, some fruity sweetness, hint of wood. Very quenching, I find gueuze a splendid first beer of the evening.

Enjoyed from bottle in the basement of the Delirium Cafe in Brussels, Belgium during a dance party, which seems odd to me but was pretty damn fun.  Appearance is a pale gold with a thin white head.  Aroma is pure sour, with notes of stinky cheese and sour grapes.  Taste is like a sour wine, definitely has a light fruit flavor mixed in with the sour.  Overall it was pretty good but hope to have this in a different setting in the future.

Sample from 2009 bottle at Falling Rock Beer Tasting with Dr. Bill on 10/13/2012. This beer pours a clear pale amber color with a medium white head and a little sediment. Short strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of funky fruit, yeast and malt. Light-bodied with a slightly tart fruit character and flavors of apricot, yeast and pine. The finish is tart and fruity with a yeast and citrus aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

Jeg har stadig ikke helt fundet fidusen med de spontangærede øl. Den eddike/hvidvins agtig surhed er bare ikke mig (endnu).

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hand pump- pours honey gold. Smells like sour funk. Taste is tart winey, green tart apple, sour green grape, & kumquat w/ good light bitterness on the tail. Mouthfeel is white wine- like & finish is sour, dry, & slightly woody.

2011 corked and capped 750 ml bottle served in a Portsmouth tulip. Big thanks to Tnudish for the share.  100% lambic bio

A: Pours a hazy golden yellow color with a whispy film that hovers the whole way down leaving some splotchy lace.

S: Nice funky notes with a tart green apple and some white grape skins.

T: Tartness is up front with green grape skin, slight puckering sour and some nice funk on the finish.

M: Light and refreshing with some spritzy carb and a slightly sour finish.

O: This a delicious beer and my pour left the glass very quickly. This is a very balanced beer and I would love to have it again and again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-16-2012

Bottle provided by Baron whilst watching football. Thanks for bringing the Loons bro, I love drinking dis shit. 2011 vintage poured into a New Belgium tulip. Poured a golden brown in color with about a fingers worth of tight white head. Its hazy in clarity. Nose is comprised of lemon and a ton of dirty funk. Its surprisingly funky for this stage in its development. There is must, horse blanket, wet hay, and some cat piss. Flavor is less funk focused, there is still some sweetness accompanied by the lemon rind. There is some funk on the finish, but not a bunch. Mouthfeel is light, carbonation is low, gentle acidity, and a moderate finish. I love Classic Gueuze/Gueuze BIO/etc., so I always think its a treat to have. I prefer 3F Oude Gueuze in terms of standard gueuzes, but this is probably a close second. Thanks for bringing this Baron.

bottle  hazy light gold  vivid white head . complex aroma  - some yeast , grapefruit  , mustiness , lemon  . taste is sharp  , sour  , acidic  , grapefruit juice . wonderful tartness in the finish  . medium carbonation full mouthfeel  . exquisite   all should try at least once

Pours pale yellow with a white head that fades away fairly quickly. A very strong aroma, fruity and earthy notes fill the air right after the beer is poured. Taste is dry, sharp and very sour. Flavours of apples, berries and grapefruit, especially in the finish. Little carbonation, sticky texture and medium body, which is pretty much for a beer with 5 % of alcohol. More similarities with ciders in France and Basque Country, for example, than with most beers. A very distinct, special beer and a very distinct beer style - not my favourite but definitely interesting and one that everyone should taste at least once in their life.
Becisamente la più buona la numero 1 delle acide!
had several vintages and this one relly gets better with time! 1997 is the best one ive had so far!

Pale cloudy golden colour. Aroma funk, lemon, sharp grapefruit, musty. Taste lovely, have had this so many times and never rated it. Mix of tartness and rich creaminess, lemon, some sweetness too. Sourness causes a prickle in the mouth. Its just lovely. I miss Belgium.
Cask at @IndyManBeerCon pours straw yellow funky smell funky taste love geuze and this one is a great example.

Very good beer. Aroma burlap, dried apricots, dirt, dough, yeast alkali. Appearance is very golden almost slight amber, with thin bubbles, slight sediment, light. Taste is rusty barn door, burlap sack, acidic fruit, apricot, peach, pine bark, hints of old cheese. Palate is clean but soiled at the end, leaves a bit of acidic and bubbly mouthfeel with clean finish after 20 seconds or so. Overall pretty good, considering this type of fermentation is rare anymore. I like it, if you rate by style is awesome, but compared to fermented with controlled yeast strains its different with a champagne wine quality.

Tap. Pours clear light amber with a medium white head and decent lacing. Aroma is sweet tart, funk, wet feet, a bit of vinegar. Taste is lightly sweet and medium tart, quite funky - sweat socks, citrus, lemon rind. Lightish body.

2011 bottle pours a clear golden color with a small tan head. The aroma is sour apples, mild vinegar, some funk. Taste is citrus, slight vinegar, green apples, grapefruit, oak ending dry. Body is lightish and the carbonation is pretty mild. Overall, I have always enjoyed this beer and it is one of my go to beers.

Very classic example of a gueuze.  Pours cloudy dirty yellow with large head and lots of white lacing.  Smell is very earthy, close to wet feet but not disgusting.  Palate is bright, very tart and a refreshing finish.
UPDATED: SEP 20, 2014 Bottle. Orange pour with an off white head. Sour apple and grape elements. A bit of tartness in the middle. Slightly funky. Awesome.
Bottle. Golden oragen color. Thin to medium head. Low carbonation. High sourness and medium bitterness. Herb, fruit, light hop aroma.

On tap during the 43 Hours Of Sour at The Birch, Norfolk, VA.  Hazy straw colored pour with a bright white head.  Faint, clean lemony aroma.  Easy drinking, smooth yet tart lemon flavor.  For a gueuze this was well balanced.  A beautiful sour.

Pours somewhat murky yellow with lacy white head.  Smells of vinegar and citrus.  Tastes of sour and finishes bitter.  Orange and lemon flavors, rubbery bitterness in the finish.  Clean mouthfeel with a bit of dryness.

Classic sour flavour, aromas of grass and potent apple come to fore. Sour apple in the mouth with a robust vegetal quality. Well carbonated which cleanses the palate to a dry finish. One to take your time over, and punches above its weight for complexity.

750ml Bottle. Appearance is clear orange color with lots of fizzy, off-white head. Aroma is sour, barnyard, and fruit. Taste is similar with lots of lactic funk, balance with apple, and lemon fruitiness. Palate is medium-bodied, smooth texture, quite acidic, fizzy carbonation, and a dry finish.

Aroma has sour fruits and berries, bit funk. Clear golden, big white frothy head is long. Taste is sour and dry, lots of berries, green apple. Light body, soft feel, low carbonation, long sour finish. Lots of sour flavor. Quite demanding beer.

375 ml, bottled. Pours hazy yellow with a small whitish head. Aroma: Sour green apples, wood, grapefruits. Lactic acid. Taste: Mildly sweet, enjoyable discernible sourness. Some light bitterness in presence. Palate: Medium bodied, quite light. Soft, pleasant carbonation. Enjoyable gueuze.
My first gueueueueuze. Oh wow. What an adventure Im about to embark on. This was sour loveliness. Gimme more. Problem is too many pale lagers and crappy bitters on market. Gizagueuze

On tap at Håndverkerstuene. Slightly hazy orange with a small, bubbely, white head. Aroma of barnyard, horseblanket, wood, citrus and fruits with hints of malt. Lightly sweet with a sour and citric taste that takes over. Quite well balanced. Finishes quite dry and sour with sour aftertaste with some citrus. Pleasant and refreshing!

2011 bottle poured golden hazy with small white head. Aroma of apple and some funky. Taste granny smith apple. Tart and dry mouthfeel. Lingering sourness. Very tasty beer happy I was finally able to get some. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice and golden with above average carbonation. Head doesnt stay long with not much lacing. Restrained and classy funk in the aroma with good cellar notes. Taste is citrus with some grass. Might very well be the description of "refreshing". Look it up.

A-- Poured a golden straw color. Quite hazy looking. One finger bright white head that fell to a white layer of film. Slightly thicker film on swirling. Couple strands of lacing here and there. 

S-- Big, bright, crisp and acidic green apple. Followed by straw, vinegar and pear. The acid levels in the nose are quite nice but the crispness in the apple is just sublime. 

T-- More like lemonade in the taste. Slightly thin and under sugared lemonade with some lime and lemon grass. Loses the apple, straw and vinegar from the nose. 

M-- Bright and crisp with lively carbonation and feel. More like the smell. Lots of tart apple, lemon and other citrus. High amounts of acid with vinegar soaked straw in the mid and back palate. Long lasting tart lemon grass finish. Nice amount of funk with the acid in the finish. 

O-- Have had a few of the 09 cork dated bottles and have wanted to have this fresh so can compare. Prefer older vintages as just more complex and rounded. That being said a fresh 750 is easy to drink where an older one is just difficult with the acid and funk that develops. Great gueze but was just lacking in the taste for me. Hit the rest of the notes well. older vintages do have more in the taste though.
Pours cloudy and golden, short lived white head. Aroma is funky and fruity with apricot hints. Taste is nice and tart, funky, peach skin, sour linger, dry finish, only my second gueze, pretty good.
Bottle at bar. Golden color, white head. Sweet, sour taste with grapefruit, apple,  overripe fruits and earthy aromas. Sour finish. Very nice gueuze.

Dorato opalescente con schiuma bianca poco persistente......Naso da lambic..agrumato, acetico, molto intenso.
entra morbida, abboccata e, naturalmente, molto acida.....
gran bella birra....
Bretty without being lemony. Just a fantastic beer. Id love to see how they mix the old and new lambic to make these things.An IIPA of sourness.

Bottle at home - 19/08/12.
Pours an apricot shade of orange with a billowing slightly off-white head which soon vanishes to a little edgeing.
Earthy sour green fruits, grandads shed, burnt sugar and accidental piss against the radiator in a mark I toilet!
Tarte and sour fruit taste, apple and burnt caramel.
Medium body and a nice soft level of carbonation.
Dry crisp finish with a sour and apple infused aftertaste.
Tops!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: August 16, 2012 "Classic" bottle from Blue Max.  Semi-opaque golden orange pour with some head that faded quickly.  Swirl it a bit and it foams up quickly.  Aroma was lemon/citrus and a down home earthy funk.  Taste was consistent with aroma.  Very well balanced, medium bodied and smooth to drink.
Pours raspberry red with a slight white head, very nice lacing. Smell and taste of sour berries which ends with a smooth yet tart Finish
Ah, handpumped in the Moeder Lambic. A delight after a session on Frnch beer, and worth the trip on its own. What a hit to the palate, and so refreshing.

On tap @ Cardinal, Stavanger. First impression, its lighter in carbonation than the bottled version. Hazy golden with a small white head. Typical aromas of a sour ale, wonderful fruity and malty. Crisp and fresh acidic. 
Pairing this with food, maybe seafood,  would be great!
Oh so good.  Tart and acidic like no other beer.  I avoid the cherry type stuff but this is good.  Beautiful yeast and overall hue.  Do not drink too cold.

Bottle from Bon Vivant, Edinburgh
Golden orange amber, hazy, dense white pillowy head that dissipated to thin layer, some lacing
Aroma - Fairly sour, funky musty, bit of straw, light sour fruits, leaves, hay floor, slight hint of manure, overall the aroma is surprisingly quite light but unusual
Taste - Dry clear acidic fruity must, bit of grape, hint of straw, bit of old sour grapefruit, stale citrus, lemon, hard to describe, so odd and complex, tastes slightly different with each mouthful, bit of bitter quinine, odd esters, but its really refreshing
Palate - very very sour initially but the palate quickly adjusts, clean refreshing, dry, big acid sour kick but settles very quickly. GOod wake-up for the palate. Medium carb. medium body, bitter sour in the middle. Finish - bitter sour, slightly metallic, old bitter zest
Overall - This is crazy stuff - but I like it

Bottle. Golden, hazy, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate, dry and very sour aroma  vinegar, light fruitiness and light green apples. Moderate, dry and sour - vinegar flavor, fruitiness  vinegar, light green apples. Finish is average, dry and sour/vinegar, fruity. Aroma and flavor are perfectly in balance. Nice bone dry gueuze, although bit one-dimensional.
2011 bio bottle. Golden/orange with small white head that fizzles away. Aroma of lemons, lemon peel, light funk, basement, some herbs. Taste is tart and bitter lemon pulp, some apricot, funk.
UPDATED: JAN 16, 2013 Hazy golden colour. Sour funky aroma. Taste is dry, tart and sour. Nice gueuze
Geuze ottima, alta qualità. Gradevolissima, puoi percepire benissimo il sapore acquisito dallinvecchiatura in botte, veramente ottima. Acido equilibrato soddisfacente.

Pours a pale yellow with a thin white head.  Aroma has tart and funky farmhouse notes...faint cheese and mild leather.  Flavor follows suit...lightly lemony with great restrained funk and leather.  Mouthfeel is light with a dry tart/funky finish.  A bit beyond my descriptive skills but a stellar beer!

By recommendation of verticalbaconstrips. I'm glad I finally tried this as its a sour-lovers spunk-encrusted 2-finger moustache of awesome. Excellent cloudy gold. White bubbly cap that dissipates quick. So much young apple tartness and wet attic aroma. Sweet Velcro hightops, this is dry. Tons of wild yeast and TART. I love this.

375ml bottle, dont remember the date but pretty fresh.
Apricot colored, big foamy head.  The aroma fills the room, sour lemon and vinegar.  Tastes of lemon, wheat, funk.  Crisp clean finish, good consistency.  Fine beer, but nothing interesting.

Doesnt get much better than thls! Poured cold, straight out of the fridge with a nice foamy, thick, off-white head that slowly settles and a little lace. Color is a clear amber with some tiny bubble trails. Aroma is yeast, tart, citrus, spice, perfume. Flavors like nose, tart from yeast and carbonation perfectly married up front, hint of sweet, and grapes in back; very clean. Body and carbonation are perfect. Finish is like flavor, long, refreshing and satisfying. Truly a masterpiece.

Many, many thanks to match1112 for sending this beer my way.

Poured from 12.7oz bottle to stange, bottled 17 September 2010:

Pours a lively apple cider, hazy gold with a quick few fingers of fizzy, loose head. Great lacing.

The nose is stuffed with earthy, funky yeast. White grape, pear, overripe light fruit, subtle sour character, increasingly tart.

Ooo... super smooth. It doesnt have any of the aggressive carbonation that it appears to in the glass. Instead, the feel is pretty mellow, with the perfect amount of fizz to support the tart pop on the tongue. Tart apple skin, grassy bits, drying yeast in the finish.

What a terrific beer.

A longtime want of mine that surely didnt disappoint!

5th July 2012Keg at the Craft. Hazy gold - amber beer, little white head. Light crisp palate, semi dry. Nice level of sourness, not too much. A little grapefruit and orange. Mild brett. Fairly sour finish, a little acid kicking in. Nice Gueuze - quite approachable.
Hazy orange, small but decent white head. Aroma is sour, moderately dusty. Taste like aroma. Nice gueuze, not the best.
questa classica di cantillon resta una delle migliori gueuze in circolazione, con un gusto e un aroma inconfondibile.

The beer is clear, sunset orange with a medium sized head and spotty lacing. The aroma offers barnyard funk, straw, tart lemons, citrus. Beautiful and simple. Classic Cantillon nose and flavor. A graceful acetic presence with a subtle burn in the finish. Very smooth with moderately low carbonation. Very enjoyable. As the label states, a classic.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2015 Limpido color oro con schiuma bianca sottile e poco persistente. Al naso è acida e pungente con sentori di agrumi e di lievito e un lieve tocco speziato; gusto brusco e acetico dove fa capolino anche il luppolo. Secca come un vino brut e con un finale amarognolo e conciso; dissetante e di corpo leggero. Un classico dello stile!

This Belgian traditional lambic has a fruitful nose with hints of spices and a hint of cinamin. It appears light orange with little C02 and minimal head. The flavor in contrast would be stricking on the tongue with a lingering sour palate. This is not your traditional beer!

375 ml bottle bottled on 9 march 2011.  Pours a slightly hazy light amber with a small white head that has good retention and leaves some light lacing on the glass.  The aroma is really funky with lots of brett, some horseradish, a light sulfur note, and some earthiness.  The taste has a big lactic tartness with lemon, slight horseradish, and lots of funky brett. The finish is tart with earthy brett.  Medium body. Low carbonation. Dry throughout.  This was drank side by side with a 3F Oude Geuze.  I slightly preferred the 3F, but this was still great.  I suspect that the slight sulfur note will go away with some age and this beer will get even better.

Ogni volta che la si beve sicuramente non si fa dimenticare tanto facilmente. Aroma classico del genere, spinto tra lacetico e il sudore di un qualche animale indefinito. Al palato è tanto acida che risucchi le labbra fin dentro lo stomaco. Comunque è caratterizzata da una media carbonazione, con tocchi di legno, aceto e un tocco di frutta acerba. Berla è un esperienza che non si dimentica.

375mL courtesy of PDX chasing. Consumed 6-8, reviewed from notes.

A: Orangish-yellow with a receding head. Glides off the glass. 

N: Balanced sourness. Orange, lemon, oak. Some subtleties of the yeast funk, but theyre fringe elements. 

T: Incredibly well balanced, and very oak forward. Lemon, pepper, and earth. Salty, in a way. Slight candy sweetness to back up the rest of the flavors. 

M: Prickly and perfect. Not nearly as drying as its American counterpart. 

O: Tried two days after having Beatification, and the two are comparable in quality. I prefer this one, both because its a classic and because its more rounded where the Beatification is sharp.

Bottle shared at local tasting a little while back, pours a deep golden with a nice white head and some lacing, the aroma has a decent amount of barnyard funk mixed in with some sour apples, the flavor has a good amount of funk on the front end with a nice tart finish, always a pleasure drinking a Cantillon.

Pours golden, the color of a nice cider, sligh thead slight lacing. Smell also has a bit of dry cider aroma to it, barnyard, sour apple, lactic, goatscheese, and a whiff of light airy perfume in the backround. Taste begins mellow the sourness creeps in and assaults your tongue. Lots going on with sour fruit funky barnyard flavors and a dry ciderish and bretty finish that just left me wanting another sip. SO Drinkable! The palate was not what I was expecting, very mild carbonation, so smooth and velvety. Medium bodied almost. I have had this before and the carbonation was MUCH more lively and the feel lighter. Not sure what was up but I loved it as it came closer to the Flat Lambics tht you get in Belgium, and which I LOVE! Overall just a fantastic Beer, maybe my favorite of the style but its tough as I never have them side by side.
birra+, wild wild fest: secca, secca da morire, acida che brucia in gola, questa è una vera gueuze!

Bottle, pours hazy yellow with big white head. Notes of vinegar, green apples, champage, funk and lemon. Tart, dry.
Nice!

Bottle at home poured into my new Duvel graffiti tulips. Has a golden orange appearance with a small white head, that quickly dissipated. Smell is brett funk, barnyard, champagne, earthy, and tart lemon peel. Taste is very well-balanced with a refined tartness. Flavors of lemon, citrus, brett, light cheese, and apple with a very dry finish. Mouthfeel is light with champagne-like carbonation. Very balanced and easy drinking, definitely a classic.

Hazy, dark straw colour. Thin head forming a ring around the glass. Fantastic classic "horse blanket" aroma, funky with sour green apples. Dry, tart, acidic on the pallet. Funky, musty, woody, slightly lemony and sour apples. Cracker Gueuze.

Bottle @ Craft. Deep golden color with a tiny white head. The nose is strong lemon peel, light dry wood, dried parmesean cheese and light yeasty funkiness, a bit musty. The taste is cobweb-covered moldy white grape, more lemon peel and dried cork. Light lemon custard and dust. Sweet and lively on the tongue, very easy to drink. Soft. Very good work.

Bottle pour @ Café Amsterdam. Hazy golden orange with a small white head. Aroma of green apple, funky wet wood and citrus. Flavor is very tart upfront with a light malty sweetness and finishes long and sour. Light body with active carbonation and a dryish mouth feel. This is a great beer, lots of sourness but balanced out with a light malt sweetness. Would like to have some bottles to age.
It smells a bit like white wine, sweet, fruity, intensiv. The taste is sour-citrus good balanced and a bit hoppy. A refreshing and nice to drink Gueuze! 11/12/11/11/-/12

Aroma crisp with sour fruits and a touch of funkiness.

Slightly cloudy, golden with a head that recedes rapidly.

Taste follows the aroma with gentle tartness with may be a note of apple or pear.

2010 vintage. Bottle to oversized snifter. Looks good; orange with nice head and lacing. Smells good too; tart and funky. Tastes great; borderline 9, but not quite. Good on the palate too. This is tha funk!!!

Poured into my bruery tulip. Pours golden with a foamy 1 finger head that stays. Aroma of vinegar, lemon and a little funk In the back. Taste is tart, cidery, lil funky and delicious. Mouthfeel is smooth with medium carbonation. Very drinkable! Overall this is amazing, great sour flavor with high drinkability.

10 cl sample @ Gastropub Tuulensuu Gueuze blind tasting. BBE 07.06.2031.
Originally rated on 20100925. (8+4+8+4+16)
Pours clear orange color with no head. Aroma of grapes, mild sour apples, yeast and grass. Flavor of grapes, fruits, herbal notes and some yeast.
Placed #6 of 15.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2012 Tasted @ Gastropub Tuulensuu geuze blind tasting 2012. #7/15 overall rating2011 vintage - 
Pours clear golden with a tiny head. Slightly malty aroma with earthy notes and some tart fruits. Taste is slightly malty with earthy notes, sour fruits and hars tart currants. Finish is smooth with notes of tart fruitness and spices.

It should be noted this review relates to Cantillon Cuvée De Florian. 75cl bottle shared at Akkurat. Poured in a stemmed glass. Vintage: 1996; according to the bartender, this beer is the regular Cantillon Classic gueuze produced with an extra bit of love (i.e. the best lambic at the time) as it was named in honor of Jean Van Roys first born son, Florian. Sweet golden yellow. Half (bubbly white) fingernail head on gentle pour. Smells mostly of oak and aged cheese. Notes of classic Cantillon gueuze - barnyard funk, must, and lemon have held up amazing over time. This beer smells heavenly! Taste follows smell precisely. Nice balance of oak, cheese, straw, and funk with perfectly timed citrus note near the end. This beer is so easy drink, well-rounded, crisp and smooth. Not a single flaw in the taste. Absolutely beautiful! Light bodied with appropriate carbonation. Not too sharp or rounded; just right. This is exactly why I think Cantillon can withstand the test of time and develop beautifully with age. This beer is so balanced, crisp, and amazing. Perfect is the only word that comes to mind when drinking this beer. For me, this is the essence of gueuze perfection. (Long) Stand ovation here!

Really delicious! Soapy head and hazy amberish beer. The aroma is standard geuze. Cirtus among others. It somehow tickles in the eyes. Gently burning in the back of the mouth. Well balanced despite being quite sour. If i should recommend a Geuze for someone who didnt knew what it was, this might be it. Lovely.

Shared 12.7oz with drinking buddy.  Pours a slightly hazy golden hue.  Rich aromas of tart, sour funk, with a bit of wet dog basement mildew....flavors match the nose.  Crisp, tart and complex with hints of sour fruit; apricot, granny smith apples, and a hint of vinegar.  More please....

A mild but sour and totally drinkable Gueuze. Delish. Dare I say a "session gueuze"? Not quite as funky as others but quite enjoyable.

Enjoyed from the bottle at Monk's (Thanks Eddy!)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aug 2008: I like beer, this isnt a beer I like! Since I wrote this (on BA) Ive re-visited the brewery and I still struggle with Cantillon beers.

Ive been to the Brewery, done the tour, drank the stuff while there and I just cant bring myself to enjoy any of the products Ive had. This green 75cl cork and crowned bottle is no different. I can see why this style of beer is dying a death.

I travel to Belgium about 4 times a year for little beer breaks and Ive really tried to embrace the Gueuze/Lambic way, but Ive failed.

Opened during a Belgian Beer Night with friends, this didnt go down at all well.

Light orange, slightly cloudy, hazy it looked like a nasty cider.

The aroma was of rotting old lemons, vinegar and sour cooking apples.

The taste is sour, sour anything and everything really. Just sour.

The closest liquid Ive had that tastes and feels like this, is pickling malt vinegar.

Bottle, 375 ml, bottled 7 june 2011. Pours a very hazy beautiful golden with a small frothy white head, that disappears quickly. Citric, lemony aroma, tart, crisp and funky. Taste is vinegar, citrus-fruit, a little abricot. Very dry and crisp finish. Very refreshing, yet complex. Pairs excellent with food.
Bottle (at the brewery) - Hazy amber in colour. Grain, must and lemon in the aroma, some damp wood too. Tart taste with notes of lemon, malt and dried fruit.

375ml bottle.  Pours clear golden with a light head initially which fades to nothing at all.  No lacing.  This one has a clean medium sour taste with a dry finish.  Has a light body with soft carbonation.  Extremely refreshing.  This is my first true Belgian Geuze-Lambic  and what an experience this was!  Extremely satisfied I am...!  Cant wait to try 3 Fonteinens Oude Gueuze though.

Pour hazy light orange, with a large white and bubbly head. 
Aroma of  barnyard, flowers, green apples, vinegar, lemon zest, unripe fruits and sour candy.
Taste is sour, with a nice balanced sweetness to it. Really freshens out the mouth at every sip. 
Medium bodied, with a nice amount of fizzy carb. 
This style really grows on me.

2009 Bottle from the basement. Case I split with Greg Yoder. Nose is funk, hay, slight cheese, slight acetone, lime, vinegar & fresh cut grass. first sip has a nice mouth feel  with intense sour flavors. fi ish  is lime, acetice acid and slightly malt flavor. awesome beer!
330ml bottle from Bierzwerg. First lambic so far, not the last, but not my style at all. Hazy golden colour with no head. Aroma is citrus, acid. Flavour is acid, sour, citrus. Too sour to my taste.
Bottle. Hazy light copper color with a thin white head. Sour aroma with some citrus. Dry and sour taste. Overall very good and interesting beer.

Thanks to a friend who sent this to me unexpectedly in a trade! Stoked to try it. Poured into an Ommegang Glass at Cellar temperature. Bottle Date: March 9th, 2011. Just over one year old.

A - Tangerine orange appearance. The golden orange looks like a jolly rancher like sweet candy. Looks excellent. 2-Finger cream colored head that dissipated to a find line around the edges of the glass. Im out by the river so the bugs are flocking to this beer. Very nice head lacing.

S - The young Gueuze dominates the scent. Very strong, funky and bitter all in one. Floral honey scent and mango.

T - Wow. Amazing sour apricot taste on the tip of my tongue. Bananas and cranberries cover my tongue to the back of my throat. The mouth puckering sourness of a lime at the finish.

M - 20% carbonation. Heavy body with so much complexity. Very dry finish. Slick mouthfeel while in my mouth. More like a syrup than a beer. Very nicely balanced 

O - This beer is excellent. it doesnt compare to the 3F Gueuze or Gueuze blends Ive had. The funk is nice but, mid-way through the bottle and it starts to become too much.
375 ml bottle. Pours a light gold with full head. Wood and sour mash to the nose. Green apples and citrus. Sour and tart. Great beer to finish the night.
Bottle sample at the 3rd Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks Lee. Bottled 2011. Almost flat, blond and cloudy, Dairy aroma - brie cheese, some apple. Sour, hot and sour taste. Dry, flat finish, light body.

375ml bottle from late 2011. Rating #1124. Clear dark gold pour with a small white head. Interesting aroma, light grain, apple and a little funk. Tart flavor, sour apple and smartees, nice stuff. (2298)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 375ml bottle (bottled 17 Oct 2008), drunk at home, 8th May 2011. Hazy orange with a line of white head. Musty nose with an underlying tart note. At this age, soft gentle sourness with a dry, lingering aftertaste - woody and leathery notes come through strongly.

Pours clear golden, small bright white head and solid lacing. Cedar, vinegar, fermented white grapes on the nose. Acidic, vinegar bitterness, cooked vegetables, super long sour, dry finish. Bubbly champagne like body. Not my favorite but original no doubt

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2012 Bottle. Monks cafe version. A shimmering hazy golden color with tiny head/lacing. Aromas of tanin lactic funk, spicy yeast, raisins, and lemon. Taste is peachy, butterscotch, wood, puckery lemon, clove spice. Balanced and refreshing for a sour. Re-rate 1994 and 1996 bottles from Frank, Further notes of oak, peach, sour horseblankets, vanilla, caramel, man old cantillon gets so freakin sour. Maybe the most sour beer I have ever had. Amazing.
Crazy horse blanket.  Sour, salty, no head.  Hazy yellow appearance.  Smells a bit rotten.  Amazing.
