One a scale of one to sour this beer is sour! Its tart even for a lambic. Crisp and sharp with a prominent barnyard character and sour fruit.

reviewed 04-19-2010. vintage 2009 served in a tulip. pours a hazy straw with subtle hints of orange. light fizzy white head with nice retention. sour and vinegar up front. light lemon zest and light sour grapes. up front, nice light sweetness that lingers through out, even through the finish. lots fruit favors through out, mainly grape and green apple. nice light sourness without any strong vinegar flavor. quite balance. light and dry with a nice moderate carbonation. sweetness coats the mouth. insanely easy drinking. this is young and im sure it will become more dry over time and the sweetness may even take a back seat. i cannot wait to see what some time does to this.

16-03-12 Bouteille 375ml fraîche: Couleur jaune-dorée, avec une effervescence normale et mousse abondante au début, mais éphémère ne laissant pratiquement aucun collet. Légers arômes de vinaigre, dherbes, de miel, avec une touche de citrus. Fortement sûre, avec une totue petite note sucrée et une bonne amertume. Corps moyen avec une texture mince et croustillante. Forte carbonisation et finale astringente et sure.  Comme conclusion, bonne gueuze classique, bien équilibrée pour le genre et se boit facilement et avec plaisir.

From notes.  First reviewed 9/28/2011.  Poured from a 350 mL bottle into a tulip. Thanks to bauermj for bringing this over.

The pour is a slightly hazy soft golden color with a small white cap.

The smell has a perfect balance of tart and funk. A fair funky aroma, full of barnyard, some must, horse blanket, lemon zest, and some leather. This is just an awesome aroma.

A soft start to the flavor has some light grains, then some strong tartness for the rest of the sip. Lemon zest and general citric tartness. The finish has some funk and stinky cheese to go along with a bit of woody oak. 

This is a light to medium body, with fairly delicate carbonation. Tart, lightly acidic, with a strong funk toward the end. Some tannic oak astringency toward the end. Fairly dry. The finish was lightly watery as well. 

This is a very nice gueuze. Sour and funky in a nice balance.

Vintage 2009. Bottle shared with ClubGonzo. Beer looks straw-colored and slightly hazy, with a small white head. The aroma is quite sharp and acidic with berries. In addition I also sence wheat, citric acid, horse blanket and something floral. The flavour also contains a fairly crisp acidity, not far from bitter berries, but also a nice amount of fruit. This lambic appears acidic and fresh with a smooth mouth feel. A wonderful gueuze.
Wow. Big massive sour up front. Pours a golden colour with a light foamy head that sticks around. Backing is yeasty. Healthy carbonation in the mouth.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ cloudy golden with a white head. earthly aroma  nice and sour. crisp.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange with a small quickly diminishing white head. The aroma is sour fruit and tart. Thin mouthfeel with a sour fruit and crisp finish. Easy to drink a very good gueuze from Cantillon.

Bottle, thanks to Frank at Hacienda Beverage. Pours vibrant orange, slightly hazy. Thin white head. Aroma of apple, citrus, grapes, yeast and hay. Flavor is fruity and funky. Medium body, light carbonation. Finishes sour. Very sour. Very, very sour.
Great hazy golden geuze beer. In taste it reminds me of stables. Sour in taste with a hint of fruit. Great beer as aperitif!

750 ml bottle bought @ Bierkompass.de. Pours very hazy golden with a frothy off-white head that quickly dissipates while leaving almost no trace. Smell is sour with green apples, hay, horse blanket, lemon juice and gastric acid. Taste is tiny sweet and quite sour with apples, lemon juice, orange zest, leather, vinegar, hay and horse blanket. Mouthfeel is creamy and tart. Finish is dry and tart with lemon juice and orange peal.
Bottle shared by BenC. Fantastic as always such a great beer.

03/08/2011 La Tana (375ml bottle). Ambrata chiara, con riflessi color miele, lievemente torbida, leggero cappello di schiuma biancastra, frizzante e poco persistente. Al naso è acida, con note agrumate, di pino e resina. In bocca è estremamente acida, con note astringenti, limone, pompelmo, cedro, pino, resina. Corpo medio, carbonazione un po soft per una geuze. Acida senza compromessi, non certo la migliore geuze che io abbia mai assaggiato.

Bottle at Eleven Madison Park paired with my second course of snapper.  super funky nose and nice yellow pour.  tastes so sour of lemon citrus, green apples, balsamic vinegar.  again waiter left entire bottle for me to enjoy and i was happily surprised they brought me out some Cantillon

Appearance is golden-amber with a small white head. Aroma is acidic, funky, green apple, cumquat, apricot, grapefruit. Tart and dry on the palate, reminiscent of a dry champagne. Slight bitterness on the finish. Taste is vinegar, green apple, sour grapes. Very interesting but best in small quantities.

Pours yellow with a small white head.  Nose has grassy earthiness and sour grapes with some lemon.  Flavor is sour through out with some bitter and sweet mixed in a different parts of the taste.  Super complex.  Mouthfeel crisp, clean and has an aftertaste that hang on for a while.

Looks very appetizing in the glass, golden like sparkling apple juice.  Aroma of funky apples and yeast.  Tasty tart and tangy with a dry bubbly finish.  Overall, I really dig the tangyness on the tongue.  Its very refreshing.  Thanks Hopper for sharing.
UPDATED: JUN 22, 2012 Bottle @ Tap and Mallet: Pours a slightly cloudy gold. Tons of funk in the nose. Super funky on the palate. Wow. This blew me away. Wow.  Insane.

37 cl bottle [bottled in Dec 2010, 13 months old] during happy hour. My first full bottle of lambic ever [had tasted a bit of Girardins Black Label before but this is better]. Pours a clear, deep golden liquid with a thick but not persistent white head. Aroma of green apples, very delicate, almost no trace of the vinegary sourness that will follow. Taste is aggressively acidic, vinegary at first, then it gets more tame. A little fizziness, just the right amount to make it a lively, refreshing drink. Long, balsamic finish, some apples still present. A masterpiece, even though this is not a usual drink for me.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Appearance is a hazy dark gold with a thin white head that dissipated quickly and left little lacing. Aroma is tart like green apples. Taste is tart, drying, and fruity. This beer reminds me a great deal of Granny Smith Apples.
Bottle at RKT2011. Pale with thin white head. So sour. Funky aroma. A sweet chore of a beer.
Bottle fae Bens at the R Kelly Tasting. So much sourness all over shop. Completely radge.

From bottle. Pours yellow with thin white head. Funky aroma, like angst mans arm pit. Taste is funky as fuck, some lemons, citrus. Incredibly sour. Wild on the palate, an assault. Gueuze at at its best

Samean keltaista tavaraa kaatuu lasiini. Se muodostaa ylleen valkoisen vaahdon. Lasita tulvahtaa maanläheinen, hapan ja sitruksinen, mutta myös kummallinen ananasta muistuttava aromi. Tuo mieleen Hartwallin ananas Jaffan. Maku on hapan ja kirpeän sitruksinen. Melko hapokas ja mystisen tuoksuinen olut.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2012 2010 bottle.  Brilliant golden orange pour, medium white foamy head, decent retention/lacing.  Nose is pungent with white grapes, fruity,  riding a funky base; earthy, tart citrus finish.  Sharp sourness, but not overpowering, full of tart juicy green apples, citric acid, malts coming out in the funky bitter finish, mouth still tingling all the while with all that came before.  Not too thin in the mouth, minimal carbonation gives additional thickness, and relatively dry.  For me one of the standards with which to compare other gueuze.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2011 12.7-oz bottle from 4th Ave Pub. Pours cloudy, apple cider gold with no head and a vapor lacing. Smells of tart white grape and faint alcohol. Carbonation explosion on the tongue that leads into a champagne-like acidity that tingles all the way down. Very acidic, lively and effervescent, but lax on the puckeriness. Also, not a ton of fruit outside of the white grapes. Meets all but one or two of my sour criteria - not bad at all.

The prototypical gueuze, how can it not get a perfect score?  Well, its hard to get a hold of, other than that, its brilliant.  Pungent, yet refined.  Blond and cloudy.  Fruity and floral.  Tart and sophisticated.  Does have a cool cap.  If you can find it, buy it!

Flaska 100% Lambic Bio. Gulorange lätt grumlig dryck med vitt snabbt försvinnande skum. Doftar surt, lätt vinäger och lagrad ost. Torr munkänsla och en surthet som drar lätt i kinderna. En surhet i smaken och inslag som påminner om grapefrukt. Uppfriskande.

Rating #400! Pours a translucent apricot color. Aroma consists of complex layers of deep sour, yeast, and acid. Taste is a rapid influx of flavor that mellows out in to a smooth finish. Flavor is a mellow sour with various layerings of yeast, acid, citrus, and very slight bitter-sour. Very fluid - neither thick nor watery. Finish is sour and acidic - shifts from wet to dry. Quite excellent. I absolutely loved this gueuze and will fondly remember it.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2012 Bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours a golden colour with a thick white head. Aroma of horse-blanket, lemon and barley. Lemon tartness. Some dry balsamic vinegar also with barley again. Lingering tartness. Quite mouth-puckering. A little bitter with a long tart linger and a long warm afterglow. Also had this on draught at Cantillon and De Cam Volkscafe. Pours a light golden colour with a fair white head. Aroma of lemon, lime popsicles, horse blanket and wet cardboard. Similar flavours and quite tart with a dry finish. Moderate carbonation, light CO2 prickle and a foamy mouth-feel. Lovely (7,3,7,4,17).

(bottle - capped and corked 750 ml - 2008 vintage) Cloudy orange pour with a thin layer of foam. Big and deep funky and tart aroma with a particularly heavy wet and runny cheese aroma. Flavor is tart and sour, enough to make you take a step back. Very dry as well, but has a ton of tart and sour notes. Smooth and really rich with a lingering sourness. Fantastic.

Bottle courtesy of a trade with Rasmus40.  I popped the cap off and the cork started rising from the bottle almost immediately.  I was able to pull the cork out with my hand and feared a gusher, but thankfully that did not happen.  Pours a cloudy gold with a large linen white head.  The aroma is very nice with sharp acidity in the nose along with a bit of funk.  The flavor is equally sharp and acidic with a bit of sour lemon.  A touch of funk present here as well.  Bright on the palate; really awakens the taste buds.  Wonderful!
UPDATED: DEC 22, 2012 221212. Bottle at home. Pours hazy golden with a minimal head. Aroma sour grapes. Gueuze like dry acidic taste. Full bodied. Not Bad.

375ml bottle, bottled 3 December 2010.  Pours a cloudy, light amber color with a white head.  Aroma is earthy, funky, wood, citrus, lemon.  Medium on the palate with soft carbonation.  Flavor is sour, tart, citrus, with a cry, tart finish.  Excellent.
This one had been lurking in the back of the fridge since a trip to Belgium in 2003. Nice earthy aroma, funky flavor and tart finish.

75 cl bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu. Rated on 25.09.2010
Tasted in blind tasting with 13 other gueuzes, this one won.
Disappearing head and murky orange colour. Aroma is slightly sour with vanilla and some farmhouse. Flavour is very nice with sourness. Just right amount of CO2 on palate. Balanced and lovely.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2012 murky, milky yellow, light orange, big frothy quickly disseapearing head, 
aroma: oak, citrus, funk, farty, manure, stable, dusty, lactoacid, sourness, gooseberries,  vinegar. medium, very fizzy mouthfeel.
 Taste: tart, some bitterness, very refreshing, acidic, green apples, citrus, lemon, applecider vinegar, fruity bitterness, brett, woody, fruity sweetness, dry lingering aftertaste.
"100% Lambic Bio" bottle. Golden colour, white head. Great acidic aroma with green apple and grapes. Balanced refreshing sour taste with lemon and grapes. A very good one.
UPDATED: SEP 7, 2012 29.10.2011- @home with my dad - bought at Bioplanet, Gent - 37,5 cL bottle  typical geuze aroma/taste  pretty sour in the mouth  how I love this one.

Bottle of Cantillon Classic Gueuze. Pulled cork out, nice pop. Let it warm up a bit before consuming. The beers aroma is mildly sour, slight notes of funk. Flavor is tart, a bit like sour cherries. Pretty carbonated, like a champagne. I guess well made, but certainly not extraordinary.

Bottle 2010... at Kulminator.....it pours cloudy yellow with small head....  the aroma is dust, citrus, grape....the flavor is sour, dry grape, citrus, and dusty, with a long acidic after taste..... very nice....
Licht geel bier, bijna geen schuimkraag. Bloemerig aroma, best zuur. Heel zure smaak, veel te zuur voor me. Best wel droog ook.

Draft at Monks Cafe.

Pours a cloudy, dark golden orange color with tangerine hues and a one finger frothy white head that slowly fades into a thin ring.  Sporadic spots of lace left behind. 

Funky, earthy aroma with some musty, earthy bugs.  Lots of earthy oak, musty barnyard horsey funk and acetic vinegary sweetness along with a strong citrus fruit presence.  Amazing nose.  

Medium bodied with a tart puckering mouthfeel and dry, tart sourness that lingers throughout into a slightly acetic, sweet vinegary finish.  Not harsh or overly acidic with a ton of sweet citrus, especially lemon, and a lingering vinegar flavor that has me salivating for more.  Extremely complex and quaffable.  Highly recommended!
Rather sour yet smooth. Decent carbonation with tiny bubbles. Typical gueuze aroma.

Bottle at steingarten la - shared with bman 1113vr- light brown hue mostly clear with a small white head
Aroma is of citrus and flavor is acidic and sour.....
Kind of flat carbonation with medium mouthfeel.....

Oddbottle has crown and cork, and when I removed the crown there was fluid on top of the cork. Ive had this beer stored in the upright position for about a year now what is up with this??? Kind of scared Ill have a bad bottle but when youre talking Gueuze is there ever a good one? Corked did open with a bang a brew appears to be properly carbonated, the mystery continuous. Beer looks like apple juice with a nice white skiff floating on top. Intense sour aroma, vinegar, rubberthis style is always lost on me but Im liking it more now than when I first had them.  Taste is better than I thought it would be. Sour white grape, darkness, old apples.  Dark aftertaste with a lingering better. Something I want to call tart lemon but I know thats wrong maybe more of a grape fruit but I also know thats wrong.  What the hell I just smelt rotten egg briefly and I cant get it back. So very dry, Ill need to chug some water when Im done here to avoid getting pasties.  I can actually drink this with some enjoyment and thats pretty high praise from considering Im not a fan of this style.

Clear golden body with quite dissoving white head, like a sparkling wine. Also quite some vineous notes in the arom, with vinigar, clove and some herbs and lemon. Acidic, yes, but within (my) bounds and it really adds to the complexity. Very refreshing too, but I wont drink many in one session. Little carbonation makes the body smooth. If youre in for something sour and challenging, this is great. Reasonably priced. (37,5cl bottle)

750ml bottle, bottled September 23, 2009. Leaked through the cork a bit but the cap kept everything contained. Nice vibrant rose with a quickly fading pink hued head - leaves nothing but tiny bubbles around the outside of the glass. A nice combination of funk and tart with the former taking the lead, sour cherries, some grass. Extremely acidic and vinegary, good carbonation, medium body but light, some cherry, dry, nice tart and sour that just keeps on going on the finish. A little too acidic for me but still good - if you like tart and vinegar this is one for you - and with some time to breath it becomes slightly more balanced (only slightly).
UPDATED: OCT 9, 2011 Bottle from 02-2011 Not as sour acidic as I am used to from Cantillon, a much more moderate bottle as the ones before. Will compare some more and re-rate.
Bottle shared with northropfrye. A nice bright aroma, but the taste is just nasty. Way too sour for me. Yuck.
Bottle. Nice fresh fruit aroma, sour plastic, but in a good way. Hazy orange colour, very little carbonation. Taste is sour and then very bitter. Definitely an acquired taste. I like it.

750 ml capped and corked bottle.  The cork says this was bottled in 2010, the bottling date on the bottle is smudged but it looks like it says 17 March 2010.  Served in a flute, the beer pours a hazy gold color with a half inch off-white head.  Head retention is decent, not much lacing.  Aroma is very nice, its tart and musty.  The brew smells like funk, tart apples, lemon peel, and some hay.  For the most part the taste is just like the aroma, but theres also some white grape and oak flavors noticable, too.  Mouthfeel/body is medium with moderate carbonation.  Its also dry and very easy to drink.  I think this is a pretty good beer and would buy it again the next time I come across it.  At $13.99 a bottle, its definitely worth the money.

(75 cl, 2010)  Quick notes : Clear golden.  Rocky head.  Sour and acidic aromas.  Fruits.  Light funk.  Cantillon signature.  Sour/acidic taste.  Very sharp.  Fruits flavors as well.  Lemons and apples.  Belgian goodness.  Medium body with good carbonation.  Bone-dry finish.  Classic.
From the tap. Murky amber. Smells sour and fruity with a taste to match. Finishes tart and sour. Recommended.

Bottle, sample at GBF 2011 cons 2011-09-02
Yet again a bottle that can be saved at home for some time more...
AR: dry, fruity, womit
AP: hazy amber, wee white head
F: dry, tart, white grapes, a bit smokey???

Bouteille de 750ml avec capsule de métal protégeant le bouchon de liège. La bière est dorée la mousse est impressionnant et bien durable même que de fines dentelles apparaissent sur le pourtour du verre. Elle offre des arômes fruités de pêche ou dautres fruits du genre (abricot, nectarine), un peu de vin blanc. En bouche lacidité est marqué, Les brettanomices sont bien présent en fin bouche avec un incroyable velouté presque sucrée.

A very well balanced gueuze.
A: Apricots, hay, slight sweet grain
T: stone fruits-Apricot/Peach, tart, sweet pils malt
I have never seen head last on a gueuze. I am ready for another.

375 ml bottle from EZ Liquors. Poured a great looking golden body underneath ana verage sized dense frothy bright white head with some tiny rising bubbles from the center of my DFH chalice/snifter thing. Aroma is sour, lemons, band aid, mango, vinegar. Flavor is basically identical to the aroma. The body has a hard hit of acidity on the back of your throat to let you know your drinking a true sour lambic. This is some solid shit.

Bottle poured into snifter. Hazy orange color, very little transparency. Aroma is slightly floral with hints of  sour fruits. Flavor  is sour, semi sweet and mildly tart. Tickles the jaw. Easy to drink and pretty refreshing as well.
Sample from bottle at the Cantillon Museum Brussles, Belgium august 2011. Golden almost orange. Vinegar aroma, fruity. Dry taste, sour fruity, garpefruit.
Bio bottle. Flavors are orange, vanilla and absolute funk. Love it....great Gueze.
!ottle. Citrusy, tart and bittle. Very acidic with a lemon backbone of yeast and lambic. Excellent gueze. Makes your mouth pucker

Drucken på fat på Mikkeller. Gyllengul med lågt skum, syrlig doft att syrliga knappt mogna äpplen, trä, och jäst. Fantastisk fin balans. Inte för söt, inte för syrlig, frukig, blöt trä, jäst. Riktigt gott. En av de bästa, kanske den bästa geuze jag druckit.

Bottle from EZ liquors. Pours out a well carbonated apple juice color with a small bubbly white head. Aroma is of basement, tart earthy notes and some tart sourness. Taste is complex, some notes of sourness, tart funk, basement, light barnyard, some oak. Well balanced and complex.
Bottle at the brewery. Pours a nice bright yellow. Very nice offering, it has a really strong sourness to it and it tastes pretty good. I would have more of This.

Pours orange with a large disappearing white head. The aroma is oranges, lemon, some vanilla and light barnyard funk. The flavor is nicely tart with citrus rind, oranges, vanilla, mild oak, leather and funk in a bitter/tart finish. The body seems very full for a gueuze. Not as funky as oud beersel, or as oaky smooth as 3 Fonteinen. Heavier than Girardin. Perhaps more fruit forward than the others? Anyway a very nice gueuze.

Sample from bottle at the Cantillon Museum. Yellow beer with a small head. Dry rubber aroma, sourish, fruity, vinegar notes. Dry sourish flavor, fruity, rubber notes, wet grass, grapefruit, citrus. Sourish finish with wet grass.

37.5 cL bottle from Beers of Europe poured into a bowl shaped glass.  Orange golden colour with good head.  Surprisingly light and normal for gueuze.  Pleasant aroma, smells a bit vinegary though.  Sour and vinegary beer but not excessively.  Bit of apple acidity to it.

Gold with fizzy/fading white head.  Aroma is sour, with less decaying/sewage funk than some gueuzes.  Body is light and bubbly.  Flavor is a big, biting sourness and hints of apple fruit, hop bitterness.  Cleaner than other gueuzes in the tasting.  Hanssens and Beersel.

0.75l bottle. This one pours a glowing clear golden body with a small and fading just off-white head. Aroma is tart and light sour with some tart green apples, notes of wood and brett. Average carbonation, it has a eye-running light oily mouthfeeling and its medium-bodied. Damn, this is one sour, dry and tart beer. Lots of earthy, sour green apples, cider vinegar, the white stuff on the lime zest, actually some hints of strawberries in the finish and it ends really dry. Everlasting tart aftertaste.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2011 Poured from a 2010, 375ml bottle. Pours a clear golden color with a dense white head that holds up for a bit. Smell is wheaty malty with lots of clean lambic esters, pineapple lemon, funk citrus barnyard. taste is immensely rich with gueuze yeast components, funk, citrus, pineapple barnyard. so clean but so intense. a bit beyond tart to sour. pushes your senses to the limit. mouthfeel is medium light with a moderate spritzy carbonation.

I am reviewing the Monks Cafe Cuvee Gueuze (2006 vintage) that was on tap at  Monks Cafe on 8/8/11, but the listing for this beer redirected me to the Classic Gueuze. I am reviewing a completely different beer! Served in an 8 oz wine glass on tap.

Aroma- Lots of citrus and barnyard funk in the aroma, very much what I would like in an elite gueuze.

Appearance- Orange/golden in color with some head, a few bubbles clung to the edge of the glass while drinking.

Taste- Up front, sour and funk, neither overpowering, but both contributing to a very enjoyable flavor. The aftertaste is where this beer separates itself from other beers in the style. The 3 yr. old portion was brewed by the Isabelle Proximus crew with Amarillo hops, and this comes through in the orange and peach flavors present in the finish. Excellent!

Palate- The citrus flavors linger nicely on the tongue. Very easy to drink without taxing the ol palate.

Overall- I (and my friends) could have ordered some more Fou Fone (2007 at that!) for the table to drink for our last round and we went with this instead. This was a great, inventive take on the gueuze style.

37.5cl bottle: Bottled in 2009. Bright yellow colour with almost no head. Fruity-citric aroma, not just lemony, fruits like apples and pear come to my mind. Definitely a hint of alcohol as well. The taste is of course sour, but far from being abrasive. Its actually very refreshing, with a lingering pithy aftertaste. Im not too big into sours, but this is quite nice.

Poor is nicely heady and hazy. Smell is like ground green apple seeds LOTS! of fruit acids. Taste is cheek burning lip puckering and eye squinting. AWESOME! Has HUGE green apple and tart pear flavors. Big aromatic florals. Great Beer. Will kill your taste buds after a glass but well worth is.
750mL corked bottle poured pale golden into wine glass with little head.  Earthy and citrus aromas dominate, taste slightly yeasty and lots of sour.

Pale gold with lively carbonation.  Citrus, lactic acid and some great, fresh funk.  Sour, lemon citrus, funk, some cider.  Dry, residual sourness.  Mildest of hop bitterness.  Still working on appreciating the sours.

i like the very sourish cantillon taste.
It is refreshing to!
It is not really balanced, only sour........
citrus notes as usual

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2012 Rerating 13.10.2012.
Yeasty cider smell, mud coloured and hazy. Extremely sour and medium bitter. Aroma of apple and some other fruit.

Poured a slightly hazy yellow/orange color with almost no head.  Nice tart aroma with some fruit and lots of yeasty notes.  Slightly dry.  Taste is very crisp and tart with nice fruity flavors.  Finish is dry with some bitter slightly hoppy notes.  Slightly acidic as well.  This is a great lambic, the flavors are very strong and well balanced.

Clear golden blonde with a thin white head leaving a nice veil. Tart fruits aromas with citric notes. Nice acidic bite on the palate, very clean lambic with nice lemon flavors, hay and a touch of funkyness, earthy finish. Very refreshing lambic.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2017 Rerate: It takes time and continuesly trying out new beers, especially sours, to get used to it. Look at my old original rating from 2011, I think this was by far my highest rated lambic and I rated it 3.1. Nowadays I love this beer. The essence is still the same though: I really love the balanced sour fruitiness in this beer. Very well done. -- Original rating: 6-3-6-3-13=3.1 - I dont like sourness in a beer. I dont like 99 out of 100 sour ales, wild ales, lambics or fruitbeers. But after tasting the Cantillon Kriek, which was way better and way more balanced then other krieken or lambics, I was very curious about other Cantillon brews. To other raters a 3.1 may be a low score. I found this beer to be pure sour and very very well balanced, but just too sour for me. I dont dislike it, but its just not my style. Still: very recommendable this beer, even if you dont like sour ales, lambics etc etc.
Hazy golden with tiny head. Very sour aroma with leather and wood. Flavor contains apples, leather and ends rather dry.

This is my first true lambic so here we go! 12.7oz bottle Bottled 17 Sept. 2010.  Pours a pure clear gold with no head. Initially, I was alarmed at the utter lack of a head until the bartender informed me that this is characteristic of the style.  Aroma is SOUR! I detect notes of funk, citrus, hay, cherries and limes.  Taste is puckeringly sour with notes of sourdough, french oak, hay, and the aforementioned fruits.  Body is medium with sneaky carbonation that swells up in the mouth like champagne.  Although it appears non-carbonated, it is super fizzy.  Absolutely bone dry finish that felt like it was cleaning my teeth... Ethereal.  Overall, this is one of the best beers Ive ever had, bar none.  Intensely complex and utterly delicious!

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2012 Bottling date of March 17, 2010. Got this 750ml via trade. After months of contemplating when to drink it...I finally cracked it on a random Tuesday when I was out of work early and its hot as hell out. Capped and corked bottle, absolutely love the label and look of this bottle. I cracked the cap and found some vile smelling yellow liquid sitting above the cork. Decided to give it a taste....straight acid. The spider webbed cork pulled out with a very faint pop. First glass was poured into a palm tulip at near cellar temperature. The rest of the bottle went into the fridge for some temperature variation. Pairing this with some fresh caprese salad drenched in balsamic vinegar.

A - Deep golden color, lots of bubbling, and a really impressive white, foamy head that died down slowly. Lacing was pretty dismal.

S - The first thing I thought of was sparkling apple cider...and then came the wall of funk. Lots of bretty goodness, hay, sour lemons, and oak.

T - Near perfect. The mouth feel is just so dry, lively and crisp. It just compliments the amazing flavors profile. Sour apples and lemon, barnyard funk, hay, grass, and light oak flavors. 

O - This just surpassed Drie Fonteinen oude as my favorite gueze. This is such a well crafted beer that was worth the wait.

Great sour acidic lambic taste. Hits all of the taste buds at once. The aroma is complex and difficult to describe. Hops are really in the background as they should be. There was no yeasty aroma. The head was minimal and assumed properly poured since it was at Cantillon.

Was very eager to try this one, although i dont really like gueuzes/wild ales. This one seemed to be the most sour one ive tasted yet. Very balanced though. Not my favorite beer, but it sure made me respect this style more.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2011 Bottle. Gold pour with white foam. Strong lambic funkiness immediately finds its way to my nose as Im pouring. Aroma has strong notes of wet hay, leather, brett, classic farmyard gueuze funk and cheesy aromas from the aged hops. Taste is very sour, no sweetness really, some old hop flavors. Palate is what makes these beers a wonderful experience for me. Highly carbonated and dry, it is super refreshing. A great classic.

Have had this many times, only just got round to rating it! Pour is peachy orange with no head. Nose is barnyard funk, hint of apricot, hint of vinegar, very distinctive indeed. Taste is sour and extremely dry, no sweetness at all. Hint of green apple on a long, assertive finish. Absolute classic.

Bottle at home. Cloudy golden colour with no real head. Classic lambic funk in aroma, with acid and some fruity hints. Taste is very sour, kinda in the same was as green apples. Takes a couple of sips to acclimatise to, after that, its lovely. Dry, refreshing finish. Actually really hits the spot - very nice indeed.

Disclaimer: This is the first time I taste a lambic! Yet another virginity lost. (I have tried another type of sour beers though.) The color of this one is somewhat unusual to me. Its a golden-orange, but not in the way a "normal" beer is. This one "looks thicker", if that makes any sense. There is virtually no head, only tiny bubbles. Probably normal for this style? Next: aroma. At the first smell I definitely get what must be the barnyard funk Ive read so many times. Also, a bread-like component here, and a hint of something fruity, peach perhaps? And of course the expected sour vinegar-like aroma is in place. Otherwise, Im having difficulty finding the proper words here. So I take a sip. WHOA! What was that? I got some hop flavor there, and something else, I think its yeasty esters, and a MASSIVE sourness! And then some really well done, almost burnt barbecued meat?! Nope, didnt expect that! The sour taste is a green apple kind of sourness. The best part is: I really like this! Thus began my journey into the world of sour beers...

This poured a clear yellow color with a white head. Aroma was lots of barnyard funk, some vinegar and tart green apples. Flavor was medium sourness, more funk than sour, some chesse and sour lemons and apples.

In die Nase steigt ein Aroma von trockenem Weißwein, säuerlich. 
Der erste Geschmackseindruck ist bombastisch sauer. Nach einer Eingewöhnung kommen apfelartige Aromen auf der Zunge zum Tragen. Auch ein Hang zum moosig-modrigen (Waldboden) läßt sich nicht abstreiten. 
Ein sehr eigenwilliges Bier, dessen Säure die meisten Biertrinker verschrecken dürfte. Dennoch ein Gebräu mit Qualitäten.Test vom 20.2.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2016 New Rating:
Clear golden colour, white head. Funky aroma, loads of lemon. Light sour flavour, funky brett, lemon. Quite mellow. Finish citrus, white wine, lemon, wood. Very, very nice! The best bottle of Cantillon Gueuze Ive tasted to date.(from 1,5L magnum bottle -2011 Vintage- @ Cantillon Quintessence 2016)
Old Rating:Slightly hazy light amber golden colour, no real head but some covering bubbles. Very sour aroma, brett, acidic acid, bit buttery. Sour notes overpowering most other smells. Some fruits, bit of malt, some earth. Flavour keynote is very tart, all kinds of sour. Citric acid, lactic acid, acidic. Slight iron. Very dry, rather astringent. Long acidic and dry finish. Quite hardcore geuze, not for the faint hearted.
(From 75cL bottle)
7-4-7-4-15: 3.7
Tap @ Akkurat, courtesy of pantanap. Pours cloudy golden with a tiny white head. Great sour, fruity, buttery and honey aroma.  Flavor is dry tart, sour and fruity   Finises sour tart.

versa color oro ottonato, la schiuma è bianca spumosa, di poca persistenza, al naso è attraente, con le note fruttate di mela e limone in primo piano. al palato è però difficile, lacidità presente e invadente è caratterizzata da un agrumato rancido, arancio ammuffito, la persitenza in bocca è lunga e dopo qualche secondo si aggiusta, ma nel complesso non sono stato ammaliato da questa birra.
Bottle. Pours hazy orange with a bit of white head. Aroma is funky with sour lemon and citrus, a bit acetic. Taste is dry ant tart with more citrus. Very solid.
Bottle at Doerak, Delft. A new beer style for me but an enjoyable introduction. Tart, sour flavor and dryness.

A SIP of a friends beer at the Doerak.
Not my cup of tea.  I must rerate this if I start liking sour beers.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2013 On [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ pub.Pours cloudy golden with a white head.Aroma of funky barnyard, berries, citrus/lemon and vinegar.Flavor is sour with some sweetness and oak/wood .Nice leathery texture.Medium body, average carbonation . Classic Geuze !

375ml bottle. It pours a rich golden colour wih some bubbles and a little bit of head some of which hangs around. The nose is hard to describe, sour with notes of apple and perhaps even a hint of salt. The taste confirms the nose with an apple vinegar start and middle and definitely a long note of salt on the end. The palate - how do you describe something that doesnt have the traditional constructs of structure, texture and bitterness. This is sour from start to finish and rather than making you thirsty to have another drink, it makes you contemplate it for a while and then take another sip.....never a gulp. You have to be in the right frame of mind for this, if youre not, its wasted. Overall, its one of the most interesting beers in the world but I dont want to have more than one, in fact, I just want to share one. So, the enjoyment is not as much as the individual personality that it has.

50 cl bottled dec. 2010
Really nice head, not clear, yellow
Sour and fruity, still "friendky" but seems unevolved
some body nice length, harmonic
Delicious but I think it is still too young (4 month)

Cloudy orange pour from a 375ml 100% bio. Big white head. Aroma full of oak, sour funk, peach, and light sugar. Excellent. Flavor is similr with massive tart peach, starfruit and apricot, soaked in a funky oaky gueze bath. Awesome and extreme drinkability, this gueze stands out in a beautiful way.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2014 My first Lambic. Bottle from Selfridges. Date on it was April 2010. Pours yellow/orangey. Aroma is tart, vinegary. Taste is surprisingly very tart citrous, like really bitter, with vinegary sours and apple notes in there. Its like a cider without the sweetness. This is definitely an acquired taste and not an entirely pleasant experience. Sorry, just being honest. I will come back and reassess after trying other Lambics. 3.4 Re-rate at Toms Lambic tasting Craft Beer Co. Cloudy, thin white head. Nose is apple, caramel, cider. Taste is sour, acidic, white apple, dry on finish. Citric acidic, citrousy, lemon. Lighter and more citrus than other Lambic gueuze. Very drinkable but not as much depth as others. 3.7 Rating at GBBF 2014 on gravity dispense at the Belgian Bar. Colour is bright cloudy, rusty orange, almost no head, few white bubbles. Nose is tart sour, apple skins, citrous acidic, musty grain, white wine vinegar. Taste is tart and sour, clean white wine vinegar, sharp and tangy white apple and apple skin tannin, musty grain. Full flavoured and very sharp and tart. Superb. Compared with a Tilquin and the Tilquin was much softer and more subtle. Preferred the Cantillon! Big bold flavour and full body.

Bottle. Pours a light golden yellow color with a small white head. Aroma is very tart with alot of white wine and vinous notes, some white grape, green apple, applevinegar, funk and citrus. The flavor is super tart with alot of white grape and funk, along with the green apple, applevinegar, citrus and hay notes. The body is light with a very dry mouthfeel. Overall a really nice Gueuze, probably the best I have had.

Best lambic i ever experienced. Excellent. A true world classic. This lambic is subtle and balanced. The musty and tart characters perfectly balance eachother creating a surprisingly mild beer. No slap you in the face tartness or overly pungent mustiness. Aged approxmiately 1 year in bottle. Drank at the end of an era...while moving out of the old apartment with Mike.

(750ml bottle from rayl101!).  Pours hazy golden color with white head.  Good carbonation.  Aroma is funk, cobwebs, green apple, and some light berries.  Taste is sour with a little funkiness and some vinegar.  Thin bodied with a slick mouthfeel.  Finish is quite dry, yet its quenching.  A very solid beer that is easy to drink, especially on a warm day (as it is here now).
small bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange with a white head.  Nose is of sour lemon and orange rind.  Taste is of sour fruit - lemon and orange.  Mouthfeel is very sour, yet smooth.  Nice.

Courtesy of CraftyCarl21.
Yellow-gold pour.
Aroma is sour and heavily of barnyard.
Flavor is very acidic sour, berries and grapes, plus hay and notes of yeast.
Dry/acidic finish.

12.7 oz. Bottle labaled classic gueuze. Pour is hazy gold yellow with a tight  off white head that fades to a film. Aroma is sour funk with some apple and citrus. Taste is again sour tartness and funky fruit that feels acidic. Palate is thin and fizzy and finishes dry and bitter. Tasty!

Bottle:  Bright golden pour, tons of bubbles, and a large off-white fizzy head.  The nose is very tart and acidic, oak, earthy sours... very lively.  Smooth blend of sours, tart, citrus, oak, earthy, and a little barnyard funk come through in the taste.  Tart and lingering finish.  Acidic.  The palate is actually quite smooth and creamy.  Very enjoyable.

2010 bottled.  Pours a golden color with hints od red.  Clear with an ample white head.  Aromas are of sour peach and pear with notes of sweet sugar.  Taste is very tart, sour fruit notes with a light vinegar note.  Much like a champagne, or white wine.  A very interesting and tasty beerl
I accidentally chilled this beer, the strong tart sour flavors are subdued with the oak aging, very delicious

Bottle, cellared since 2007, shared with Jeff. Hazy light bronze, robust ever-lasting finely bubbled head that glaciates its way down the glass. The retention on this beer was remarkable. Aroma is awesome and ever-changing throughout the drinking experience. Initially lots of basement must and cobwebs, followed variously by notes of light vinegar, petroleum, white grape juice, horseblanket, and dried out corn stalks in autumn. Flavours are complex as expected, but are centered around a surprisingly toasty malt base (not expected). Lots of funky horseblanket, light pear and green grape fruit, some yoghurty lactic acidity, light vinegar, light acetone. Finish is mildly sour and astringent. I was anticipating this with high expectations, and I was not disappointed. Absolutely fantastic!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: slightly opaque orangish yellow. nice fluffy white head with great retention. outstanding lacing. very tart nose. unripe peaches, a nice vinegar aroma, but subtle, some grape notes. almost chardonnay like. lemons and some spun sugar. absolutely outstanding...like biting into a key lime. very tart, but sweet at the same time.

750 ml. bottle thanks poisoneddwarf- Pours hazy cloudy orange with a nice soapy white head and perfect blanket lacework. The aroma is strong notes of brett, tart cherries, orange, raisins, very complex. The flavor is brett up front, followed by a mellow tartness that intensifies as it lingers on the tongue. This is my first Gueze, and I love it. The body is medium to full, carbonation is medium, finish is bitter and sour. Nice beer, thanks bro.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2011 750 ml bottle into tulip, shared with Brenn79. Pours a hazy gold with a medium white head with nice retention. Aroma is strong in Brett (so pungent my brother could smell it from out in the hallway about ten feet from my glass); some other things noticeable are wet stone, a freshly opened bag of raisins, tart berries, basement, October leaves...lots of stuff here. Nice. Taste is mouth-puckeringly sour. Carbonation is medium, body is full, mouthfeel is creamy. I cant find much wrong with this, other than the fact that Ive seen better lacework in other beers, but I have a sneaking suspicion that the 3 Fonteinen is going to be superior. But this is some seriously delicious stuff.

Bottle. 1997 Vintage, shared by Darren.  
This is one of the most intense beers Ive ever experienced.  The aroma is an insane mixture of tart, gasoline, sour, and nail polish remover. Whaaaat?  Not completely pleasant, but earns points for intensity for sure. I had doubts if this was even safe to ingest.  The flavor was a bit more refined but was still hugely acidic with a new level of sour.  Sharp lively carbonation.  Probably a bit beyond my level of appreciation for sours. But this one was not easy to come by and I thank Darren a ton for sharing it.

2009 vintage. Beer is yellow / orange and forms a big white head of tiny bubbles. Carbonation is moderate and steady. No lacing on the glass but this beer looks great.

Aroma is sour, very lactic, slightly acetic. Very good.

Beer is thin and kind of fruity with lots of great flavors. Finishes cleanly, nice lactic and acetic notes with great tartness at the corners. Drinkability high, mouthfeel great. One of the best gueuzes Ive ever had.

Serving type: bottle

Sample at brewery in Brussels. Pours a translucent apricot color. Aroma consists of complex layers of deep sour, yeast, and acid. Taste is a rapid influx of flavor that mellows out in to a smooth finish. Flavor is a mellow sour with various layerings of yeast, acid, citrus, and very slight bitter-sour. Very fluid - neither thick nor watery. Finish is sour and acidic - shifts from wet to dry. Quite excellent.

375ml bottle, bottled 2008-04-28. Pours a slightly cloudy, medium straw. Complex nose, evidently funky, lots of brett, barnyard, oxidized apples, hay, malt, wax, wood, faint dairy-like notes. Medium body, bone dry, low bitterness, marked acidity, appropriately low carbonation. Very complex, rather matured taste, very tart but balanced, apples, brett, malt, hay, funky, cheese (!). Wonderful. (2010-12-21)

Pours with a fantastic white fluffy head, supported by a hazy golden body with lots of carbonation. And what an aroma factory this one is: funky dirty socks, apple cider, vinegar - generally barn-yard. Pucker up, because I know whats coming: a sour fizz thatll either be wonderful or damn punishing. Indeed, this has turnout out to be one of my favorites: think granny smith apples on steroids, sprinkled with a bit of salt, lemon, and wood chips, although I expected the taste to be a bit more intense. Overall, its simply a wonderful experience.
classic gueze, the standard. Cloudy but clearish gold, ok retention and lace... The nose is horse blanket, musk, tart but overpowering... The taste is very sour horse blanker. Great.

Bottle at the Rake, shared with Duff and Reakt. It pours hazy golden yellow with a thin fizzy white head. The nose is sour white grape, juicy fruit, lemon and skunky. It tastes of juicy white grape, lemon, lime, red apple, grass, and a little soap. It is quite light bodied and has a fruity tart finish. The sweet-sour balance is spot on. Yum.

375ml bottle. Pours a cloudy golden color with a foamy white head. Aroma is mostly sweet-sour with oak and horse blanket qualities. Taste is sweet/sour, almost lemon peel. Grassy earthy notes. Some bittering hops. Medium bodied and lots of carbonation. A true classic for the style.

Bottle: 2010:
Quick disappearing small white head.
Beautiful clear orange colored beer.
Smell sour, dust, yeast, wood, piss, hint of berries, yellow fruit (lemon and grape).
Taste sour, acidic, yeast, wood, lime, lemon, malt, dust, sour berries, grape, citrus and hint of grain and wheat.
Nice aftertaste of sour, bitter, herbs, wood, sour sweet.
Medium to full body, low to medium carbo, soft mouthfeel which turns quick into a tingly mouthfeel. Lovely Gueuze!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle 37.5cl at tre små rum. Pours almost clear yellow with a small white head that disappears quickly. Complex aroma of stable, citrus, root cellar and whool. Sour to the taste, acid, root cellar and citrus. Light bodied. Great beer!

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2013 29 sept 2013, bottle. Dark yellow, faintly cloudy, occasional bubbles. Nose is brett yeast. Thin body and mildly fizzy. Oaky, brett. Very approachable. Not terribly sour. Dry but not hugely sour. 

(Original rating 7 2 7 2 12 = 3) mar 15 2011.  light yellow, slightly hazy. 
smells slightly tart like green apple. heavy on tart, light on apple. tart, vinegar and unripe green grapes. 
only the second or third lambic ive had so i dont know what to compare it to or how to describe it. 
ever so slightly acidic and tart but mild in both categories. remembering the other cantillon, this is very balanced. 
tart and oaky. awesome!

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2014 [14/03/2011] [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Moeder Lambic: very different and more straightforward than the 3 Fonteinen Geuze but that may have been just because I tried this one on tap & not from the bottle, it was complex, subtle, with restrained sourness, tart & funk, compared to others of its kind & the lemon, vinegar & acid were less harsh, minor barnyard, very nice, extremely drinkable on tap, dry lasting finish // this is one fine brew that improves greatly with age, had a sip of 2003 not too long ago, this really blossoms with age, stellar /// Had this one many more times since the previous rating, didnt take any notes, it is very balanced, little in the way of acidity young, quite an incredible achievement, great stuff and obv. better than 4.5 // upped it to 4.7 (it is at least a 4.7) ///////// Tried a 2002 Vintage. 75 cl. bottle @ Cantillon Quintessence 2014. Mind-blowing aging potential confirmed here. Smells hugely funky, raw barnyard and burlap sack with little acidity. Taste is surprisingly mellow, little sourness, very fruity, peaches, pepper, touch bitter oak, incredibly mellow and balanced. Doesnt feel past it in any way, gorgeous.

Clear amber with a white head. Aroma is very sour - vinegar. Flavor is medium sweet and very sour. Sour and dry finish. This is rather one-dimensional with the very sour vingear dominating. Fortunately I like that. 110311

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2013 Bottle @ Vail. Pours a cloudy yellow orange appearance with a cream colored head. Cheesy, funky, big lemony sour, vanilla aroma. Quite sour, big lemon, light orange, fairly oaky, lactic, moderately cheesy flavor. This bottle seems to be less sour and more funky than my previous experiences but still not as good as 3 Fonteinen.

Bottle. Cork date of 2009 so this is a really young one. Cork opens with a nice pop. Poured into a tulip glass a clear, only ever so slight haze, apricot orange color with a 1 finger lace white head that quickly settles to form a slight collar around teh glass. The aromatics include; white fruit notes like pear, apple, and grape, definitely some barnyard funk, and hay. Carbonation dances on the tongue with a light mouthfeel. Not overly sour but its there along with a funky floral flavor all balanced with some sweetness and a slight bitter in the end. End semi-dry and clean. For the price and availability, this is just great.
Bottle @ Blackfriars. Hazy light golden colour, no head. Aroma is sour apple, yeasty, funky, barnyard. Flavour is sour apple, funky, bit of vinegar.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2011 330 ml bottle from bierzwerg.de. Hazy, light/golden colour with white small head. Looks like a gueuze should. Smells funky with much lemon, lemon zest, sour apples, barnyard and horse blanket. Taste is sour with small sweetness. Not overpowering sour, very well balanced. Light to medium bodied with good carbonation. Very good gueuze overall. 9/4/7/3/17

Re-rating 20110812, this time 1997 vintage. 375 ml bottle at Akkurat.
Almost clear, deep golden liquid with small white head. Aroma is funky with notes of apple, horseblanket, barnyard, lemons. Balanced and a bit less agressive than the younger ones. Taste is dry and medium sour (for the style) with notes of lemons and apples. Light to medium bodied with nice carbonation. Compared to a fresh bottle, this is a lot more balanced. Overall, I really enjoyed it a lot. 9/4/8/4/17

On draft labeled as Monks Cafe Geuze. Pours a hazy, golden straw yellow color and topped by a small head of white foam that settles quickly leaving barely any lace. The aroma is classic geuze with notes of barnyard funk, sour lemon and grapefruits, citric acidity, along with some old oak. The flavors follow suit with the sharp, soured citrus fruit and funky yeast up front followed by a touch of vanilla from the oak and vinegar. Medium bodied with ample carbonation that leads to a short, dry and refreshing finish. Nice stuff.

Pours a beautiful hazy golden blonde with a thin white head.  Aroma is not as strong as I expected.  Standard sour notes, apples, a little yeast.  Taste is very tart, with apple and peach notes and a subdued, but well done creamy maltiness underneath.  Finish is long, tart, and dry.  This is a very good Gueuze.
Yellow orange pour with rim lacing.  Sour nose, brett, barnyard funk, hops.  Has a classic gueuze taste, kind of metallic with bitter citrus hops.  Finish is dry sour and pleasantly bitter.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2014 Looks like a gueuze man! Aroma is wild with notes of bretty yeast, classic gueuze barnyardy notes, sour berries, rural notes and lemon peel. Taste of citrus, grapefruit, wine, barnyard, white-wine, brett, slight woody and some sour fruity peels in the end along with a dry mouthfeel. Extremely fresh and drinkable!

On tap at the local option. Pour is cloudy light gold with a modest white head. "Thats a lambic". Indeed it is, my friend. This brew has a nice funky sour barnyard nose. Lemon zest, hay, funk, spicy, earthy, sour. Nice brew, really.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2013 2008 Vintage, Green bottle with yellow label. "Classic Gueuze".

A careful pour into my Duvel glass produces a bright orange/amber/peach colored beer with a firm white head that dissipates rather quickly, with not much lacing.

The smell is bright and sour with hints of citrus, pear, apple peel, and some funk as well.

I almost coughed after the first huge quaff of this, something in here is really sinus clearing. It has a nice tart fruit tang, with some shock tart acid as well, though it isnt overly sour like some beers. It has a good subtle sweetness to balance out the sourness and a decent mouthfeel, if a tad bit watery. Hints of pale malt, green apple, and yeast come out in the aftertaste.

The object of a Gueuze shouldnt be making something unbearably sour, and this one isnt, it is almost a perfect gueuz,

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-29-2009 23:38:31

2003 Vintage Bottle that I have had stashed in the cellar for years.  Pours a bright orange color with a tiny layer of bubbles.  The nose on this beer was unreal, like a super sharp cheese rind followed by a pervasive dry oak scent.  Taste was typical gueze with some barnyard funk and tart green apple notes.  Only real complaint was that the body was a little watery.  Hard to believe how dry this beer is, makes you feel like you need to keep an emergency glass of water on hand.  Oak and stale cheese flavors are found throughout.  The finish is dry and crisp.  I think this one benefited from some aging, it really sharpened the flavors compared to a fresh bottle.  Oddly the cork smelled heavily of caramel even though its about the last flavor on earth you would associate with this beer.  Another winner from Cantillon.

18.02.2011. 0,75l Bottle. Vinmonopolet Haugesund. Pale golden colour with white head. Aroma is sour and it bites like acid. Very refreshing beer. Tastes good with sharp aftertaste and a long lasting sour finish. There is a lot of yeastflavours at the end.

Tasted from a 750mL bottle purchased at Binnys South Loop, 2008 vintage.  Pours clear golden with a thick white head that quickly recedes to a thin lace collar.  The nose is sour and funky with a good amount of citrus and vinegar.  The flavor is sour and funky with citrus, vinegar, and light bitterness.  The body is light with average carbonation and a long sour and funky finish.
Triple Rock Sour & BA Fest.  Poured hazy orangish yellow, citrus, funky, wood, dry finish.
Bottle pours out a cloudy golden topped with a small head. Aroma was of sour, barnyard, citrus, brett, and some other fruit. Taste was much as the aroma with a nice funk, fruit, and a little wood.
Bottle, Pours hazy yellow/orange with a nice but quickly disappearing white head. Aroma of lemon, citrus, vinegar, and barnyard funk. Very intense citrus sour flavor with a clean finish.

Pours hazy orange with frothy white head that is quick to fade. It has an aroma of funk, vinegar, lemon, and something I could only describe as "earthy". The flavor has that horseblanket funk, vinegar, and an lemon/acidic background. It has a dry finish and a splendid tartness. Quite the thirst quencher.
Fruity aroma.  Pours a hazy straw.  Lactobacillus sourness.  Astringent and tart on the finish.  I wish I could describe how good this beer is!

Poured into a tulip.

4.5 A: Slightly hazy vibrant yellow orange color. One finger of "fuzzy" white head that drops quickly but leaves behind 1/8 inch head for quite some time.

4.0 S: Lots of astringent woodiness from the top. Acetic acid and feet that have not been washed in weeks. Zesty lemon and citric acid. Musty basement.

4.0 T: Puckering sourness throughout. Sturdy musty cellar undertones. Lemon and tart crab apple fruitiness, but for the most part dry. Woody astringency with a touch of acetic acid and lots of citric acid.

4.5 M: Lighter body, but quite creamy. Plenty of fizzy carbonation. Dry finish with lingering astringency.

4.0 D: Tasty brew. Ive been into wild stuff lately and this hit the spot. Strong flavors, but not off putting. Well done.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-13-2010 01:49:49

Pours pale golden or yellow.  Aroma is fruity, oaky, basement funk, lactic sourness, and mellow overall and very pleasant.  Taste is oaks, lemony fruits, lactic sourness, basement funk.  Doesnt seem just too overly complex.  Light body and just slightly oily on the palate.
Bottle 350ml. Pours golden hazy with white head. Aroma is vinegar, dry white wine, yeast. Lasting sour taste with bitter and sweet notes. Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle 37,5 cl. Poured golden blonde in colour with a sparkling white head. Aroma is  vinegar, wine-like notes, dry and sour. Flavour is very sour, light fruitiness and crispness of fresh green apples. Interesting concept this one and leaves one with a very pleasant aftertaste.
750 bottle.  poured golden yellow, funky sour, excellent gueuze example.  nice head and lacing.
750 bottle thanks to rommel.  Poured a dark goldfish yellow.  Very clean and enjoyable funky gueuze.

A very accomplished and complex beer, more drinkable than I assumed..  Pours hazy amber with a small head. The aroma is big and fruity, the lambic funk quality is very well complimented by notes of orange, caramel, apple and a distinct tartness. The flavour is also funky, quite tart, especially toward the finish, and fruity. Some caramel initially, but much more predominantly dry, sharp citrus and peaches are also evident. Wonderful

Ricordo che prima di una serata romantica con mia moglie, decisi di aprire la danze con questo lambic come aperitivo. Da quel momento anche lei quando mi vede tirar furi bottiglie simili addrizza le antenne...Io ne berrei a litri...

Aroma and taste unmistakable.
The sharp taste, accentuates the classic Lambic taste and this makes the Cantillon Gueuze very appreciable by the most obstinate Lambic lovers. I like it very much.
Bottle at the Ginger Man. Pours semi-cloudy apricot. Nose and taste of tart fruit, peach skin, fermented pear and oak. Very tart on the palate.

Shared bottle. Sparkling. Hazy golden with a fully diminishing head. Wonderful fruity and malty berries aroma. Fresh and inviting. Crisp and acidic with malty notes. Dry. Medium body. Medium carbonated. Had it with shrimp - a combination that worked well.
Yellow-orange in color, hazy, with a big head that quickly fades to nothing. Aroma is straight up sour and funkiness. Certainly not everyones cup of tea. A bit too tart for my tastes.
33 cl bottle, Devonshire Cat, Sheffield, UK. Hazy gold appearance, cinnamon spiced vinegar aroma. Sour lime flavour with a musty background.

375 ml bottle from Wine and Cheese Place.  Labeled Classic Gueuze.  Bottled 30 December 2009.  Pours a semi-cloudy gold with a finger-thick white head that leaves some film on the beer and lace in the glass.  Aroma of oak, lemon citrus, white grapes, funk, lemongrass, and basement.  Flavor of lemon juice, oak, white grape skins, tart green apples, funk, and a little lactic acid.  Finishes dry and tart.  Light-medium bodied, with medium carbonation and a lingering tart mouthfeel.  Really nice gueuze.

This is my first gueuze, so I have no idea what to expect. I like sour foods and non-alcoholic drinks, so well see how this turns out.

Bottled in 2007.

G: Poured into a Duvel tulip glass.

A: Pours a hazy, light gold with the tiniest white head, which very quickly recedes into bubbles.

S: Definite funk and sourness. After that, some green grapes and hints of citrus. Lots of barnyard and a little lemon.

T: Supremely sour off of the first sip. As the sourness recedes, Im getting tangy fruits and some tart green grape and/or green apple.

M: Other than the clear acidity, surprising smooth. Very dry. Much tangier/sour on the tongue, and smooth as it goes down. With this level of sourness and low ABV, its clear there wont be any taste of alcohol.

D: Surprisingly drinkable. It took my palate a little while to adjust to the new style, but after the first few sips I was definitely getting into it.

[3315-20100809] 750mL bottle. Foamy yeast aroma smells vaguely like rotting cucumber. Slightly hazy, light orange brown body with a long-lasting foamy white head. Mild barrel yeast flavour has a lingering sourness. Medium body builds upon a foundation of sourness as you sip. Fresh and quite tasty, very pleasant.
(@ brewery, Brussels, Belgium; w/ jerc)
Cloudy yellow with no head. Nose was of sweet, sour urine, but in a good way. Puckering nastiness- I just dont get it :(

Appearance: haze from the bottom is slow to spread throughout the brew within my freshly poured glass. Fizzy and bubbly. Decent white blanket; bubbly. Swirls with no lace but retains head.

Nose: tart and sour up front followed by earthiness, hay, and leather. Straw and dried flower petals in the back. Lemon essence and rind in the front. Hint of kiwi, slightly unripe. Overall lively and bright, earthy and homely.

Palate: I love gueuze; I love sour. Soft mouthfeel despite playful carbonation. Almost creamy soft white breadiness to mouthfeel. Bright on top of tongue. Kiwi more forward than lemon, though both evident. Not overly dry. Concentrated lemon zest inside and out while underneath rests leather, dry earth, and baled straw. Tastebuds do a happy dance. Short finish. Kiwi and lemon pith is a whisper amongst the leather, dry earth, and baled straw. Balanced with Brett dryness tinging my breath.

Final Thoughts: one of the best gueuzes to please these tastebuds yet. Not easily available in my area, I nonetheless enjoyed her as much as I possibly could. Even now I can relive each and every flavor moment with keen precision accompanied by a goofy smile of contentment on my face. Cantillon rocks my world. Nuf said.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2013 Bottle 750ml vintage 2009 @ Geokkjer
Pours slightly hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is sour with notes of malt, horseblanket, barnyard and funk. Taste is light sweet and medium sour with a long sour, dry and fruity finish. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

Bottle 750ml @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours clear golden with a small white head. Aroma has notes of sour green apples and spices. Taste isheavy sour with an average dry finish. Body is full, texture is thin, carbonation is soft. [6 3 6 3 13 - 3.1]
Nice orange colour. Hazy, light head. Aromas of sour berries. wonderful refreshing taste, sour, fruity.

Corked and capped champagne bottle.  Labled Classic Gueuze.  Poured very clear, pale yellow with a nice foamy bone white head.  The aroma had a strong sour yet somewhat fruity presence.  Super musty but was actually quite pleasant.  Flavors were tart up front, really hit the glands in the back of my mouth with a puckering sourness.  Very dry finish although it left a sticky feeling in my mouth.  These brews are so different, a lot of fun.

Bottle at Where the Wild Beers Are. Hazy bronze pour with white head. Aroma of cherry, raspberry, and red wine vinegar. Intense flavor of nail polish and sharp notes of sour cherry. Finish is nail polish and acetone with raspberry. Intense but sharply sour but just short of being obnoxious.

Bouteille de 375 ml. Arômes rustiques de brettanomyces rappelant le foin et les herbes sèches. Touche citronnée. Robe dorée et légèrement trouble, effervescence moyenne et légère mousse. En bouche, on retrouve une acidité lactique et citrique très vibrante, mais demeurant équilibrée. Les brettanomyces apportent une touche très rustique (foin, cuir). Belle touche dagrumes. Finale bien sûre et très sèche. Un classique !

Clear straw pour with a white soapy head. Atoma has lots of funky barnyard, citrus, vinegar, tart apples and oak. The taste is really nice and fresh, very balanced. Oranges, apples, tartness, barnyard, lime bitterness and all of it just hugely well balanced. A text book gueuze.

Bottle. Slightly hazy orange colour with a smal white foam. Aroma is big on sourness with lots of vinegar, sour grapes, sour raspberry, barnyard, cherry, basement and yeast. Taste is only moderately sour and quite fresh. Also lots of vinegar and sour grapes. Very pleasant and yet adequately complex.
Lättdrucken, trevlig balanserad syrlighet, vinteräpplen, vindruvor. Så god att det nästan är lite hink-varning.

375ml bottle.  Pours a very hazy orange with no head.  Aroma is apples, woody, sour cheese and some grapes.  Tart lemon to start.  Sour finish with some cheese.  Very dry, tart finish.  Good level of carbonation.
Bottle @ the brewery. Pours dark yellow, pretty clear, sticky white head, good retention. Sour nose, aroma of sour apples and a dusty attic. Flavor predominantly sour. Pleasant astringency.

[sample from 750ml bottle at Cantillon Brewery, Brussels] Famously an acquired taste, sampled at the brewery serving area following the self-guided tour. Totally opaque, extremely hazy almost peach-colour. Vinegary tartness dominates the aroma, with gooseberries and other sharp fruit coming out. On the palate it is colossally sour, extremely bitter with an acid tartness. I can see why lambics are revered, but Im not going to deny it was a struggle to get through  Ill clearly need to drink a lot more before I get a taste for them (having been raised on British bitters and porters). One for a re-rate in the future [31032010]
10/9/10.  Thanks Coleman!  Green apple and sour cheese aroma with a nice sour flavor with a hint of bitter grain and greens.  Very nice!

Clouded golden orange with a dense white head.  Fruity, lemony sour aroma loaded with barnyard funk.  The flavor gives a similar impression, sharply citrus sour throughout without overwhelming, develops barnyard, wood, hay flavors.  A very well made gueuze that I would return to.

12.7oz bottle with deyholla, thanks Derek! Pours a hazed, somewhat deep gold colored body with a thin, foamy, white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is horse blanket, moderately tart and funky with lots of nice lemon-citrus, apples, florals, wood, and some lighter malts. Flavor is similar. Very woody and funky up front with lots of tart lemons, flowery citruses, apples, horse blanket, and a touch of acidity. Flavor grows nicely into the finish where this is dry, woody, tart and puckering, but not over-the-top. Lengthy aftertaste following a light, smooth, clean body and soft carbonation. Overall, a pretty impressive gueuze. Funky, tart, and fairly straightforward, but very tasty without ever getting obnoxiously sour or acidic. Very nice.

Im totally not a geuze/lambic-fan... Bought this bottle some months ago for a trade on RB... For some reasons the trade never took place, so this bottle stand in my way... Pours out golden coloured, a good sized head, but colapse to quick. Smell is sour-wooden-fruity. Not my thing... Taste is the same... wood, some fruits, sourness. Not my cup of tea. A bit sad for the bottle, so many lambic-geuze lovers would love this one I think. For me its barely drinkeable...

Bottle at Pizzeria Paradiso. Very strong and funky aroma, but somehow enticing.  Drinks like a champagne.  Aroma: cheese, gym shorts, skunky. Appearance: golden, sparkling, frothy. Taste: heavily sour.  Palate: fizzy

375ml, 2009 vintage.  Pours a beautiful golden yellow color with small white head that recessed quickly down to a white ring.  Fantastic aroma!! Pure funk! Piss, vinegar, lemon, citrus, barnyard. Flavor is quite the same but with Largely acidic presence on the palate.  Sour, tart, yet very soft. Coats the palate and lingers for a long time. Delish! Its like a fermented golden shower in my mouth.

Thanks rateyourpoison for sharing. Pours a hazy medium light to medium orange with a small but fluffy white head. Aroma is excellent, sharp unripe citric fruits, lemon zest, a bit of funky and a dusty note as well. Flavor is much the same, sharp and citric, but a bit less aggressive. Dry and tart with a nice easy refreshing finish. Medium body and a softer carbonation. Id like to try a well aged one

12.7oz btl. Pours a hazy light orangish with a fair white head. My first major lambic. Drinkin with some pros. Intense pleasant aroma of citrus. You can smell that tangy sourness. The taste is not as agressivly sour or tart as I woulkd assume based on aroma. Incredible smooth and even.Definitely has a grape and lemon taste. A bit of suddle bitterness. Ill have to come back to this one.

24/09/2010 - 37.5cl @ Opening night Karakterbierfestival Bissegem  
A little cloudy (my bad) ocher to orange beer, little white fine head. Aroma is fresh tart, sour apple, a little fusty. Taste is very acidic, tartness with a bite, refreshing and a little fruity even. Aftertaste has lemony acids at the back of the tongue and a slight grapefruit touch. Damn, this is good stuff...
Sparkling deep orange hazy body and a small fizzy white head. Aroma of basement, yeast,, fruits, apple. Medium bitter and heavy acid. Fresh and crispy.
Cork dated 2008. Sour apple aroma. Light amber hazy appearance. Flavor is a tart green apple with a lemon flavoring. Paired with Uniekaas Reserve cheese. Great Combo.

375ml bottle (Bottled 6/14/09) from La Cave à Bulles in Paris 
Appearance: Pours clear golden with small white head and some lacing 
Aroma: Tart fruits and malts, wet blanket. It smells like a fresh breeze 
Taste: Tart fruits and malts. Some bitterness and dry in the finish 
Very nice and refreshing. Not over the top tartness.

(750 ml bottle @ Ravintola Gloria, Kuopio. Rated @ 11.12.2009.)
Pours a nicely orange, a bit hazy colour with a flat white head. Very sour lemon on the nose. Dry lemonish taste with hints of sweetness. Resembles champagne a lot. Dry finish. Classic gueuze.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2012 2009 bottle.  So this is gueuze??  My first attempt at this crazy belgian concoction.  The smell, I dont wet dog, horse blanket, ass???  Yea, ill go with ass, sweaty, musty, dank ASS.  Amber in color with a tiny white head.  The taste is surprisingly pleasant, and to think that funk near the bottom of the cork made me a little hesitant.  Its light and refreshing with lots of tart green apples, lemon zest, and just a hint of funk.  Its very dry and kinda reminds me of cheap champagne, ehrr, I mean cheap sparkling wine.....

Jan 12 additional rating of Cuvee de Monk Gueze 08.  Clear yellow pour with a white head.  Dry with a medium body and good balance.  Tart with sour funk and mild citrus/lemon notes.  A very nice gueze.  3.8

12.7 oz bottle.  How has it take me so long to get to this beer?  Here we go.  Cork ready "Bottle 2009", so its somewhat fresh gueuze.  The cork was in there tight as a bugger.  Upon taking it out, it expanded so much that there would be absolutely no hope of fitting it back in the bottle.  Hazy orange pour with a descent white head that holds respectably well.  Best lace I have ever seen.  Just a wall of it, as if my glass had a white lining.  Very beautiful balance aroma that reminds me of my childhood for some reason unknown to me. Reminds me of the country.  Sour green apples, typical Cantillon acidity, and a hint of barnyard funk.  The aroma is more balanced and less extreme than most other top notch gueuzes Ive had.  The flavor is impeckable.  Perhaps one of the best gueuzes Ive had.  Not outrageously tart and acidic, but certainly tart and acidic.  Tons of green apples, fresh juicy lemons, and a bit of funk with a bone dry finish.  Not much lacto pedio cheesiness here.  So refreshing.  The mouth feel is OUTSTANDING.  It feels full bodied and lazy, and yet somehow has some very fine carbonation to tickle the throat after swallowing.  I absolutely LOVE how this is not over-carbonated like so many other lambics, gueuzes in particular.  Overall: If there is a heaven, God will most certainly have an eternal supply of this on tap.  I am giving this a 4.9 because I don;t have it in me to give a 5.0.  Maybe after a try it a few more times I will be confident to give it that status.  But, right now, there is no such thing as a 5.0 beer.  This really pushed that perception I hold though.

Golden with a white head - malty aroma with hints of acidity - some malts in the body, but a litle bit overwhelmed by the acidity - long dry acidic finish - a little to sour to really enjoy it, but still good

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2010 37,3cl bottle from Systembolaget.  Bottled 25.09.2009. Poured hazy light orange color with no head. Acid, fruity aroma. Flavor is sour fruits and acidic. Very dry mouthfeel, almost vinegary finish. My first Cantillon, didn´t really know what to get, as I haven´t yet tried many lambics, but a nice surprise. Really enjoyable, I really like sour beers.

37.5 cl bottle bought at the Hogs Back Brewery, bottled 2009. A bright golden amber in colour with a dense cream head and fine carbonation; sharp acidic fruity aroma with apricots and almonds; tart and explosive in the mouth, but with a velvety texture. The acidic fruit is balanced well by the sweetness, apple is the predominant flavour with some woody undertones. The finish is crisp and clean with a hint of grapefruit. An excellent gueuze.

(37.5cl, bottled 2004) Cloudy, orange-golden colour with a creamy short layer. Acidic fruity aroma with notes of apricots, citrus and lemon, accompanied by moderately mouldy and woody notes. Acidic and tart flavour; sour-fruity taste with cellary and woody notes; dry mouthfeel, tart and vinegary finish with a tannic aftertaste. Pleasantly well-aged brew. 13.VII.10

head: none 
colour: clear, egg yellow 
smell: subtle sourness, some bitterness but more like a brut champagne, barley/grains, bit of alcohol 
taste: skunky malty taste, some honey in the mouthfeel , swirled around in the mouth and the sourness hits in, vinegary , end of the drink is somewhat hopy , end is dry and quite bitter ! 
thruly a very nice geuze deffinitly something for me !

Beautiful dark golden coloured beer with a lasting white head. As soon as you open the bottle a almost perfect aroma comes to greet you. Really good gueuze, the sourness in not overwhelming, perfectly balanced. (Corked bottle 37,5cl, bottle date 30 december 2009)

Pours a soft golden color with a small white head that hangs around for a while.  Smells of deep tart oranges, deep earth, andk a rich brett-funk.  The aroma is just wonderful.  The taste is very tart with a deep earthy barn flavor.  Almost reminiscent of a must basement fruit cellar.  Very clean and crisp with a balanced acidity.  A wonderful beer.

375ml bottle poured into a tulip.  Hazy straw/gold color with frothy white head that dissipates.  Aroma of citrus, wheat/hay, barnyard funk, and sourness.  Taste is very sour, makes you pucker.  Crisp light/medium mouthfeel with lively carbonation.  Quenching and very tart, my first experience with Cantillon and I like it!
Aroma of citrus, hay, and some oak. Golden pour with a small white head. Sourness is worderful. Nice gueze. Solid gueze.

Bottle. Finger of pure white, large bubbly head. Hazy straw yellow color. Really wonderful aroma, sour, lightly funky, unripened white grapes, hay, and just a little wild. Acidic taste, tangy and some tartness, sour grapefruit, dry and a little puckering.  Thinner body with subtler carbonation.  Really solid.

Bottle (vintage 2004): Hazy, orangey coloured, small foamy layer; mouldy, cellary nose with lots of sour fruits (lemons, apples) and fruit vinegar; bonedry sour flavour, light to medium bodied; dry vinegarish-fruity finish with a tart aftertaste. Good session beer.....

375cl bottle at home Vintage 2009. This is a great example of a gueuze by cantillon. Its lighter than some of its peers but very refreshing. Champagne carbonation, moderate brett and sour lemons on the taste. Not the most sour of their beers but really drinkable. Great stuff.

Bottled in 1996. Beer geeks tend to cellar bottles to commemorate the birth of their child. When youre the brewer of Cantillon I guess you have other options.

Looks like their standard gueuze, but has a metallic smell to go with the usual funk, oak, and woodsorrel. Tastes like -bal aged lemons with a little white wine. Ever smelled the scum that gets trapped under your fingernails? Thats what the finish tastes like. All aspects of the beer are crystal clear. A remarkably vivid gueuze for its age.

This was assembled with Cantillons "best lambic", according to the Akkurat bartender. As the only difference in label from the Classic Gueuze is a plain sticker that reads "Cuvée de Florian", this may be more of an exercise in psychology than brewing. Either way, any fourteen year old Cantillon product is nothing to sneeze at. This is truly a dynamic fluid.Earlier Rating: 7/31/2010 Total Score: 4.3750 ml of the 03 bottling courtesy of mikey711. Opened on my birthday, an aged gueuze for an aged guy. I wonder which of us has fared better these last seven years.

Were both wanner and funkier than before, but the gueuze is downright fruity. Notes of pear, chords of cider, and an opera of lemon. Age has mellowed us. Its smoother, but still sour. Suaver, but prickly yet. I was going to include something about lambic "gaining wisdom" in the barrels as a parallel to education, but this is getting too complicated.

I wasnt sure if the bottle would be worth opening, whether itd be palatable or in an unsavory state of flux. But its aging gracefully. Hopefully I can follow suit.
user_location: The Court of the Crimson King, California, USA

text: Pours a  cloudy deep orange with little head.  Aroma of barnyard funk, lemon, and brett.  Taste upfront is grainy wheat, then sour green apples and barnyard wood in the middle.  Finishes fairly dry.

Draft, City Beer Store.  A wonderful beer and an excellent take on the style.  This isnt my favorite gueuze in the world, but thats hardly a real complaint.  This beer pours yellow-orange and fairly cloudy with a tight white cap.  Theres a ton of funk, fruit and grain in the nose.  It smells of barnyards, lemons, sour apples, hay, grass and leather.  The taste is dry with a big sour bite.  Ive had a couple bottles of this beer in the past, and the keg seemed a bit tarter, though I have no idea of its age.  The beer tastes like lemons and brett.  Its deep and earthy.  Not as complex as the best of the style but still lots going on.  More importantly, its a pleasure to drink.  I finished my glass much too quickly and would have loved another (for a lower price).

375 ml bottle.  Wish I could figure out the vintage.  Aroma is very tart wit hhints of barnyard and cheese.  color is very pale with a white head an good lacing.  Taste is cheesy on the front with with a very tart finnish with apple-tu[e fruits.  Palate  is very crisp and clean.  Really nice beer.  Beginning to solidify Gueze as my favorite sour style.
Draught at Akkurat. A fresh and fruity gueze with a powerfull sour punch. Very enjoyable and great in the hot wheater.
