Flaske 0,75l. Lys gylden på farge. Litt uklart. Stødig luftig skum. Syrlig fruktig aroma. Smaken likeså. Frisk. Ettersmaken er tørr & fruktig. God tørsteslukker men litt uvariert. Litt bunnfall. KI=4

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2013 Rerate 1/29/13: this is great.  Bumped a point.  Could drink gallons of it.  July 17, 2010:  Passed by this many times, but just now getting into the style (tart, sour, etc).  Bottle from Knightly Spirits at their new location on orange blossom trail.  Murky yellow pour with lots of visible bubbly carbonation.  Aroma of yeast, lemon, funk, apple, grape and wood.  Taste is sweet-ish up front then an nice tart kick - with flavors of tart berries, white grape, vinegar and some oak.  Texture is sharp carbonation - champagne like.  Awesome stuff.
Might be one of the best beers ive ever had, id quite possibly punch my mom for another drank. nice and heavy on the sourness, not too much hay or barnyard, hints of vinnegar. fantastic beer.

2009 bottle (yellow label) sampled 2010.

I simply cant believe I havent rated this one. I would have taken tasting notes! Oh well, plenty of bottles in the cellar. Pretty mellow, at least at this age, in terms of the beloved Cantillon house character. Wood is prominent in nose, some honey, an Orval-like herbalness. Lovely lemon joins the above in the flavors.  Not as aggressive as I might have expected, easy drinking in the sense that its very tasty but not overwhelmingly complex -- perhaps the relative youth of the bottle contributes to that.

Bottled: Oct. 8, 2008

Aroma of grapes and pale malt, flavor is of balsamic vinegar with a slight sweetness to it. Palate is very sticky and very astringent. Still, somehow smooth. Bottle courtesy of FreshBeerCesar at the Back in Miami Tasting.
UPDATED: FEB 8, 2015 This is quite nice.  Pucker-y sour and refreshing. Complex and tart and champagne like. Serving: Bottle

Aroma:Sour lemon and apple in the nose, with a funkiness.

Appearance:Pale golden orange, weak lacing, weak head.

Taste:On first taste, the sourness hits very hard. After that it gets easier to drink, and I start to get some faint citrus.

Palate:This one is harshly astringent on the back of my throat, which is helped by the mild carbonation.

Overall:This 2009 vintage is still kind of harsh, it probably needs a few more years in the bottle.

75cl bottle, 2008 on cork.   Fantastic stuff, with a bracing lemon acidity and smooth funky complexity that is very integrated and round.   The only drawback to this bottle was a moderate level of carbonation that could definitely have been higher.   Lots of brett goodness.   Probably the best overall gueuze house profile that Ive had yet.   I really cant complain at all about it.

tap @ Moeder Lambic
pours golden haze, thin white head.
aroma is acidic - tart and sour, tonic citrus fruits.
flavor , light vinegary palate, acidic, light abv with lingering tartness.
Flavors are more or less very straight forward, plenty of vinegary and sourness while not overpowering the whole profile.
Bottle 37,5 cl. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head and an aroma of unripe grapes and vinegar.  The flavor is sour and tart, with hints of unripe green fruit and citrus. A nice beer.
UPDATED: SEP 21, 2011 Bottiglia comprata dal bezagnino di via maddalena. è un lambic davvero fantastico, dal gusto unico quasi indescrivibile

Bottle. Dark yellow/orange with a fizzy head that quickly fades to a ring. Light fruity aromas, apples, lemons, some oak, dust, a berry like tartness, wheat, and cheesy funk. All sour on the tongue at first, ending in a bittersweet, lingering finish. Lacks a bit of the complexity of the nose. Light bodied, sparkling carbonation. Utterly refreshing and enjoyable, easily drained a 750ml bottle by myself, and could have had several more.

Big sour apple aroma with a little dry pear and light fruit. Appearance is translucent gold with well carbonated body and little head. Flavor matched the nose with characteristic dry champagne finish. Palate was fizzy and bubbly. Wonderful stuff; an under appreciated style in the states.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2011 Big thanks to Hart for sharing this. 1996 Vintage.

A-thin bubbly pure white head, surprisingly carbonated after all these years. Light orange in color with hues of a deep yellow. It is somewhat clear with a cloudiness floating around

S-the nose is very musky up front. Manure, mushrooms, earthy funkiness up front. Light notes of sourness in the back with little tartness.

T-the earthy musk lies up front but is faint and works with the rest of the beer. Sour funk takes over with some candied and sour fruits towards the back. Light hints of bitterness and vinegar at the finish.

M-smooth and creamy with a medium to light body and high carbonation (again a shock how well this is holding up). Crisp and prickly at the back with a dry finish

D-the sour/tartness with all the funk are interesting but make this not as drinkable as Id like. The complexity and big flavors, however, do a really nice job of gaining my interest and the smoothness on the palate do make it inviting.

**********

Monks Cafe Cuvee Version

A-pours a semi cloudy golden orange with a slightly off white head.

S-the nose has notes of funk and leather, nice notes of appricot with some vinegar underneath.

T-notes of funk, salty, dry leather, hints of vinegar, faint touch of appricot with light sourness.

M-medium creamy body, lively carbonation in the back with a dry crisp finish.

D-light on fruits compared to the nose with the salty leathery funk not really working together.  not bad, fairly complex, but falls short of the typical cantillon brew.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2014 375mL bottle, pours hazy orange. Aroma of sour fruits, champagne, barnyard funk and some leather,. Flavour of leather, barnyard funk, medium acidity and moderate tartness. Medium funk and leather quality, with a modest horse blanket quality. Classic gueuze - never get tired of drinking this gem.

Slight pop on the cork.  Initial carbonation. Thin and bubble-less in the glass.  Looks like a light olive oil in color.  Light funk, sweat and mild tart aroma.  Wonderful layers of sweet and sour with lingering tart funk in the taste.  Love it!

Bottle from 16th St. Liquor in West Vancouver. Hazy orange colour, foamy white head. Bitter apricot and apple aroma. Bitter apricot flavour with very bitter finish. Its clearly well crafted, fine to sample but just not my style of preference. Im told that Gueuze is an acquired taste, something more for the beer sophisticate...but thats plain snobbery. Its a very distinct style that falls for me outside my desires.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Absolutely classic. Id probably take Drie Fonteinen Oude Gueuze and Girardin Black by a hair as far as everyday geuzes go though.  I have had many times both bottle and draft, but I finally got around to sitting down and reviewing one.

2009 Vintage opened Summer 2010.
A: Orange-gold body. Just the slightest bit of haze. Fairly large, 3 finger, bubbly head. Good retention and a nice soapy lacing.
S: On first whiff, this has all the barnyard funk of the brightest, mustiest saisons. Lemons, oranges, horsebanket, and a bit of earth. Then you start to sense the tartness and sourness that will come. Then you realize you are drinking a top flight gueuze.
T: Like the nose, there is lots of funk. Sour lemon. Fresh squeezed orange. Light breadyness. General acidic citrus notes. Complex and layered. Very nice.
M: Medium bodied. Lively, but not unrestrained carbonation. Nice zing on the tongue. Good sour/tart finish. I dont find it puckering, but it is an aggressive experience on the tongue.
O: Whenever I have a good gueuze I cant help but say to myself, I would like to wake up every weekend and drink one for breakfast with waffles, whipped cream and fresh fruit. Cantillon is highly regarded for a reason.... this is just one of many.

Since ratebeer lists the Cuvee De Monks also under this listing, my review of that is below (8/4/9/4/19).  One of the joys of living a few blocks from both Monks and the Belgian Cafe (sister bar of Monks)
A: Hazy orange-straw body. Moderate frothy egg-shell white head. Nice collar but no lacing left behind.
S: Sour green apples, acidic lemon blast, juicy orange and grapefruit. General wheat undercurrent and all-around funky goodness.
T: Very nice. Kicks it into a whole new level of funk. Tart lemons, sour green apples and grapes. Orange, grapefruit, and wheat round things out. Good lactic character pairs well with the oaky-earthy vibe.
M: Medium bodied. Exceptionally smooth. Nice lingering tart finish that doesnt distract from all the great flavors that came right before it. Remarkably refreshing.
O: The blend of lambics that Tom and Jean used to make this gueuze is nothing short of exceptional. Even more funky that the classic gueuze, but somehow keeps everything refined and sublime. This is one to track down... just come to Philly.

I tried the Cantillon Gueuze a few times while traveling through Belgium. The first time I had it with dinner (Ham and Kaas Toastie with eggs over easy on top). It was great to pair this beer with food. The smell is pungent and fruity with a dry twinge. The taste is sour, complex and comes in three waves of flavor. First sour, then fruity, then dry with a bitter finish. A really great beer to have with food. 

The second time I had the beer I had it in the Cantillon Brewery. It was as great as I remembered, but would prefer to drink this beer while eating some food. The beer is not quite crisp enough to go it alone. For this I would recommend the Gueuze Giardin. 

Also, if you are in Brussels, you HAVE to go to the brewery. There are no words.

Bottle at Jimmys No. 43 during a Lovullo Tasting Session. Pours a cloudy, honey gold with a modest white head. Grassy aroma, some barnyard, some florals and tartness. Flavor is tart and crisp, with more grass, sunflower and dandelion. (Yes, I know what those plants taste like.) Soft, tiny bubble carbonation. Some lemon and oak notes. Quite acidic in the finish, and dry with more flowers and earth. Nice.

Draft @ Brouwers Sour Fest; had small sample of this and it was just amazing; real deal, authentic lambic with poopy cheese, lemons and raw, earthy sourness; like many Cantillons, this is one I need to save up a little cash and sit down to drink a whole bottle myself 

Original Rating 5/23/08 (Score - 3.8): draft @ brouwers sour fest; cloudy and pale yellow; white head lingers; tart aromas and lots of funk; texture is thin and sweet, sort of like a white wine; flavors of honey, apples and sweet candy; tartness is there, but sweetness melds it nicely; pretty tasty

Poured from a bottle.  My non beer drinking friend told me she thought this beer had gone bad before i took my first sip.  I knew from that moment that this was gonna be something good.  Poured a golden orange with a large white head.  Very funky aroma with some strong lemon aroma, too.  Taste is super acidic.  Nice wheat-like sweetness, and lemon acidity.  Just phenomenal.

Appearance:  Pours a vibrant dark magenta with a gathering of small bubbles around the top of the pour.

Aroma: Raspberry, cranberry, funk, cinnamon and clove. Almost like a spicy holiday punch.

Taste:  Red apple skin, acidic vinegar funk, grape, oak, and metallic notes in no specific order. Very complex.

Mouthfeel:  Medium bodied, medium fiz and slightly juicy.

Overall:  An excellent approachable gueuze.

2009 Bottle? - Thanks JohnGalt1!! - Pours a deep hazy yellow with a frothy white head...aroma is typical Cantillon fare, tannic oak, dusty and lemony tartness, raw grain and acid...flavour follows pretty closely, lite carbonation cuts thru the acid, lemon and oak phenols round out the dominant tastes, with some subtle earthiness as well...finish is some lingering acid...

750ml bottle bought at Vinmonopolet and shared with Finn Arvid during a warm and sunny evening up north. We were sitting outside on the veranda eating stockfish from cod and wolf fish. The beer and the fish paired very well together. The body colour of the Gueuze is cloudy, orange-yellow. One-finger, white head with fine retention. Smell of dry acidity. Taste of tart fruits, some grapefruit shells, cheese and yeast. Tart and sweet in the mouth. Refreshing and cleansing to the palate (Tromsø, 28.05.2010).

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2013 Bottle. Hazy golden with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, wheat, tart and barnyard. Flavour is malt, fruit, wheat, tart, barnyard, little citrus and medium dry.

Draft at MikkellerBar. Hazy orange with white head. Flavour is sour, dry and earthy.
incredibilmente buona.... lho bevuta di recente al del borgo day e non mi ricordavo assolutamente come fosse perchè era molto tempo che non lassaggiavo... il gueuze con la G maiuscola!

MONKS CAFE CUVEE

Enjoyed this blend at Monks Cafe with beerloco, mrs. beerloco, deliriumfest, ms. delirumfest, and dbhog yesterday.

Appearance: The body is closer to straw than golden while the crown and lacing are minimal. Still a solid gueuze look imho.

Smell: Oh baby this one just sings! A touch of spicy meets a symphony of sourness and barnyard. It has its vinegar moments but they dont dominate whatsoever. More of the acidity in the nose comes in more of an extra bitter lemon manner.

Taste: Well refined sums it up. Loads of complexity here but tons of separation as well. Nice blended dose of sourness, citric notes and funk. More like leather than horseblanket.

Mouthfeel: fairly thin and lively carbonation.

Drinkability: This is a fantastic beverage that could serve you well all evening!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-21-2009
Unclear orange, white head. Complex aroma, sweet and sour, light funk, barny. Its not overly sour which makes it nicely drinkable and refreshing.

Bottle (75cl) from Vinmonopolet, Oslo. Bottled 13.2.2009. Inch-thick white head that disappears  fairly quickly. Nice hazy orange/golden colour. Complex aroma - unripe apple, champagne, vinegar, leather, banana, lemon peel, brett yeast. Medium bodied - a bit watery. Average carbonation, refreshing mouthfeel. Nice balance, ends with a grape kernel dryness.

draft at brouwers sourfest. pours a murky dark yellow with a dense and creamy white head. big funky barnyard nose with a little lemon mixed in. creamy medium body, a little on the flat side alas. tangy lemon mid palate, no funk or mineral. puckery and slightly acetic, maybe tannic finish. delicious.

Bottle, 37,5 cl. Golden blonde colour, small white head,lots of carbonation when pouring out. Aroma is sourish, with barley, wheat and krieken. Sour taste (my sourest this far), dry, somewhat sourish, but very refreshening, with a light fruitness,with lime, grapefruit and sour apple. NIce, and enjoy when druk quietly.

a good gueuze. Bottled at Redlight redlight 
sour oh so sour. 
a great bite on the tongue
golden yellow in color
Aroma and color lack for me in this one

super mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm
mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm
Golden colors. Nice nose. Palate of sour lemon. Not too bad but nothing special either.

Bottle at Yellow Brick Pizza. Clear deep gold color with a medium white head. Fruity sourness in the nose with average acidity for the style. Flavor is lemony tartness with a bitter and acidic finish. Pretty good.

375ml bottle thanks to peter 2004 vintage. Pours a clear light gold with white fizzy head. Aroma of nothing but pure, great sourness and a bit of horde blanket. Flavor is the same. Mouth feel is light body with fizzy carbonation. Overall, WOW, Damned GOOD SHIT!

Corked bottle.Pours an average cloudy cheddar orange with a splendid (yes, splendid) aroma of barnyard Sprite, hay, horse blanket and cedar leather.  Flavor is leather, cedar, horse hay, horse blanket, straw, lemon, light lime, and a touch of floral essence.  Tingly on the tongue.  Another superb Cantillon beer.  Yummy.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: bottle thanks to peter.  poured yellow with a white head.  aroma was lemon and burnt popcorn.  flavor was lemon and tart.  medium body with low carbonation.

Thanks Hart for pulling this vintage 1996 out of the cellar and sharing it!

A-Body is a uniform translucent, very hazy golden yellow color. Pours with virtually no head.

S-The nose in this brew is quite interesting. At first all that comes through is a huge barnyard funk-filled with earthiness, mustiness, mossiness...etc...but once the nose has become accustomed to this assault a lot of apple comes through-tart, juicy, and sweet-this comes no where near balancing the funk-but its certainly there.

T-Flavor is pretty interesting as well. Lots of funk comes through across the board but there are accents of apple and some other fruity sweetness. A big lactic sourness-not at all noticeable in the nose comes through for the finish and overpowers the initial flavors.

P-Very low, cask-like carbonation. Body is light weight but very full-quite smooth.

O- What a great opportunity to try this 96 vintage! Lots of sour and funk still hanging around in this brew-it has really held up well. Id like to try this a bit fresher so I can look back and compare the experiences.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-13-2010 22:21:10

37,5 cl bottle at home. Bottled June 2009. Clear amber color, nice but disappering head. Aroma is barnyard, vinager, brett, apple. Flavor is apple, citrus, more than medium sour, a discret sweetness. Fine carbonation. Lovely lambic.
UPDATED: MAR 2, 2013 Light white with slight haze. Powerful fruity aroma with lots of funk. Crisp, white wine flavor with lots of carbonation. Finishes very quick and clean.

375ml bottle. What an unusual beer. Light orange in colour with a small flat head and a lot of bubbles that cling to the side of the glass. Aroma of well fermented sour grapes. Extremely sour, almost like vinegar, yet surprisingly not that unpleasant.

(375ml bottle thanks to peter 2004 vintage) clear gold with light bubbles, very funky nose, cheese, burnt wood. Taste is very tart, vinegar, sour tangerine, cranberries. A medium body thats well carbonated and quite slick.

Thanks to Peter for sharing this beer. 

2004 vinrage. The beer pours a clear yellow color with a white head. The aroma is funk, brett, lemon and tartness. The flavor is tart with some lemon and brett funk. The beer is very dry and really gets the salivary glands going. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

(Bottle at Cantillon)
pours a cloudy orange with wispy white head.
aroma is lemony yeast and slight funk.
flavor is more citrus with some wine and slight vinegar -- too sour (though maybe we were just drinking too many lambics for one day).
light airy body, slightly flat.

An unclear golden-orange beer with a 1 finger head. The aroma was sweet, sour, apples, and funk. The taste was mouth puckering, sour, citrus, apples and almost tastes like a seltzer in the finish with a spritzy mouthfeel.

On tap at Monks (as the Monks Café Cuvee Gueuze).  Served in a nice tumbler, pours a lightly hazy golden amber with a thin creamy white head.  Big sour lemons, cheesy funk, femented bean paste.  Big brett funk hits right up front, and then moves into a nice sour lemon tanginess.  Finishes up with some classic Cantillon vinegar and lingering funk over a dry acid.  Really yummy.
The Gueuze.  Pours an orange, yellow color with lots of life.  Thin foam head.  Has a tarty, fruit, maybe apple, aroma.  Has a crisp, tarty taste.  Very nice gueuze.  Well balanced.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2012 **Cantillon Monks Cafe Cuvee Gueuze**  Really a completely unique blend from the "regular" Cantillon Gueuze.  From a bottle, pours a clear orange gold with a white head that settles to a ring around the glass.  Nose is sharp, citrusy, and really funky.  A lot of lemon and barnyard to this, very sharp.  Not as sour as the regular gueuze, much less puckering.  Lemon, hay, some white vinegar, neatly integrated brett and funk.  Balanced and refined, kind of this lemony, funky burst in the back palate.  Really neat montage of flavors, especially the way it unfolds on the finish.  Awesome.

May 2012 Edit.  The regular Classic Gueuze is better than the Monks Cafe Gueuze.  Several 2006 bottles have been near perfect.  Rich rotted wood, deep musty funk and animal sweat, floral summer meadow.  I have come to find these better than 3 Fonteinen Oude Geuze, taken a complete 180.
Apple and pear nose. Clear amber, thin head. Dry at first, then in an instant powerfully sour. Finishes  less sour with a kiss of sweetness. Apples, persimmons, and stems. Nice transitions.
pours hazy gold with small white head. very tart aroma with vinegar and some fruit. drinks tart with fruits, vinegar, must, barnyard. very puckering.

375 ml bottle from Binnys South Loop (Chicago, IL). Pours a darker muted hazy gold, very heavy carbonation with a bubbly big offwhite head that dies to a small layer, laces minimally. Very carbonated and fizzy. Aromas are a heavy lemony citrus sourness, hay, grass, barnyard, high acidity. Sweet tarts, grapefruit, lemon juice, decent funkiness and brett. Initial is lighter bodied, a spritzy carbonation and lemon sourness and acidity, fairly potent sourness. Moves into grapefruit, grass and straw, barnyard funk, this really is citrus forward with some good brett bite. Acid forward, the beer is sour on the palate, funky and fruity, lemonheads, with a touch of crabapple. Malts come in a bit into, sour wheat and grains, very nice. Finish is sour, lightly funky, and clean with linger sour citrus, crabapple, lemon juice.

This one is an old time classic and I have enyoed it soo many times. I have always avoided serving it to new comers to the lambic world cause I always have thought that it was a pretty agressive gueuze. Appearently I have never rated it - but here goes. 37 cl bottle from Ølbutikken (also availeble rather cheap at Ørsted Ølbar if you want it a night out) Corked and caped like always with Cantillons - pretty cool. Served in the small fluty cantillon glass. Pours a fizzy and sparkling hay yellow with a rather thick foamy crown. The nose is some how artificial. Cleaning spirits and soap long with some urinals, vinegar and sour green apples - I love it ;-). The taste is goo plane sour with a low key finish where the bitter- and sourness gets softened by some sweetness. I find this as I said rather agressive and actually unbalanced compared to other gueuzes. That doesnt change the fact that I really like this beer - its powerfull with a temper and it freshens you up way better than 10 Red Bulls. Grapefruits with a tiny layer of sugar is the impression I get when drinking it. Nice. The palate is medium to light with a low oily feeling,

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2010 Monks Cafe Gueuze, on tap at Monks.  Fizzy orange apperance with a thin head.  Smell is mostly sour citrus notes, grass, and hay, tastes like tart citrus, with a light finish.  Well balanced, a great beer. 8/4/8/5/17 = 4.2

UPDATE: 2001 Bottle at Maxs on Broadway, Casey generously allowed us to try this on May 4th 2010.  Pours a hazy golden yellow with a big head.  Aroma is musty and sour with lots of barnyard, like a humid basement in the middle of the summer.  Taste is perfect, up there with J&J Blauw- sour, grassy, moderately acidic, with all the best flavors of citrus peel without any harsh bitterness.  Incredible, I think theres a reason the rating for this dropped off, none of the newer bottles ive had come close to this.

A delicious blended lambic that is insanely sour, but also surprisingly creamy. 25.4 oz bottle. Cork says bottled in 2007. Pours a clear honey amber with generous carbonation that fades quickly to just a few tiny bubbles. Sour green apples and clean brandy aroma, absent the heavy funkiness of many sours. Some brett pucker in the taste, very dry champagne, white raisins, oak. Lovely.

37.5 cl Bottle. Vintage 2009.

Appearance: Murky golden with tiny, champagne-like bubbles. Easily diminishing white foam.

Aroma: Sour cider vinagar with lemon peel dryness. Low to moderate barnyardy yeast notes.

Flavor: Vivid, lemony-grapefruity bittersweet tartness plays the leading part. Some muscat grapes and a low amount of musty yeast notes hiding under the sour surface.

Mouthfeel/Palate: Quite easy bodied, but the viscoustiy of the yeast makes it really dense. Moderately high carbonation.

Overall Impression: A classic, traditional gueuze with medium to high acidity and remarkably thirst quenching nature. Its still a really great experience to had it freshly. An older vintage of this would be insanely complex. 
A pairing with some aged, moded cheese could be a perfect choice.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2011 375ml bottle from drewbeerme (2005 vintage)...pours a mediocre orange brown with a medium white head which quickly dissipates... Aroma of medium funk and lemony citrus, somewhat earthy funky dry... Flavors of acidic and vinegary lemony aspect to it which didnt seem as composed as the girardin before it.  Perky carbonation but still very good.
Cantillon geueze. Draft at chez moeder... Pours a semi-hazy orange  
brown with a frothy white head.... Big funk and horseblankety nose  
that doesnt show up too much in the flavor...Sharp acidity with a  
nice funk albeit not too assertive. Bit of horseblanket and a mild  
hoppiness to the finish. Very nice and nit sure if Ive had this.
8/4/8/4/15

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2015 [3/10] Bright gold, small white head. Smells of vinegar, unripe fruit and the forest floor. Very champagne-like creamy mouthfeel before a big whack of acid. I cant really pick out flavours because they seem so tightly bound together. I havent had many in this style and its still too much by itself - with some Gorgonzola Im coming around. 
[2/10]2008 bottle. A grower. The cork oozed weirdly after the ugly-stained crown seal came off and this time it looked inviting. Now the acid shock has worn off Im tasting the depth of the sour funk a lot more.  Still very cider vinegar-like, but compelling. [3.7] Tap. Creamy, slightly slippery texture. Less acidicic than previously. Lots of underipe nectarines. Lovely.  [3.9] Averaging score.
Pours cloudy amber with a white head. Aroma is horseblanket, grapefruit, leather, sulfit and barnyard. Flavour is dry, grapefruit, horseblanket, leather and sulfit.

On tap at Monks.  Pours a golden yellow with medium white head.  Aroma is earthy, fruity and a hint of apple.  Taste is nice and sour, very crisp and dry with a very acidic finish to this Lambic.  Very nice.
Draft at Maxs.  Sour funk aroma, hazy yellow body with lasting head.  Overall very sour with hints of citrus with a long tart aftertaste

Golden hazy colour, medium white head.
Acid, green apples, vinegar, yeast, wheat. 
f: Vinegar, yeast, green apples, lemons, 
Smooth yet refreshing.
Does not get more unique and full of character than this.

Orange brown body, almost no head.  Sweet and tart aroma, slight barnyard notes, sweetish nectarine fruit notes.  Aroma is quiet and subdued.  Sour, but comfortably so, subtly complex.  Mouth feel is nice and bubbly with a refreshing feeling.  Hay and some nectarine are present in the flavor.  Finishes out with a tart, dry mouth feel.  A nice subtle lambic, balanced and well done.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2011 The sour smooth funk aroma is so delicious for this gueze that I could smell it all day. The color is dark lemon yellow with a small white head. It is so smooth for a superior gueze which is why I can rate it so high. The perfect sour funk flavor flows down the tongue surprisingly satiating but leaving you yearning for more of that sour flavor.

First of all, lets just get it out there: So far, Im not a huge Lambic fan. Then again, I suspect that were talking about an acquired taste here, so I have decided to buy lambics now and then despite my poor previous experiences - just to give the genre a chance. Ive done this earlier with for example IPAs and coffee stouts, to great success: after a while, I usually "get" the taste; what the beer is trying to say, what it is all about. And usually, one beer turns it all around. Cantillon Gueze might be one such turning points for me. Aside from having an inviting fresh, cloudy orange body and a mellow smell of yeast and grapes, it tastes rather...good. Sour, but refreshing in a lemonade kind of way. It has a very champagne-like dryness but is way more drinkable; perhaps due to the lower ABV. Whoever blended ("geuzed") this one together did an excellent job. Nevertheless, I just cant seem to free myself from the distracting thought that its not really beer Im drinking, but rather some warped form of sparkling white wine. I guess I still have a distance to go before I can truly say I appreciate lambics. Still, Cantillon Gueze has put its foot in the door opening up to the world of lambics - and Im not gonna close it...

"Sparkling, golden-orange body with a thin white cap and spotty lacing coupled with very slow carbonation. Tart lemon and musty citrus scents. Aroma is rounded out with a funky horse barn quality that is very calming to the senses. Extremely drinkable beer, well blended and refreshingly tart without being overly sour. So damn drinkable in fact I enjoyed the entire bottle by myself and still wanted more. A dry and drawn out sourness leads into lemon, orange, and grapefruit flavors followed by musty yeast and sour dough bread. Upfront barnyard funkiness that is well received. This beer kept building and grew more impressive until it was finished."

A: A 750 ml bottle with a bottling date of 2008 shared with the girlfriend. A pour into my Bruery tulip is a burnt orange color with very little head and quite a bit of bubbles.

S: Now this is a funky beverage. A ton of Brett character with a tinge of lactic sourness and oak.

T: As funky as the nose is, thats how sour it is on the tongue. There is a lot of lactic tartness and its very acidic. Theres a bit of lemon flavor and a lot of Brett. On the finish is a fair bit of oak.

M: Surprisingly this is not all that bubbly. Im used to Gueuze being a very bubbly beverage, but I suppose that could be due to a short maturation period (ie. my fault).

D: This is a very, very acidic beer. As a result, its tough to drink a lot of. However, it does taste very good, so its also something you want to drink lots of. A strange dichotomy indeed.

I can only imagine this is what inspired the brewers at Jolly Pumpkin!  Pours a bit deeper than a straw colored yellow with a thin white head.  Nose and flavors match up pretty well.  Sour and tart fruits are most apparent: grapefruit, a bit of lemon and orange, slight taste of vinegar.  Really enjoyable and sour.  These flavors are really growing on me.

Sampled on tap at Maxs Belgian Fest.  Pours a hazy orange amber with zero head.  Tart aroma, grass, funk, lemons, floral.  Flavor is tart, lemony, oranges, lactic acid, grass, flower petals and a little funk.  Lasting tartness.

Pours golden/orange with white head, aroma is full of cheese, horse blanket, funk, and some light fruit.  Taste is huge cheese and tart fruit up front going into acid sourness that lingers throughout.  What an excellent sour, could drink lots of this!

Aroma reminiscent of Brett with barn, grass and funk. Pours between golden and orange in color with less than one finger white head. At first, the Brett dominates the flavor with minimal tart and sour. When continuing through the bottle, the balance between sour, Brett flavors and malt is impeccable. Enjoyed this thoroughly outside on a sunny day.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2011 Ive had this so many times and many different vintages. I will rate the best examples I have had like I have with Drie Fonteinen Geuze. 1998 vintage 750mL courtesy of Puzzl at Cantillon day at Spuytin Duyvil in Brooklyn, NY. It pours a cloudy light orange almost amber with a thin, white head that leaves little lace. Looks like melted butter in the glass. Aroma is funky, sweaty, tangy sour, full of citrus complexity. Taste is watery at first, not too intense, moving to full lactic sourness, lemon yogurt, feet, and finishes very spicy, sweaty, oaky, and massively sour. Really complex if you give it a chance to warm up. Palate is zippy, peppery, lemony sour, full of lactic yogurt. Easy to love. 9/20/2010 8/4/9/5/16=4.21998 vintage 750mL thanks to Turdferguson at RBSG 2011 in Philly. The pour is similar looking to Loerik with a clear to hazy neon peach color and scant white head formation. Nose is completely insane. Just nothing comes close to this one: wild amounts of sour peaches, sweet oranges, fresh grapefruit, and soft sour funk that has no spice or vinegar. Only fresh citrus and unreal amounts of it. Perfect aroma. Taste is leathery and sharp with mild sweat and bitter grapefruit. Excellent, soft, leathery palate. What an insanely amazing treat. If you have ever dreamed about what Loerik tastes like, this is it. They are both 1998 batches and have aged very similarly. Thank you Sam! 6/3/2011 10/4/9/5/18=4.6

375mL bottle, 04-05/05-06/06-07, lot 02/08, bottled 08/08.  Pours a clear gold with a persistent fine creamy ring.  Strong and complex aroma - vinous, fruity, and ripe in particular.  Sharp and heavy tartness all the way through with a little bit of antiseptic, cheese, sweat and a slight bitterness.  Light bodied and quite smooth.

This is called classic for a reason. Pours a golden color, slightly cloudy. Aromas of funk, funk, and more funk. But seriously, cheesey, barnyard funk, some sweet, tart smells as well. Intensely dry, sour and tart. Very quenching. Love it.

Bottle pours a slight hazy gold with a large fizzy white head that quickly disappears. Aroma is heavy in sour apple and lemon, with muted notes of cheese, light barnyard, and some salt.  Flavor shows the same with some added light oak.  The overall body is light-moderate and exceptionally creamy despite its aggressive tartness and acidity.  Apparently im starting to appreciate the style as I find myself hunting these down.

Bursts open when slightly agitated, then pours with plenty of head into a tulip glass, but it dies down quick. Colour is hazy yellow, aroma is lots of lemon and apple, slight pear, very sweet. Taste is very sour throughout, again lots of lemon, some hops, depth of flavour from the different ages of lambics combined. Liked it but didnt think it was an amazing gueuze, but well representing the style.
Bottle at home. Pours a clear orange color with a small quickly dissipating white head. Aroma of blue cheese, leather and some barnyards. Very nice biting sour flavor. Great balanced acidity.
UPDATED: OCT 3, 2010 cheese, amber, hazy, white foam,  medium sourness, medium body, oily feel, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish,

Bottled 20 March 2009. Had at home with goats cheese. Love the lemony funk; smooth not too sharp; easy drinking; dry and peppery; a cheese-rind quality which is perfect with the goats cheese. So drinkable.

75cl bottle, 2003 Vintage, thanks Dickinsonbeer.  Cloudy amber body with small off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, horseblanket, lactic acid, fairly sharp.  Taste is mild sweet, lactic acid, berry fruitiness.  Smooth light-medium body, light acidity, actually a bit creamy.

Sparkling, amber color, faint head; sour aroma of sea salt and crisp fruits; mouthfeel is highly carbonated and refreshing; taste is also citrusy crisp and soul and salty in the finish. Excellent when enjoyed cold - as the beer warms up the saltiness is getting overwhelming and the beer starts to taste almost sweaty.

Pale yellow straw color. Slightly hazy. A small white and rather sparkling head settles quickly into a small ring of lacings.

A fantastic fresh and fine tuned smell. Aromas of both tart and overripe apples, tart berries, fresh hay and some vinegar. Apart from some very faint funky aromas of wet hay and yeast, this could have been the smell of a fine cider or a sparkling white wine.

The taste is just as fresh and tart as the smell. Tart apples, lemon peel with semi-sweet nuances, fresh hay, grass and some yeast. Wheat and malted barley. A very balanced character throughout the experience. In the finish, the tartness develops into a more sharp sour taste with a prominent character of lemon. The finish is dry and has notes of barrel, lemon pits, some phenols, a minimal grassy bitterness and everlasting sour notes. The funkiness is very restrained, but becomes present every now and then in the form of wet hay.

Medium body with a dry finish. The carbonation is very lively and sparkling. Overall, the beer has a very sparkling character, again like a cider or like a sparkling white wine.

This is a world class gueuze, with a rich and refreshing character. Very easy to drink and surely a "fine wine of the beer world".

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

My first experience with sour beers... figured this classic would be a good introduction. Bottled in October 2007. Pours a nice gold color with a small white head that fades quick. Nose reminds me of white wine with some light fruits and grapes and a light sweetness, but also some musty, earthy scents. In the mouth it leads with the same white wine character, quickly giving way to an intense sourness with sour apples, sour grapes, some lemon tartness, some vinegar and mustiness and a light spicy character. An interesting beer, but not something I could get into.

(Sample Date: 8/1/2009   Source:Other)   Earthy peach pear fruitiness and spicy hop aroma. Mostly clear light straw. Earthy moderately sour and acetic flavor. Hop bite in flavor and some earthy funk. Finish is quite dry and slightly puckering. Light Brett character.

750 ml. bottle from Greens on Ponce De Leon. Label is different from the ones shown i.e. a silhouetted man drinking in a chair, with a mustard yellow background. Nice looking Gueuze. Dark haze orange in color. Translucent appearance. Head is fluffy at first, and then fades away to a small wispy head. Lemon tart aroma, with a nice funky aroma. This is a very pungent brew I must say. Light citrus fruit aroma is coming through, along with a nice charred wood aroma. This a very nice complex and nuanced aroma. At first the beer is sour/tart lemon flavor, and then kind of changes direction to a sweet citrus fruit and wood flavor. Nice funk flavor showing up. This Gueuze doesnt have as much depth as others that I have tried, but this beer is still quite amazing. Very smooth, and not too carbonated. Nice sour flavor just lingers.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2010 [37.5cl Jan. 2009 bottle, North Bar - Leeds, 01/01/10] Brought in the new year with this, one of my favourites. The nose is a complex funky affair with notes of citrus fruits, farmyards and vinegar. Taste is sour but not puckeringly so, with more fruits and hay. Lively carbonation. An addictive, refreshing beer, and a great way to start the decade.

At Brouwers Big Wood 2009. "Classic". Honey wheat pour with thin head. Fresh sharp nose, huge rush of tart sour that explodes and fades to dry bitter finish. Lots of wheat, touch of honey. Creamy but knives out, explosive.

Bottle: Poured a hazy yellow to orange with a fluffy thin white head, some jello like attributes as well. Aroma is a mix of an old moldy sock, rotten eggs, and earthy, barnyard. The taste is shrieking lashes to the tongue of sour vinegary mess. Just when I thought I was starting to get why people enjoy sours this one deflates all hopes of my will changing towards them.

Cloudy, light yellow beer with weak white head. Aroma is strongly sour, some overfermented fruits and cider. Flavour is fermented and fruity, white wine and very sour and long. Pleasant to drink, carbonation with body are nicely balanced. Weird, pleasant, dry, refreshning to drink, and I want some more...

Bottle from at least 2 years ago.  Pour is hazy golden color with small white head.  Aroma is really funky.  Lots of barnyard, funk, grass, hay, horse, a touch of leather, and cobwebs.  Flavor is quite tart up front with a faint sweetness and lots of funk to follow.  Really quite good and really well balanced.  Its tart for sure, but not out of round.  I really like this and will have to put a few more in the cellar.

Pours dark orange and lively with thin head quickly disappearing. Very strong lactic nose with zesty notes and faint sulphur odour. Very sharp yoghurt tast of lambic, plus fruit and caramel sweetness. From bottle

Pours hazy bright orange with a medium white head that fades. Aroma- skunk, funk, yeast, orange, lemon, vinegar, sour berries, honey, sweaty blanket, peach, overall very zesty and pungeant at the same time. Taste is brutally sour but deliciously painful, kind of like having a small cut and pouring alcohol on it just to feel the burn.  Medium light body medium carbonation.

On tap at Brouwers Big Wood 09. Light honey-colored pour, with a small head. Very dusty / funky - bitter citrus and some grassy notes, but it has a good sweet note, too - like the Girardin with a little touch of honey. Really vibrant, and extremely refreshing. Just great.

2007 vintage, bottle acquired via trade, thanks Jeff. Pours a clear apricot color with a medium white head that goes down to some small bubbles. The aroma just seeps out; sweet yeasty and woody sourness. The flavor is great; tart, funky gueuze flavors, sweet sugars, loads of straw and light puckering sourness. Very drinkable and nice. Funky and tart in the finish. I think Im really starting to appreciate these beers. Nice.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2011 Pours a golden orange color with minimal amount of white head. Has a slightly acidic smell to it will just a little funk. Has  a slightly citrus taste that goes slightly sour with a little bit of tartness at the finish.

Its about time for this one.  One of those beers Ive been meaning to try for a long long time and even had a bottle in stock but for some reason never opened it up until now.  Pours a golden-orange color with a pretty nice initial white head with a little left on top.  Wonderful funky aroma with cherry and berry notes.  Flavors are moderately tart with berries and the additon of sour apples and a little oak in there.  A touch dry and despite being tart it still comes across as a bit light.  Silky controlled sour palate.  This is clearly well put together.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2010 An exceptional beer. Mesmerising. Poured on tap at the Rake on Friday before a gig. Lovely sense of cherries; floral notes and a sour dry finish. Aroma of cherries very strong on the nose. A wonderful beer. I really love the conditioning on this beer on tap. It brings out the flavour so well. A lovely foamy head too. Thank you the Rake for giving me Cantillon on tap. A mind blowing experience.

Bottle.  Its blond with a slight fading line of head.  The aroma is pleasantly funky, tart with apple, white grape, musk, damp wood, light grass, dandelion.  Crisp mouthfeel with bubbles on the tongue; medium to light body.  There is plenty of depth in the flavour; its tart with more apple and lots of ripe, slightly sweet dark blue grapes, a hint of brett.  Finishes long.  Wonderful!

Effervescent, lively, clear copper with orange hints, small white head, somewhat viscous... Aroma or funky barnyard, lemon, leather, new shoes, just a touch of fruitiness... Flavor is quite funky, lemon, leather.... Very lively, almost champagnelike, dry finish, a touch thin in the finish... World Class,

Golden orange body, darker than i usually see in gueuze, thin to no head, aroma is brett barn funk, initial flavor is lemon juice tart acid, body is thin, sourness all the way through, finish is tart, bitters are very mild, no malt body  or residual grain flavors at all, very thin body, acidic tartness, very very mild oak, cantillion is always a treat

Bottle 37cl. A yellow-orange beer with a head that disappeard quickly. The smell is nice and fruity. Taste is very dry, very bitter without any fruit flavour. A bit vinegar but the main taste is mushroom and bitterness. Quite strange for a gueuse.

tle. Pouts a lovely golden with slight hazing. Slight white head initially. Disappears pretty quickly. Aromas of lemon, vinegar, some sourness and a little funk. Lambic plavours of leather and horseblanket. A little lemon and some green apple. Finish is very dry with some acid and funk on the finish. Wonderfully balanced. Great beer.

Transparent yellow/orange body with a fizzy white head.  Lots of bubbles in this one, leaving a thin layer of white over the beer.  Smell is well on the funky side.  Taste is lemon citrus and rather dry.  Good stuff, my first introduction to Cantillon and Im definitely excited to try more!

This was the first Gueze i had tried. It pours a meadium cloudy golden colour with a sexy white head. The aroma is outrageously complex. Lemon Citrus, old oak, slightly savoury, a touch of elderflower, almost barnyard, leather, a touch smokey, mild vanilla. I could smell this all day long.

Tastes of lemon citrus, sour, tart, high acidity, clean, great length, dry finish. Very refreshing, Not being that familar with Gueuze i did not expect it to taste quite like that from what i smelt of the nose. 

This beer reminds me of a riesling of gruner vetliner.

I think im addicted.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2015 Bottled: 22Feb08 Rated: 05Nov09
Golden pour with a small head.
Aroma is very fruity, with tart gooseberries, elderflower and unripe raspberries along with funky and goaty notes hiding underneath. Mild oaky notes show themselves later on.
Upon tasting, first of all Ive gotta say, this is pretty damn tart, like biting into a lemon through the skin and all. A fair whack of acidity, with little in the way of balancing sweetness. Once youve got used to it some oak and funk comes through. Not bad after a couple of sips!
Light body and carbonation - I would have liked it to be more lively!
Bottle. Pours an unclear yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is horsecover, acidic and tart. The flavor is sour and acidic. The palate is dry. Overall a good geueze, but not my favoritetype.
Sweet, lemony citrus peel aroma.  Hazy golden.  Wood with tart, bitter/citrus flavor like lemon peel.  Smooth texture.

Bottled May 2008.  Smells of fresh juicy lemon, oak and nettle.  Very slight haze to the gold, strong effervescence, beautiful.  So damn tasty!  Refreshing, tart, gentle, serene, grapefruit, morning dew and relaxing.

Bottled 375ml. It pours a murky copper beer with a small head. Wonderful, deeply inviting and strong aroma of lemon peel, oak, vinegar, cork, leather and barnyard. Great taste with hints of vinegar, vanilla, lemon peel, rhubarb, oak, dandelion and hops. Great acidity. Long, very dry finish which is reminiscent of lemon peel and rhubarb. A wonderful beer.

Golden pour with a small white head that sticks around the edges. Clean, acidic aroma. Sour apple, apricot maybe? The flavor so acidic that the exact nature of the fruit flavors is hard to discern, but it tastes good regardless. Pretty mild actually, not terribly bitter. Possibly some white grape as well. Good beer,

After the beer was served in the glass there was found a lasting quantity not wall adhesive white foam collar which was fine and evenly of structure. The beer also contained no carbonic acid in the glass. 

The beer has a clear orange color and a light acid taste. The after tast of the beer is light hoppy bitter with a fruity touch. This beer smells to light acid.

The appearance was cloudy, orange color. Almosy no foam.

Tart with some hints of smoke and yeast. A significantly sour taste, yet not so brutal that the beer was not possible to drink. Also some lemon and apples. Easy on the tongue and a very dry sense of fluid. Reminds about champagne, but with the big difference that it is tastier.
Bottle. Sharp aroma with citus, fruit and yeast. Golden yellow colour with small white head. Very sour flavour with a bitter grapefruitlike finish. The bitter finish is very characteristic.

white head, golden yellow tinge. Very highley carbed, aroma of citrus, fresh apples and acidic with underlying classic brettanomyces/medicinal. Light, acidic feel. Extremely sharp and very very tart, and sour. Nice and refreshing but complex enough to keep you interested.

Bottle, 37,5 cl, labelled with "100% Lambic Bio". A yellow-golden beer iwth only a small white head, that lasts however towards the end. The aroma is very sour and sharp in the nose. Some fruity notes are attached, some yeast is also noticeable. The beer tastes similar to the smell: very sour, with fruity notes, yeasty and ending dry, which makes this a refreshing beer. A good gueuze anyway, but I already drunk better ones.

375ml Bottle. Pours slightly hazy golden orange with a bubbly white head that quickly shrinks to a ring around the top. Aroma is earthy and yeasty and also has notes of apple, lemon and apricot. Flavour is quite sour and has a strong suggestion of citric acid but is otherwise very similar to the aroma. Crisp, carbonated, refreshing mouthfeel with a lingering sour finish, this is a great beer and, in my limited experience, a good example of the style.
Bottle. Golden orange colour with a thin white head. Fruity and acidic aroma. The flavour is very sour, vinegar and citric fruits. Dry and medium-bodied. Very refreshing brew.
Pours a thin, lasting ring of white head with a golden, slightly hazy head.  Funky, fruity, floral, acidic aroma.  Juicy, sour, biting flavor.  Dry, hint of sour on the finish.

Draught at Hilpeä Hauki, Helsinki, Finland. Clear pale orange/golden colour with tiny white head. Sour fruity aroma with some vinegar. Flavour is extremely sour with some cidery side and fermented fruits. Excellent but not for every day.

This is definately a polarising style. I enjoyed it, but can’t imagine drinking it regularly. The wild yeast is just so funky and over the top, it turns an average 5% ale in to a taste experiment. Crazy, dry and brimming with ecetricity. Very nice, just not something that I would personally seach out again at this point in time. Quite pricey too.

375 ml Bottle.
Lovely clear amber color with a medium, bubbly head, which lasted longer than expected. Aroma of citrus, lemon, a bit of barnyard, some lactic aspect, 
Very dry and quite sour. Creamy, lemony, but crisp and clean. Very nice. Fruitiness is subdued compared to the dusty dryness, though it got a bit more estery after the yeast was added. A bit of funk, and a long bitter finish containing a bit of lemon peel. Very straightforward gauze, dry as a bone, perfect mouthfeel, amazing with some ripe cheese and other foods. Perfectly clean and crisp.
2008 big bottle pours clear dull gold with fair layer of off white head. Great typical cheesy funky guezey goodness. Tart semi-dry finish.  Exactly what I would want from this style.
2008 bottle, golden orange color with dusty cherry, earthy pepper aroma, flavors are very tasty apricots, lemon, wild grape, champagne, not overly sour with a well balanced dry finish
A nose of wild yeast, lemon and hay. Taste is balanced, not overly sour, and contains cucumber, wood and lime. This is a good and very drinkable gueuze, but its not very complex. Aging maybe?
Aroma is typical gueuze, hints of grass, soil and citrus.  Apperance is amber with small white head. Flavor is souer, sweet and frutiy.

Bottle 75cl.
Rated this some while ago, but only wrote down the scores and not the taste/aroma or anything, rather unfortunate. 
Anyway I remember it to be a nice gueuze, next time I have it Ill remember to re-rate it.
Smells sweet, citrusy and sour. Clear yellow color, very little carbonation or head. Refreshing, light and super tart. Enjoyable.

Bottle 0,75 %, recent vintage. Hazy hayish yellow with fizzy white head. Nose is funky, earthy, sour, dont really know what, maybe some vinegar. Would propably need to re-rate for better characteristics. Flavor is sour for sure, but not citric sour and is actually quite easy to drink. Theres no vinegar qualities in flavor and mostly just earthy, a bit yeasty and surprisingly neutral, flat flavor. Think of your basic white bread with nothing on it. A bit empty, but not bad by any means. Im curious for more.

Bottled 375ml. -as Cantillon Gueuze 100% Lambic Bio. Hazy golden coloured, medium sized white head, sharp sauerkraut nose. Slight acidic and tart taste with dry vinegary finish. Highly refreshing and well balanced gueuze.

750 bottle... Pours with not much of a head, nice golden color... aroma is really funky with some sweetness underneath... Flavor is about the sourest Ive ever tasted, and not in a good way (but thats just me). Palate is dry and puckering... Over the top sour, not a fan of the style though

Bottle  Pours a cloudy amber gold with a thin off white head which leaves quickly.  Makes some nice lacing rings.  Has a good aroma of bubble gum, floral, and peach.  Has a light carbonation.  The flavor is sour, and spicy.  Areal nice mix.  The texture is differnt not thin and not thck.  Has a medium body.  The finish is good with a decent aftertaste.  This is not my choice of beers but it has a lot of good points.

[2008] Bottle...  Poured a vibrant, hazy golden with a bubbly, white head.  Tart, yeast and acidic nose.  Spicy, grainy and funky yeast control the flavor profile.  Dry and tart of course, with a citrus and lactic character, and a earthy, dirt-like malt and yeast finish.

Bottle courtesy of and shared with ogivlado who brought it from Belgium (huge thanks!) Poured a lovely hazy golden body with a big thick white head that went away at a medium pace. Wild yeast forms the nose, dusty too, some herbal notes. The taste is kinda light but refreshing which is a huge plus for me. Spicy funkiness, acidity, dryness, some herbal notes again (is that hop?!). Light acidic (maybe even lemony) end. Surprisingly balanced, lovely.

Bottle, sat outside a villa in France on my honeymoon. Woo woo woo. Orange with pretty much nowt up top. Low carbonation, very drinkable though. Quite neckable for a geuze. Quite mellow on the tart and bitterness, still there but not so much that you cant pour it down if youre that way inclined. I am. Delicate the gentleman below me said, Ill go with that. Fruity, tasty, enjoyable but just no real wow factor.

Sour peach vinegar nose with floral notes.  Clear deep orangey gold color, small head.  Orange rind soaked in lemon vinegar taste, bright and tart.  Very light carbonation, medium almost creamy body, tart lemony finish.  A very nice beer, the floral and citrus characteristics makes for a very delicate taste.  This could really benefit from more carbonation, it seemed a little too flat.

Bottle shared at Where the Wild Beers Are NYC 2009: Hazy deep golden with a dense off white film of head. Very buggy aroma- cobweb, molded wood, leather and that sharp citric acidity known to Cantillon. Crisp, citric acidity with leathery funk, tannic white oak peppery character, cheese rind and lactic presence. Bone dry and funky. A classic staple Guezue.

At a tasting, many, many, many thanks DSG for this amazing experience. Murky light orange with a little head, aromas of mustard, sour apples, peach, aprict and an aromatic skunkiness enveloping all.  Flavours of unripe summer fruits amazingly strong sourness which feels almost salty, sea salty. The yeast character is quite noticable, aftertaste is quite short. Extremely intriguing, hope for more.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 At the sour tasting, part B, pours yellow hazy with a small head, strong acidity with lemon, barnyard, wine and floral notes, flavor is sour and burning with lemon, hay, green tea, herbs and moderate bitterness, zesty, medium to full bodied, great 8/3/8/3/4/14[3.7]
Shared at a tasting, thanks Dadi for this One, pours orange to yellow slightly hazy with a huge head, aroma of cheese, olives, grass, horse skin, leather and winey acidity, flavor is sour and zesty with pickle juice, peach and fresh leaves, tender bitterness, full bodied, outstanding
At a tasting, thanks Shachar, last drops of the bottle, apricot juice like with a small head, aroma of white wine, brett, great sharp acidity, fresh leaves and some berry notes, flavor of wood, fresh soil, horse skin, sweat with a great acidity, almost full bodied, excellent
Thanks DSG, this is totally something I have never tried. Pours orange with a medium off-white head, high complexity in the aroma, great acidity and floral notes, powerful funky tones of soaked leafs, fresh forest mushrooms and citrus peel, pleasant and enjoyable, flavor is very lemony with some olives, fruit sourness and french cheese, zesty and almost full bodied. Since it is my first gueuze it is quite hard to judge but the sourness in this one should be balanced with some sweetness (at least as long as I acquire the taste). 8/4/7/4/15/[3.8]

Bottle Date: 05/28/2008
Yellow/Orange Body, thin white head.  Mild bret aroma.  Very lightly carbonated. Tart acidic citrus flavor with a mild sour aftertaste.

Bottle at (very near 55 degree) in a widemouth chalice. Pours a nice light gold with all kinds of stuff going on in the nose. Im getting fruit / tart / and some brett-style yeast-ish nose. 

Nice sour with a bite at the back of the cheeks. Sour fruit like peach, apple, and some tart grapes. Nice refreshing sour! Not an everyday drinker, mind you... but find me a Gueuze that is.

Location: 12,7 oz bottle from State Line, 8/18/09 (Labeled Classic Gueze - Bottled in 2009)  Not sure Ive ever seen a beer with a cork under the cap, unusual...


Aroma: Sour fruits, apple, lemon, some funky yeast, tart and fruity

Appearance: Clear golden-orange color, with a fizzy white head that dissipates quickly

Flavor: Similar to the nose, sour, tart, fruit, yeast

Palate: Light and dry

Overall Impression:
My first Gueze, so maybe I just dont have the taste for these that others do, but I wasnt overly impressed.  It is an interesting beer, and I will try be sure to try this style again, but as of now, I must say, Im not sure its quite what I had hoped for.  I believe I have another Gueze in my bottle reserve, so Ill have to see if that one changes my mind.
As for this beer, I found it to be a bit light of body, and overly sour, limiting my enjoyment of it a bit.  Light, dry, funky, sour, and fruity.  Look, Ill give it plenty of credit for its complexity, and it is not a bad drink by any means, but it is not going to enter my upper-tier/favorite list.  On the other hand, Im curious enough by the raves this style receives to try a few more before I do anything as drastic as dismiss it.

Bottle - 2007. The aroma is sour, some flour, a lot of yeast and some fruit, very refreshing. The head is small, white and foamy-fizzy with a short duration. The body is orange. The taste started quite sour, then it gets softer. The finish is even softer which is a surprise because of the sour aroma. It tasted also light salty. The body is light, dry and with a lively carbonation. The finish is light astringent. A very nice gueuze, rather mild and not that sour.
cloudy golden pour, no head, little carbonation...nose is full of grapes and grass... flavor is very tart grapes, perfect amount of bite to this one

2008 Bottle of the classic. Pours a clear gold with some medium bubbles and almost no head. Nose is full of lemon, barrel, funky yeast. Flavors are nice yeast funk, pleasant lemon sweet-tarts, dry Chardonnay, a little bit salty. Mouth is perfectly carbonated and smooth. Nothing wrong with this guy.

Bottle at Brouwers cafe in Seattle. Huge nose; tight acidic cider apples, lots of extra-sweaty, funky horseblanket, almost salty its so funky. and yet a soft, curranty vein courses through the heart of this beer, keeping it delicate despite all the surrounding funkiness. So funky its almost too much, yet at the same time not enough. Palate is salty, sweaty horseblanket, soured fruit and brett. Lean, tight, dry, and intimidating, but wonderful!
Bottle pours a hazy golden with a white head. Sour fruity aroma. Flavor is sour apple, grape, with a bit of woodiness.

Bottled at Dembis in Mestreech. Color is hazy, orange. The most orange colored beer Ive ever seen. foamy, thing head, disappears quickly. Nose is apple, apricot and lime. Flavour is dominated by apricot, apple, lime with a long lasting bitter finish. I really like this one.

On draft at Monks as Cantillon Monks Cafe Gueuze.  Pours a hazy gold with beautiful white frothy head. Orange, grapefruit and cherry aroma. Nice sour flavor with touch of honey sweetness and a light bitter finish. Well balanced and good mouthfeel.
Labeled 100% Gueuze. Hazy orange color. Hay, citrus, apple, and a pleasant touch of wood. One of my favorite lambics for sure!

Bottle at Cantillon in Brussels.  Great hazy golden color with a white head.  Aroma is malt, funk, sour apples and other tart fruits.  Flavor is more of the same with citrus notes and a little sweetness on the finish.  Sharp palate with medium body.  A great example of the style.

RBESG Sheffield 2009, day 3, The Fringe, Manchester. 375ml Bottle. Hazy golden colour, white head. Aroma of sour apples, wheat, light sweet candy, a bit of fruits. Flavour is very sour at first, soft wheat, light sweetness comes through later on. Medium bodied. Way too sour for me, but you can tell this is a quality brew.

Bottle at Zly casy, Prague. This one knocked my head back, a champagne disguised as a beer? - Aroma of fruits , strawberry, and lemon. Taste is more of the same, really nice mouthfeel, high carbonation, and a tasting sensation.
750mL at Red Monk. Not bad for my first sour. Smelled like dirty gym socks. Flavor was very lemony, but not too harsh. Had some lambics since this one and this has been my favorite so far.

Bottle 1996 courtesy of Jakob.
Cloudy yellow with no head. 
It has a very dry and very dusty aroma with notes of citrus, mainly grape and wood.  
Flavour is dry grape, dust and wood, with a long acidic after taste. 
Very interesting but a little to dusty for me.
When fresh it is good but mild, a bit simple yet refreshing with allot of lemon. Older bottles is a harcore acid attack with extreme concentrated funky barnyard notes, hay, lemon and wood.

Sampled at Cantillon Brewery museum: was not prepared from the extreme sour taste.  Amber with almost no head.  Yeasty, earthy arouma.  Puckering sour taste which lasted, a unique almost champagne-like beer.  Certainly unique and worth a try.

Classic Gueuze 750ml bottle - golden hued, fizzy,tiny bubbles that dont last. Tart, sour apples and earthy, mustiness on the nose and on the palette. Dry with little aftertaste and bitterness. I enjoyed this beer a lot.

Labeled Classic Gueuze with guy tipping back on chair. 750mL at Red Monk. Some vomit in the aroma. Rather sour. Lots of gym socks. Earthy. Lots of citrus in the finish. Finish has some dust and wine too. Palate is nice, not harsh at all.

Bottle at Den Dyver restaurant in Bruges (recommended). My first geuze and certainly not what I am used to!. A hazy yellow beer with a small white head but lively carbonation. Tart sour lemony aromas with a very sour dry taste that was off-putting at first but it became more pleasurable as I went down the glass. I then realised that this beer was perfectly matched with the pickled herrings I had chosen as one of the starters on the fixed price menu. An acquired taste for sure but I shall be investigating further.
hazy yellow/golden pour.  tart notes nice fruit character, green grapes.  acidic int he mouth, tart but still retains a lot of fruit flavors. vinegar abounds.

Hazy yellow pour with a foamy white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is quite tart and funky, with sour fruit notes. Flavor is extremely sour, but I dont consider it assaulting. Very tart and very dry, with lots of vinegar. Im still learning to enjoy this style, but I do appreciate it, and this seems to be quite the solid lambic.

375ml bottle - Pours straw yellow with a small white head. Smells of sour fruit--apple, perhaps? Theres some pear in there, too, and its nice and musty. Initially it seems like a simple flavor, but once you really get in there, you realize theres a lot going on. Flavor is just as youd expect--tart and dry with very little aftertaste. Its so sour that it almost borders on bitter, like youre tasting something that isnt ripened yet. Its medium-bodied and smooth--dry and with just enough carbonation. This is only my second Cantillon, but I really appreciate their complexity.

Source:  375 mL bottle at the Rake.  2008. Glass: Tumbler. Appearance: Cloudy gold pour with a one finger white head.  Aroma:  Sour cherries and wheat with a hint of vinegar. Flavor: Wheat, sour cherries and a hint of green apples. Palate:  Light body with bubbly carbonation.Overall:  A new experience for me.  My first Cantillon beer.  Very sour and different, but very good.

375ml bottle 
5.0% ABV 
I tried this beer on June 18,2009 at "The Beer Bistro" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer was bottled on February 22, 2008.....and if stored in a cool dry place would keep until 2030 (it said so on the bottle).  The beer poured a cloudy gold colour with a very thin white head.  The aroma was sour cherries and apples with a little bit of malt.  The mouthfeel was dry, very tart, highly carbonated, and medium bodied.  The flavour was tart apples, and some graininess.  Very enjoyable.

The pour was a slightly hazy golden-copper color with a short, fizzy white head and lots of effervescence.  The aroma was tart citrus, earth, mild funk.  The flavor is well balanced between tart lemon, light funk and some residual sweetness.  Tart, but not so much that thats all you notice.  The body is thin, dry and refreshing.

Pours a lemony yellow with a very slight almost non-existent off-white head.  Fermented white grapes and lemons on the nose with accompanied by a similar flavor.  Tartness is at the forefront on the tongue with a dry lemon biscuit finish.  Very refreshing, enjoyed on a humid summer evening.
pours a hazy golden orange with a small white head.  some nice lemony tartness with a bready dry citric finish.  great beer on a humid day like today.  very refreshing and satisfying.

2006 bottled. Served at celler temp (55F) Light straw yellow pour with a white head. Sour funky aroma hits you as you pop the cork, pour the beer, and as I write this. The head dissapated quickly. The sour flavor is prominent. I also tasted a s;ight sweetness and then my mouth went dry. The sourness really hits the side of my tongue. I also get the tartness. The bottle says it is aged in oak barrels,but I dont get that flavor. My first gueuze, and not my last.
Had on tap as "Cantillon Monks Café Gueuze".  From the tap poured a hazy straw color, with a tart flavor and finish.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, Brussels. Slight hazy golden with a small egg white head. Musty yet floral and citric aroma. The flavour is fruity, dry, sour and earthy.

750ml bottle.  Pours a glowing golden orange with a tiny off white ring.  Nose was full of Brett with some tart citrus as well.  Slight tartness in the initial taste with some great apple and tart citrus flavors.  Finishes kind of of sweet and sour and drying on the palate.

labeled "Cantillon Monks Café Gueuze". 5/27/09 notes:  on tap, Monks Café in Philly.  This was the real winner tonight.  This beer was refreshing, challenging and tasty . . . what more could you want from a beer?  Appears dark gold with a small white head.  Aroma is initially plasticky sour, but soon turns towards vinegar and tart citrus peel.  Flavor has a well-rounded sourness, with green orange citrus, funk, and grapefruit.  Fruit is evident without ever being fruity-sweet, if that even makes sense.  Perhaps its more the peel that lends flavor characteristics.  This is delicious.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2015 Bottle at Blind Tiger. First gueuze i have tried. was quite tart but a nice change to all of the stouts and barrel aged stouts of the night.

Fixing this travesty.

On tap at Monks in Philly, MrBendo was brave enough to let me swig on his. Murky gold with a white head. This baby is sweet and tart citrus, horseblanket and assorted barnyardy notes. Not over the top sour, comes off more tart. Gets rather dry late. Niiiice...

Brewed in Belgium....... Courtesy of AFI96, thanks Waylo. Pours a lite orange color with a super thin white head. Aroma of orange peels, citrus, straw and sour notes. The taste is of earth, straw, citrus and a fabulous sour kick. The mouthfeel is very thin in body and finishes with a nice dry sourness. I am also very satisfied with this gueuze from Cantillon.

375 ml bottle shared with BeerGestapo. Clear golden pour with a thin and quickly diminishing head. Smells of barnyard, lemon, straw, leather, and glue. The flavor had a good deal of woodiness to it with some funk, lemon, straw, and pencil shavings. Creates a good deal of dryness at the back of the mouth. Not as sour as some gueuzes. Very tasty.

375 ml bottle. Slightly hazy golden yellow colour, thin and quickly disappearing white head. The aroma is very interesting: sour, fruity, with some vinegar, notes of apples and a strong presence of citrus. The flavour is aggressively sour and vinegar-like. Like in the aroma, citrus fruits, especially lemon, are strongly present in the flavour, along with other sour and fermented fruits. The flavour stays lingering in the mouth for quite a while after swallowing. My first experience of a "real" lambic, and a very positive one, at that.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2010 [Bottle] Pours a hazy gold with a small, effervescent white head. Aroma suggests quite a bit more tartness and acidity than the 3F version. There is slight funkiness, somewhat diminished from the 3F. Plenty of sharp citrusy notes remain. Flavor has a ton of lactic sourness, light to moderate brett expression, medium to full mouthfeel, prickly acidity, and a touch of citrus fruits. If I could meld Cantillons sourness with 3Fs funkiness, I would be a very happy camper, but both beers are fantastic in their own right.

One noticeable thing about this beer was is lambic like qualities. In the handful of Gueze (girz) that Ive had the opportunity to try, this one came across a bit more tart then i anticipated, nonetheless a really nice brew. Big bright eyed orange colour, little HAZE with an enormous creamy top. Plenty of sour fruit on the nose (der). Lemon and something that resembled mangoe. Watermelon, lemon and some cranberry notes in this extremely fruit forward beer. A delightful beer from highly respected brewery. Thanks again John :)"

Golden with a champagne fizz.

Sour crab apples and lightly woody yeast.  Hints of alcohol and rich honey.

Crisp and light on the tongue. The sour hit comes with the swallow.  Sherbert-like bubbles.  Maybe hints of light liquorice in the finish.

Dainty bubbles let it dance over the tongue.

Not awful but maybe a shade too vinegary deep in the throat.

Bottle pours hazy yellow with little carbonation.  Tart aroma with some yeast.  Slight tartness in the initial taste with some great apple and some lemon and lime.  Slight funk.  Smooth finish.  Nice gueze.

The perfect gueuze. Pours a hazy yellow. Dusty, earthy, sour, citrusy lemony, wild nose. Flavor is enamel melting sour. Kick you in the face sour. Citrus, refreshing, vinegar, tart fruits. Insane complexity. This is the bench mark for all other gueuze.

75cl Vintage 2003.  Pours a hazy golden bronze body with a thin white head.  Lots of tart lemon and a sweeter balsamic reduction and a light honey body to finish.  Delicious and worth its weight in gold.  Cant wait to try the 1999 vintage bottles.
12.7oz bottle pours hazy pale yellow, aroma is earthy, musty, fruity, instantly sour upon the tongue, fruit, complex flavors. first real experience with a gueze and loving every minute.

Yes, it is the classic gueuze from the heart of Bruxelles. Ive tasted it two years ago, but i can remember it... It has an amber body with a minimal off white head. Aroma of a light vinegar, some barnyard, fruits like citruses, grapefruit, some vinous character. Complex flavor with tart, sourish Brettanomyces, nice fruits like lemon and grapefruit. Minimal carbonation. Longlong aftertaste of tartness and fruits.

Pours a hazy gold with quick dissipation of the head. Nose is BRILLIANT bandaids fermented in a subtle brine of apples both ripe and freshly green and sour, plus a clean chlorine water along with what I can only describe as angels tears. Sour and fresh fruits on the tongue, this is definitely subtler than some of its counterparts. Maybe more refined. Taste experience goes on for a good 20+ seconds, probably closer to 30. To think I paid 8.50 for a plastic cup of piss at the ballpark, when I could have watched the game on TV and drank one of these for the same price. Its a mystery life, baby.

Bottle at Cantillon.  First experience with classic Lambic brewing.  Different than any other beer I have had before.  Flat, golden yellow, and drinks more like a fine wine than a beer.  Enjoyable but different.

Bottle August 2008. Golden color with a white head. Aroma is tarty with a bit of a smokey sent to it. Flavor is quite complex, definite tartness and bitterness. Brings out a nice citrus with a bit of apples. Quite enjoyable.

Bottle from La Cave à Bulles (Paris)- September 08. 
Appearance: Golden color. Little to medium head and white.
Aroma: wheaty and tart. Reminicences of green grapes, green apples, quince and prickly pear.
Flavor: wheaty, wild yeasty and sour. Citric fruitiness similar to quince, chardonays grapes, green apples and lemon. Light bicarbonates note. 
Palate: Light body and medium carbonation.
Remark: Refreshing beer with a nice and multidimentional fruity sourness.

light honey and funk .. . yellow, and friendly bubbles .. . sour, and crazy delicious .. . insanity drinkability .. . some lemon..good stuff 
..
im glad im not taking your brewery tour! im a coors man, silver bullet!-Joe

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2014 Bottle split with Thi and vi.  Pours a hazy orange, no head , light white lacing. Slight sediment. Mouthfeel is perfect with notes of tart fruit, funk, putrid wood and dirty earth. This gueuze is awesome.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2010 (bottle) pours a cloudy golden colour with a little white foam. aroma of oak, mild vinegar, lemons and fermented apples, lavender, honey and a touch of grain. flavour is fermented plums, grain, sweet bread, light barnyard and a few blades of grass. medium-bodied with moderate carbonation and a dry, lightly sour finish. wonderfully refreshing!

Bottle shared with NickTheElder at the Back Abbey.  Pours a murky golden yellow with a thin white film.  Aroma is is extremely funky, musty, oaky and pungent without much else to it, just the way I like it.  Flavor starts extremely acidic and citrusy, all of the stuff in the aroma is there but not nearly as much as I expected.  Finishes very clean and dry.  Palate is sharp and light.  Starts out really strong but dies off a bit.  Still damn good.

Bottle pour.This was my first Gueuze and it was amazing.It tasted like nothing I have ever had in a beer,180 degrees opposite.It smelled of lemons and citrus maybe a little oak too.Sour taste that left me wanting another sip.I loved the flavor,not too overwhelming but strong.My overall impression is I love this and cant wait to try more lambics!

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2009 My bottle was labeled Classic Gueuze Ale Aged In Oak Barrels. It has an orange yellow label and its the shadow of an old dude falling back off his chair while downing some gueuze. Full-size green bottle, about a quart; with a stopper that was really tuff to remove. I eventually got it out but now there is some cork in my brew; oh well, adds to the personality. Label is quite interesting but does not interest me as much as the rose de grambius label. Good fresh barn aroma with no ill olfactory and it comes across as farmy or something.  Tho farmy, the aroma is not overwhelming. Pour is swirling hazy amber, good show.  For a mental picture, think about grapefruit soda that was tinted with iced tea. Tremendous sour tart taste bud impact. Quite a lovely experience. Words cannot do justice for the realness of these lambics. Puckering at times; makes its acerbic position well. Would love to drink this kind of beer all the time instead of that IPA or impy stout stuff. Dee-lish!  This is one impressive beer, it rocks!  Cannot detect any real bitterness in there except perhaps a touch of fresh squeezed grapefruit juice in the finish, very acceptable. Does not get tiring to the taste buds even thru this whole bottle. Cannot detect any alcohol in this brew. $12 at Vintage estates in Ohio. Again, these lambics are REAL beers. S7L5F5T8O18
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
UPDATED: JUL 9, 2011 375ml bottle from IPB. Bottled Dec 2010.

Appearance : Clear pale amber with a small white head that doesnt last long.

Aroma : Great citrusy tartness with a hint acetic. Nice acidity and sourness. Nice malt. Classic. Light barnyard.

Taste : Great tartness with nice sourness. Light acetic character leading to a tart and oaky finish. Light acetic notes on finish.

Palate : Soft carbonation. 

Overall : Very tasty. Awesome tartness with nice oak and great tart finish. Very close to 3 Font but I think I still prefer the Girardin. Gets better as it warms up. Really awesome stuff.

37.5cl bottle at Lautre Oeil. Crystal clear yellow. After pouring the remaining quarter inch of the bottle, it became hazy. Very small head that goes away fast. Aroma is acidic, apples and sourness. Bottle date oct 06. It basically tasted like concentrated citron juice. I always liked that taste. Could be a bit more complex. It became less effervecent at the end and a bit less tasty as it tempered. It was a remarquable experience ! Rating #58 
Re-rate 090708 Sample at brewery. More balanced than what I remembered. No change in rating. 090903 8,4,8,17; 4.1

At Cantillon, Brussels, Belgium.
Taster from bottle, 050309.
Golden wih no head. Aroma is fruity and dry. Flavor is balanced sourness with berries and ripe fruit

Date: 5/3/9
Beer info: Bottled in 750ml corked bottle 5.0% abv BB September 2027

Sampling notes:
Served lightly chilled in pilsner glass.
Capped and corked, nice pop upon opening. Clean golden apple-juice coloured body, very fine beading leading up to a small but dense white collar.
Sharp aroma, pungent, deeply complex. Plenty of tart apple cider upfront, vinegar undertones, hay, grapefruit pith, light horse character, faint floral notes.
Lean body, soft lively carbonation prickles the tongue, high acidity yet somehow not as brutal as its framboise/kriek counterparts.
Vinegar seems to hit home straight off, cider vinegar possibly, definately has that crisp new season granny smith acid bite about it. Citrus works its way in, grapefruit is obvious but lemon and lime seem somehow present, hint of honey and hay sweetens and otherwise bonedry mouthful.
