(the bottle says Cantillon Gueuze Bio) Hazy yellow. Earthy, sourish iron-like aroma and flavor. Finishes, and leaves me, with a really dry palate.

Not as intnese as I was expecting but veryy nice.  I found the intense sourness to be well balanced with light fruity notes like lemons, grapefruit and light cherry, and some moderate woddyness.  Caroline says it tastes like stomach acid and there is a touch of that but i still really like this one and will definetly come back too it.

Cloudy, golden hue, with very low carbonation.  Complex, somewhat musty aroma with black cherries and lemon.  Tart nose, leads to an acidic, very sour finish.  Tartness is almost difficult to overcome.  One of the harshest Gueze's you're likely to find, but the beer is extremely complex and deep.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2004 Cork date of 2001, Sampled November 2004
Pours a brilliantly clear copper orange color.  It is topped by a frothy light tan head, that is held up by a light but persistent carbonation.  Ah, the aroma is simply magnificent.  In the nose I get notes of lemon, grapefruit, an astringent woodiness, musty leather, vinegar, citric acid, a hint of ripe cheese, lemon zest, and hay.

The beer is creamy up front, but quickly moves to a bracing hit of sharp acidity that lingers through to the finish.  I get lots of notes of grapefruit up front, and the finish has an austere dry, mouth coating, tannic astringency which helps to balance the citrus character.  It is almost like chewing on a old piece of formerly musty but now dry leather, ooh how pleasant that sounds.

It is amazing how much one can get used to things, I hardly even notice the acidity in a traditional Lambic anymore.
Sampled 2001This one is quite sour smelling.  There is lots of acidity (one of the harder gueuzes out there) and tastes of grapefruit.  Well carbonated and has a woody finish, that is accompanied by a light bitterness.  Though quite sour this beer still manages to be well balanced with lots of different things going on.  A good traditional example of this style.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2006 An almost nonexistent, wispy white head reveals the near-still qualities of this hazy, golden-straw hued brew.  Upon assaulting the glass with my nose for the first time, I quickly realized that this is the absolute dankest, most pungent and vivid gueuze Ive ever encountered.  Yes, even barnyard-laden Hanssens Oude Gueuze would cry in shame before this monstrosity.  Simply put, this is an Imperial level of funk.  (True believers, ignore that last comment.)  Across the boardpungent barnyard, medicinal esters, band-aid phenols, sweat, dust, vinegar...all of the nasties are present in full force.  Beyond that, softer elements of hay and alfalfa provide a nimble base while hints of lemon rind tug the aroma about.  As it warms, a concentrated doughy center emerges along with a semi-bright overripe tropical fruit element.  The flavor is assertively sour throughout, owing much of that to pervasive grapefruit, lemon and lime citric tones.  Dough and straw are displayed at the forefront with the funky stuff coming on strong from mid-palate to the end of the aggressively dry and lengthy finish.  Despite the level of funktitude, there is quite a malt body present, and it seems to grow as the beer warms.  The body is rather reedy and carbonation minimal (there looked to be a bit of cork leakage), so, combined with the still oily texture the total mouthfeel comes off much closer to an unblended lambic rather than a traditional gueuze.  I dont think Ive ever referred to a beer as a food-beer before (similar to a food-wine), but this might be one for the books.  The thought of most any shellfish is terrifically appealing at this point, alas, I have none.  Still, this one goes down the gullet to mark my acceptance into a Masters program...so, cheers to me!  75cL bottle, Burgundy glass, 1996 vintage.  I dont enter ratings based on terribly old vintages (hence, my original numbers stand for now) but, for anyone that actually reads this and happens upon a 1996 bottle, Id give it a 10/4/9/4/19=4.6Old rating (8/4/8/4/17=4.1): 75 cL bottle, wine glass.  Fifth bottling, October 2000.  Deep, rich orange body is cloudy from tiny, dense particles.  Large, dense, frothy head diminishes quickly.  Powerful horseblanket / barnyard yeast aroma.  Grainy malts.  Some vinegar and dry wine aromas are present.  Lonts of delicious stench abounds.  Moderately sweet start turns into moderately acidic, puckeringly sour finish of long duration.  The mouthfeel is wonderfully smooth.  The body is medium and oily.  Seems to be slightly less complex than Hannsens.  The bottom line is: theres lots of beautiful nastiness here.

Musty, sour fruit, barnyard, wet blanket aromas, the gamut of Gueuze! Cloudy golden, with a tiny creamy head. Tart, earthy, musty again, fruit flavours, tastes like a farm field smells. Intense complexity, layered sensations on the tongue, sour, tart, acidic, dry. Magnificent, this must be how Gueuze is meant to taste!

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2004 Bottled in 2001. A fantastic brew. Mature horseblanket and leather aroma. Notes of cobwebs and sour green apples. This is the most sour Gueuze I've tried. Extremely complex and nice.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2006 1994... Poured a cloudy golden color with small, sticky, white lacing on the glass.   Aroma of barnyard, brett, sweet malts, mildew, and green apples.  Taste was subdued sour, honey sweetness, green apples.  Long sour finish, really nice.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2012 This is a highly complex and well made gueuze.  Beautiful fruity aroma and tart complex taste.  Brettanomyces clearly evident with the complex horse and leather flavors.  A great beer with food.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2010 2010-08-09. Hazy golden yellow body with a small foamy white head. 3+ Aroma is milder than I recall from previous samples, lemon seeds, musty dusty malt, it gains complexity as you go on. 7+ Flavour is sharply sour at first but subsequent sips are far more drinkable. Dramatically so in comparison to my past encounters with this beer. Lemon seed and a moderate sourness by Cantillon standards. Very light fun. Lemon accents in the finish are refreshing at times. 7+ Average palate. I found this surprisingly easy to drink for a beer I have previously described as pickle juice. Have I mastered my nemesis, or has it slowly beaten me into submission?!? 7+/3+/7+/3/16+ = 3.6+ Bottle at Cantillon, BrusselsSeptember 2006 Brewnosers Meeting, bottle at least a year old. Hazy yellow body with a small white head. Massively funky aroma, horseblanket. Powerfully sour acidity up front hints at lemons. Grows on me a little bit as the glass goes on, but I wouldnt want a whole bottle to my self. Average palate, effervescent. I have had a few unrated samples over the years, but this is slowly growing on me, but it is still a far cry from the complexity and drinkability of others. 6+/3/6+/3/14 - 3.3  
July 2003 Girlfriend brought me back a bottle from the brewery. Golden color,no head. Sour in the aroma and the aftertaste which lingers. Girlfriend really likes it. Me, not so much. Definitely a classic and worth trying though. 4/3/4/3/10 - 2.4

Smelled like pee, was yellow. I am supposed to drink this??? I have heard that drinking pee has health benefits but I'll never be an advocate of that! Nor do I forsee myself ever becoming an advocate of this beer, way too feral. This is the stuff left over in the kitchen scraps bucket after a week! And you're not going to change my mind in a hurry.

Bottled in 2002.  I had this side-by-side as an apertif with the Mort Subite gueuze, and while the comparison was favorable to the Cantillon, these were moderately different experiences.  For one, the Cantillon poured murkier and lighter in color.  While my glass kept a trace of head, and overall seemed to have more carbonation supporting it, it also flattened out a bit as well.  The aroma was more pure--barnyard and mold, for sure, with an ugly attractiveness.  Funny, I found similarly musty, cellared aromas tonight with the wine I had at dinner, one a 1998 St. Veran Chanson and another a 1996 Ochoa Tempranillo Garnache Tinot, though both of those didn't continue the vein into their dry flavors.  My friend Simon, with whom I have shared many good beers (from Abbaye des Rocs to Traquair Jacobite Ale) was, for the first time, repulsed by this beer.  "Strained through an old man's socks" was his expression.  Nevertheless, I didn't find the sourness and acidity so difficult to adjust to (compared to the Cantillon Kriek).  Nice strains of citric, very fresh lemon juice flavors.  Late bitterness under the jowels seemed to mark the end of the progression of senses and flavors that I got with each sip.  By the end, this was delightfully drinkable.

2001: Pours an effervescent golden with a pillowy white head.  Thick cheesy barnyard aroma with detectable maltiness leads into a fizzy and strongly acidic body with a dry warming finish.  Some faint cheesy flavor is present, but the body is way too tart and sour for enjoyment.  Perhaps by bottle was bad.  Caution, may induce heartburn...

For those who have visited a pulp and paper mill, there is a distinctive paper mill aroma and flavour to this beer.  Anyone living near a mill would recognize the smell.  Somehow it works very well.  It is a woody, resiny kind of character.  The beer is dark golden in colour with a frothy white head.  Medium-high carbonation levels.  Very acidic, leaving a sensation in your mouth as though you had drank way too much the night before and your body has disagreed with your perception of it's alcohol limits.  Still it is an intensely interesting beer that is thirst quenching.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2004 Slightly cloudy golden. Very interesting aroma--sour apples, men's room, vomit. Somehow it all ends up smelling kind of nice. Taste follows aroma with an addition earthy element. A very strong tartness like unsweetened lemon juice. My intro to gueuze and I love it! [and I love it even more one year later]

Bottled: Yellow coloured. Unfiltered. Light white head. Aroma is sour and earthy. Is balanced by a ligth sweetness. Very sour delicious flavour, that ends in bittersweetness. Balanced and wellmade beer. Happy to have 2  of these left in the cellar.

The aroma is powerful acidic, sweet and slightly sour. The color is an unclear orange and it has no head. The flavor is very sour, a bit acidic, prickling but at the same time flat. It ends on a acidic dryness with no metallic notes as other gueuzes. An OK gueuze - without being great.

My first Cantillon tasted in the Highlands of Scotland, go figure! Hazy orange/apricot color, the head disappeared in 2 seconds.  The aroma is of wood, stable, sweat, leather, cheese, a bit medicinal at times.  The beer wasn't as sour and tart as I thought it would be.  Still pretty damn sour.  The leathery caracter comes out throughout all the acidity and sourness.  There are too many things going on for me to describe.  Very challenging and complex.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2005 Rerate:  Orange colour, almost no head, very cloudy.  Quite lacing. Citrus aroma.  A complex sour flavour, with fruit-sparkles.  Quite long finish.  Fizzy Carbonation. I just love this kind of gueuzes.

Ever driven by a dairy farm?  You know that intense, putrid, musty cow manure smell that makes you gag?  This beer has a lot of that in the aroma and flavor.  I like moderate lambics, with the sour/barnyard notes in balance with malt or fruit or whatever (something half-way between this and Lindemans).  This beer is definitely at the extreme end of the sour/barnyard range.    I've tried several of Cantillon's styles, and they all have the same signature barnyard/sour/enteric/horsey characteristics. The sample I had was relatively young - 2001 - but I still think this beer is best left to the true lambic enthusiasts, as opposed to people like me who like a mild one now and again.  I realize this is a classic, if extreme, example of the style, so my rating reflects my personal tastes to a strong degree.

45-50 deg in a tumbler.  Cork indicates 2001 bottling, sampled May 2003.

Light bit of yeast sediment provides a mild cloudiness in this golden yellow beer, with a small foamy white head of modest lacing.

Pungent aroma of sour fruit (cherries mainly), some malt.  Some light fruit (peach) but not very distinguished.  

Notably tart flavor, with some astringency in the finish and mild chest warming.  Fruitiness less apparent in the mouth than in the nose.  Could use a tad more carbonation, becomes borderline cloying, losing the refreshing edge this beer should have.

Another nice lambic in my recent round of samplings of the style, but not as complex as the best ones I've found so far.  Perhaps its relative youth hinders further complexity.
Very enjoyable pouring experience, lots of foam... great aroma, pretty sour taste.

I uncorked the bottle, and noticed that the cork said "Bottled in 1993." It poured like a fresh beer, scant white head above cloudy amber beer. Aroma of definitive Lambic basement funk. More funk and strong sourness in the flavor, also some wood barrel notes. Finish of mouth-drying sourness, with a wee bit of hop bitterness. My friend who doesn't drink beer liked this. Perfect for #400!

Bottle conditioned. Gold colour, good initial fluffy white head and sparkling condition. That typical barnyard lambic nose with hints of metallic tartness, lemony citric tartness in the mouth and a quite subdued finish which is dry but nowhere near as bone dry as some Cantillon beers.

Bottle from the October 1999 vintage.  A copper color with a tornado of fine rising bubbles up the middle of the glass that fuels the white foamy head.  Sour, smooth, wood, citrus, apples, and lemon releases a bang onto the palate.  Dry with a nice tart aftertaste.

[bottle] Golden colour, cloudy appereance, nice head. Cheesy aroma. The flavour is obviously dominated by sourness, but it has also a great complexity with fruity traces (apple citrus and peach). Really pleasant, a great gueuze.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2004 Oh man...On draught and from the bottle.  Both samples are fairly similar.  Very beautiful hazy deep golden coloured liquor.  Foamy dense white head.  Nose is fantastic: barnyard, leather, stale cheddar, vinegar, rubber bads and bandaids.  This is by far one of the best brews I have yet to encounter.  Starts nice and perky.  Assertive sourness all the way through.  Creamy texture. Every sip yields to another flavor, unexplainably complex.  I dont want to spoil it, so get this one for yourself!  This is great to steam mussels in...And to bath in for that matter.

On tap. Very enjoyable, reminscent of the Petrus Aged Ale with the vinous dry oak and strong tartness. Light gold, small, appetising head in a thin tulip glass. Musty, slightly citrusy and malty in the nose, mouth-filling sour tartness up front, earthy, almost bubblegum sweetness on the sides of the tongue. Hard pear and apple. Long finish. One of those beers that has flavors developing for many seconds after the sip. You may need more than one of these as it gets better and better as you adjust to the strong flavors.
Very "unbeer" like.  Very light golden straw like color.  Very tart flavor - unsweetened fruit.  Very wine-like.  One of the best Gueuzes I've had on tap (Monk's in Philly).
This is the sourest Gueuze I have had yet. Many people don't like this one, I can imagine why. But I liked it, at last a beer wich is not sweet at all.

What the hell have I come too when I smell horse blanket, horses, and Horse poo in my beer and smile?  How come I enjoy the face pucking tartness and the taste of circus peanuts in the finish, this is a beer right?  I mean it is yellow/gold and it dose have a head, I certainly looks like a beer.  Why does it taste like a riesling with only with more grapeskins?  WTF is this? Cream? Lemon grass? VITINIM C PILLS?!?  I give up, Im out like the fat kid in dodgeball.  Just leave me alone....
Picked this one up after the Chicago real ale festival, fuckin great time!  Anyway, a good gueuze.  It was tart with a slight winey taste, lots of foam with the pour.
Im not to happy on lambics, good thing I got a big bottle of chimay, anywho this one was odd, not for me.

Yet another brew enjoyed at obrien's.  A light orange color with hints of yellow. A great mixture of fruit flavors. Not sour, but tart. A good lambic which i am much appreciative of having the pleasure to sample.

Another one of the many great beers i was privileged to sample from Tom Nickel's personal collection at Obriens last night. This one poured a mighty cloudy orangey/peach color with a very minimal orangey head. The aroms was entrancingly lovely with orange, peach, lemon, and yeastiness becoming apparent. The taste offered an acidic battle of the tongue and cheek. Flavors of lemon and peach dominate with acidic citrus creating a beautiful souring finish. A bit rougher in the finish than the Oud Beersel tried earlier, but still this was a very respectible brew. Oak flavors also begin to come out as this one warms. Very carbonated and extremely tart...nicely done indeed.

Bottled 1999. Slightly hazy golden color with bubbles that explodes in the glass to a tall fluffy near white head that despeckles the glass is in disipates.  The CO2 left in the glass burned the nose as I went to smell the aroma.   True sweet sour aroma which only gets better as it warms. Champagne qualities.  The more I  drink the more I like this.  Mild farm yeast start followed by fruity citirc flavors that are quite intense. Light maltiness that emerges and than get taken back by the sourness. Rather sticky in the finish, but still clean and crisp in the finish.
Going mostly off memory here, but I distinctly remember not liking as much as Lindemans Gueuze.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2008 Dec, 2002 Oaky cider with grapefruit juice. Packed with flavour. Interestingly tastes better when the whole bottle is finished. [3.1]
Jan, 2008 Served at the brewery. Soft and woody with a pleasant tang suggesting grapefruit. Pleasant and refreshing. [3.3]

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2003 OK, I'm new to this and mostly I have rated beers that I like or love.  This is the first one that I truly hated.  My eyes and nose screamed unneutered male cat piss.  My mouth said "I have no first hand experience with cat piss, male or otherwise, but no basis for contracting nose or eyes.  Go to the sink right now."  Lots of stuff going on here  barnyard, diaper, mating cats  and not a bit of it pleasant.  Wow.  And this was really expensive and really hard to get.  Just wow.  I give it points for being interesting and complex, but not a single point for being pleasurable. // rerated May 2003.  Several months in the basement seems to have helped enormously.  Helped the beer, I mean.  Now seems better balanced, more sour lemony than sour ammoniac.  Much nicer to drink, still complex and interesting, but still far from being a favorite!
sour, stinkous and scary - not as subtle as girardin though. very juicy and dry.
Quaffable, like good lemonade. I tasted citrus, apples, a little bit of oak and mustyness. Not a style for everyone, but I love this stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2003 fabulous. tart sour but far from one dimensional. hazy amber color, funky horsey aroma.
many complexities here - a hinbt of apples some herbs.
perfect carbonation and refreshing.
the champagne of beers.
the funk in this beer may scare off some but its worth it.

1996: Sour with a must nose.  Extremely sour taste of lemon. The end was smooth and there wasnt quite as much edge as the newer versions.  1999: A more floral nose and sour taste.  2000: Tone of lemon with soap water.  Not nearly as good as the older versions.  The rating here is a combination of the three years.

3.7 rating is for 1996 VERSION:  Hazy and bright gold with the musty basement smell that gives hint to its age. Complex start with pepper and bready notes. The end is that supreme sourness that also proves it has aged well and is ready to drink. Another superb gueuze.  
1999 Version: Seemingly more dry and complex as compared to the 2000. Some sour notes still wayward.
OCTOBER 2000 VERSION:  Soapy nose and taste, many flavors- especially the sour ones- seem out of order and in your face. Id still rate this young gueuze about a 2.7 or 2.8.

Initially smells like a clogged drain, but the aroma got much better through the glass. Cloudy gold color but no head to speak of. Puckering sour of course with a chalky finish. Did we get a bad bottle? Was complex and unusual for sure, but unpleasant at times – and I really like Gueuze beer (see my rating for Oud Beersel for example).

Same as the Cantillon Kriek I am not sure if this bottle got infected. Had 2001 bottle and also it smelled like rotten eggs. After a while it began to smell fruity and citrus-y. Had a nice dusty yellow orange body with a little head. Sour with a bitter finish. After it sat a while it also hat initials of grapefruits. Long medium aftertaste. As we got this and the Cantillon Kriek at the same store, it might be the storage that didnt do well on these beers. Definetly have to try it again.

Holy crap, this blows my mind. From the rusty cap onward this has a most amazing outlandish smell--salty, sour, yeasty, and a disturbing touch of diarrhea. Pours a lovely golden color with a huge but quickly diminishing head. 

I really cant wrap my mind around the complicated flavor of this thing. It is so sour that it makes my eyes water and nearly makes me wretch. But theres something there that I want to get to the bottom of--a maltiness hiding in there, and a spicy flavor reminiscent of pot. A totally new experience for me.
I didnt like this gueuze all that much. Lindemans was much more palatable.
golden hazy appearance.  quite tart, very spritzy.  quite refreshing even at room temp.  very complex
Had at the brewery and in the bottle.  Very nice and tart.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2004 My eyes shoot out of my head when I saw the incredible score for this beer. Highly overrated. When I drunk this one, my thought was that the other Lambica I've had were not that bad. Aroma is perhaps the most striking and confusing of this one. Not knowing what to think about it, I gave the aroma the benefit of the doubt. Taste is horrible sour. 
Rerate 22-08-'04. Well times change. So does taste. The new bio version. Very oaky aroma, winey and fruity (apple and citrus). Hazy, orange-yellow coloured with a firm white lasting head. Taste is tart, moderate sweet, oaky. Very well balanced. Tartness evolves towards finish. Quite dry brew. (Offcourse....)

Orange golden color, with a very quick disappearing head. Oaky aroma, sour gueuze. Sour taste, as the girardin. IMO the Boon Gueuze was better than those oak-conditioned gueuzes as Girardin and Cantillon.
Blond, clear if you pour carefully. Big head quickly dissappearing. Aroma: Rubber wheels and mould in the normal sour geuze aroma. Complex aroma. Very sour.

Faint hazy gold with huge rapidly dissipating head. Super sour, wet rubber, faint fruit and  mouldy old cellar yeast aroma. Medium sour start. Softer middle and milder bitter finish. I cant see whats so good about this one and cant find the complexities that others seem to find. I think the De Cam I had last night had more character about it than this one.  Also the bottle smells of human excrement.
Not that Im fond of Gueuzes but I always think you must know where you want to talk about.  So I had to change a little bit of my opinion and i can appreciate this style more and more.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2005 1999 edition: a 2002 experience...gueuzantic off-white head...it shrank before my eyes to mere normality...brilliant cloudy orange loveliness..aroma hinted at spiciness with lotz of tart sourness...Extreme perfection in the language of sour!!! I kid you not..I am fricken dumbfoundingly retarded...this is lambicness at its best!! the sourness meets you with subtle love and wraps itself around your brain and seduces you till you explode...If youve never had a lambic, dont make this your first, because the rest will be downhill!!

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2007 375mL bottle. Head is initially large, fizzy, white, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy medium yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly to moderately yeasty (barnyard, cobwebs), lightly malty (toasted grain), with notes of sour apple, lemons, and cask wood. Flavor is lightly to moderately sweet, heavily acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, fizzy carbonation, moderately astringent. Less aromatically interesting than Drie Fonteinen, sure, but this has always been Cantillons best product IMHO. Good stuff.
Sour, moreso than the Lindemans.  One dimensional?  I didnt see the complexity other speak of.  Not bad, but for experienced drinkers only - who know what theyre getting into.  Weird seeping cork.
Only my 2nd lambic, and I think Im a fan of the style. Has a very dry woodiness, metallic flavor, but it is truly yummy. Fruity, mouth-puckeringly sour.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 9, 2003 Refreshingly dry.  All of the soury goodness to be expected of a good lambic.  The more of it I drink, the more I notice and the more I love.

Oddly, there was some liquid underneath the cap but over the cork, but the cork and the beer seemed to be fine. Pours with a huge head, which appears almost alive as it recedes, with lots of rising carbonation, light orange body, slightly hazy. Sour, cidery nose, typical of the gueuzes Ive sampled. Very woody flavor; the sourness is more subdued that the Lindemans examples Ive tried. Nonetheless, it is very tart, and quite dry. Halfway through the glass, the sour fruit flavors asserted themselves over the woodiness, making this the best lambic Ive tried so far.

Attacks your palte, with its heavy acidity and sourness. Bone dry, refreshing, complex, very good. Was also interesting to see the differences between this and the Girardin Gueze (which i had next to it). To me the Girardin was slightly more complex, and it also had more acidic sourness than the Cantillon. The cantillon however was more bone dry, and less tart.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2006 Perfect equilibrium of green apples, earthy yeast, lemon, grapefruit and leaves...Not too agressive for a Cantillon, nicely carbonated, refreshingly tart, a fabulously serene and confident example...Lemon juice lingers without the barnyardy funkiness though...Nicely placed yeast cushion and a smooth wheat presence make for a creamy summer quencher and a classy evening sipper...A delectable, quintessential gueuze...

A 10-year-old, 1996 bottle proved to be in absolute stellar shape, making me raise my score even more...Balance of all elements, tartness, dryness, sweetness, perfect carbonation, sustaining malt structure, and all in all, the perfect gueuze, period...Age Cantillon Gueuze, you really wont regret it...

Outside of bottle in area around cap was covered in a black crusty liquid that smelled of soy sauce. Cork was still in good condition though. When cork was about halfway out we heard the hissing and rushed it over to the sink to protect the floor. Right about the time I got it to the sink the cork shot out (attached to one of those big cork screws with the handles to make it easier to get the cork out) and it hit the ceiling.Im just glad I had it aimed straight up and not towards my head or the window. The head was huge but faded quickly and unevenly. The scoring in the bottom of the glass left a thick column of tiny bubbles coming from the bottom of the glass so the head never completely went away. The smell was a bit musty with an aroma I have noticed with many darker belgian ales, especially the La Trappe Dubbel and Quadrupel. I had thought that until recently it was candy sugar, but Im not sure if thats what it is since I dont know if its used in this beer. In the flavor, the beginning is some maltiness, mustiness and a few other flavors I dont recognize. The finish is sour and a fairly lengthy aftertaste is also sour. The sourness is the largest part of the flavor profile but not as much as I had been led to believe. A very interesting experience, but it was a little difficult to drink more than a glass.
Incredibly complex sourness in the malt and a perfect finish. My favorite geuze. Drinking it in the brewery may have added to that, but still a world class beer.

Drank with the family in the brewery while watching the World Cup. Fabulous, you can almost taste the history and funkiness of the brewery while you drink the beer. As they told us, Beer is meant to be acid, it should not be sweet! The flavors of this one are a great mix of sourness and acidiy without being overpowering. I really enjoyed this lambic.

Draught version.
Cloudy orange brown with a hint of red. Thin white head. Sour youghurtlike aroma. The flavor is sourcream like with hints of chives and bluecheese. Sourish finish. A middle of the road benchmark gueze
The only gueuze that is still brewed in Brussels.Extremely acidic..I LOVE it, I agree its not the most balanced of gueuze,but hard to find and worth the price

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2003 Aroma has sulphur, grass, citrus, apple and oak. 
The apple and oak I found in the taste is dominated by an overpowering sourness. Dry mouthfeel. For experienced beer drinkers only. 
Vintage 2002: geuze-lambic bio. Fairly light color. Overwhelming aroma of sulphur, ctrus, oak, honey and cheese. Harsh sulphury sourness. Citrus, oak vanilla and apple in the flavor. Some vinegar and hops. Delicious and very complex geuze. Young and a bit harsh, but will ease down and get even more complex in a few years. Great beer!
Served form tap. Pale amber coloured, hazy. Acidic nose. Tart, champagne like. Refreshing and complex. th edruaght version appears more mellow than the bottled.
one awesome lambic...the champagne characteristics are there in the aroma...the most tart beer ive ever tasted. yet it doesnt leave a sour taste on the palate....awesome!

On tap, Toronado (SF). I havent had this in many many years and this is much better than I remember it... You never cross the same beer twice. Beautiful headless grapefruit and golden color. Served less than 48°F Cloudy but no yeast bodies unlike most bottles Ive seen. Lively grapefruit and cider with sweet tart feel that doesnt command a pucker. Fairly tame -- I was expecting something much wilder. Now at the bottom of the glass Im certain I could drink 10 more.

I wanted to like this. I shoulda waited for a hot August day to try it...Very champagne like presentation out of the bottle except for the foamy persistence of the head. Winey, cidery, yogurty lactic aroma. Odd color seemingly golden at the top and more yellow at the bottom...an illusion? Very sour, grapefruity tart, not what I think of as beer. Ive had gueuze before but not this one. I thought I was ready for Cantillons gueuze but better stick to their fruit lambics from now on. Rating is out of respect, I didnt really enjoy this that much...didnt note great complexity, overwhelmed by tartness. After drinking it, I still wanted a beer.

Champagne like flavour, Golden cloudy appearance,

Sour and acidic! 

Probably the best cult beer in the world!

Really Great!!!

Very nice and relatively persistant off-white head of foam over a typical, cloudy amber brew, with quite lively and very fine bubbles.
Subdued but typical gueuze aromas, barnyard, yeasty and cheesy aromas of adequate but not great intensity.
Very fine lacy mouthfoam, sour and of rather light intensity, with slight silkiness, clean and of good quality.
Rather light-bodied and not extremely long in the mouth, but fine and satisfying.
A very fine gueuze, quite civilized yet sour character.  I would say this one does not score in barnyard ecological as much as in the field of fine character, which is a meant to be a compliment in another sense!

I like lambic beer and I really enjoyed this.  Sour and acidic, so if you dont like these qualities then you wont like this.  Cloudy and yeasty, winelike, but it does not taste like wine per se, as some claim.  Overall, just delicious!  Will buy again.
this was great,the nose was woody,fruity,musty,it was golden,and cloudy in apperence,great flavor sour,tart,kind of like bitting into a grape seed very refreshingwith a dry finish

A cloudy yellow, lots of fiz. Some head collapse but persistent. I love the aroma, I dont know what it is but makes my mouth water. Sour, fruity aromas that are immense. Acidic, tart,oak stands out.  Sour green apple flavors come out as well. Drying at first but becomes very juicy. Smooth, sharp and one hell of a body. Great stuff.

Here is a beer I havent been able to find for two years, yet I caught myself tasting it the other day after two years without...talk about finish.  Arguably one of the top Lambics.  A biting sour like a lemon with teeth.  This is a beer which makes a pipe smoker buck up.  Yet all exxageration aside, (though I am serious about tasting it two years after the fact)I am sipping it again now and I find it though tart quite round and smooth, bodied and oak flavoured.  A first rate Lambic!

I wanted to like this more than I did.  It was definitely very complex, but the acidity really took a lot away from my ability to enjoy drinking this.  That said it was decent chasing a bowl of mussels down the hatch.  Better with food.
weirded me out. slimy, salty, sour, grassy. have to have a few more bottles to figure it all out

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2004 re-rate 29-2-2004: Barnyard, fruity, oak aroma. Hazy, yellow color, small white head, no lace. Oak, tart, sour, complex fruits, little cheesy, sweet finish, full. 2-1-1999, 3.4: Very sour and you taste the oak it was kept in.

I had this hand-pumped at Toronado: what an experience.  Sour, tart, and incredibly brisk and refreshing.  Clearly a style that takes some getting used to, which can be expensive.  If this beer is any indication, it might just be a taste worth cultivating.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 bottled in 2000, sampled June 2003 - bright, orange colour, fine head, complex nose of rhubarb, cellar and old apples, fresh and acid, light oily mouthfeel, long dry and very acid fruity finish - lot of character and not intended for beginners
One of the greats.
